Dear Dr. Jordan Peterson, I was watching the talk that you gave at Oxford Union. I was extremely shocked at the statement you made. Here was your statement, â€œLife is essentially suffering. I believe that to be a fundamental truth.â€ This statement is the most FALSE STATEMENT I have ever heard in my entire life, and I am 62 years old. I am not sure if your ignorance comes from your advanced education or your personal life experience. I am not using the word â€œignoranceâ€ as an insult. I am using the word for the definition of the word. Here is the definition: The condition of being ignorant; the lack of knowledge in general, or in relation to a particular subject; the state of being uneducated or uninformed. You are not uneducated; however, you are greatly lacking knowledge, unaware, and uninformed. I was also very shocked to see that you have millions of followers. Which from my viewpoint you are misleading millions of people. Let me tell you what suffering actually is, since obviously you do not know. In life, we all will experience pain. However, how we handle or deal with that pain is a choice, a personal choice. Many times that choice is made subconsciously or unconsciously. Some people will rise above the pain and others will choose to let the pain destroy them and put themselves in a state of suffering.  Pain and suffering are two very different things. Pain can be emotional, mental, and/or physical. However, the state of suffering is only a mental construct; suffering is only in the mind. I will be sharing this letter openly on my social media and website because I feel this is a very important topic. There are many people in the world putting themselves in a state of suffering unnecessarily. I want to help people come out of their self-imposed state of being. However, you as a professional psychologist seem to be doing the exact opposite with your false statement above.  I see that you have a YouTube channel with over 7 million subscribers. I would love to have a conversation with you about this topic on your channel or mine. I have been hosting a podcast for 9 years, Awake 2 Oneness Radio. You are invited to be my guest anytime. It has been my experience that whenever I send someone with a large following an open letter to have a conversation, they do not respond, and refuse to have the conversation with me. It will be interesting to see if you accept my invitation to have a conversation publicly.  I hope to receive a reply from you and have the opportunity to have a conversation with you on this important subject matter. Much Love & Appreciation, Caroline

â€œHe who has a why to live for can bear almost any how.â€ â€• Friedrich Nietzsche This quote reminds me of an argument I made recently. If you don't want to read the whole thing, my conclusion is at the end: Porn is not an addiction. It's a compulsion. I advise everyone to stop lying and making it out to be uncontrollable. I had a compulsion towards it due to trauma I endured as a child but I worked hard and I make an effort everyday to see people as humans and not anything else. Men and women alike. We are dependent on something with addiction. But with compulsion, it is simply an overwhelming urge, fed by our weaknesses. If you want to fix a compulsion, you have to build up a tolerance. Strengthen your mind with self discipline and a clear reason as to why you should stop. Remember that reason, and build onto it. Whether it be out of respect of the body, or for your future family. Everyone has a choice, sometimes they just haven't found a 'why'.

Dr Jordan Peterson is a wonderful man. His two 12 Rules For Life books have helped me enormously since I read them earlier this year and I am an avid follower of his large body of online content too. I would love to meet him one day to say thank you, but I could not get the ticketing websites to work when looking into buying a ticket for his current lecture series, whether in Amsterdam, Belfast or London.  12:35 we need a low-resolution description of the world to move through it effectively: a "general existential theory", an agreed-upon narrative of ourselves 14:00 one option is collectivist, dating back to monke (and again dominant in postmodern culture): a human is a tribe(s) member, reality a battleground for tribal power > mayhem 16:40 another option is [individualist], developed in Western (especially British) culture: a human is a sovereign individual, with rights & responsibilities > peace and (unequal) wealth 18:15 answer[?]: the effort of [political correctness in] universities to "sacrifice the sovereign individual view for the collective tribal view ... is appalling beyond forgiveness" [so, no?]  19:00 Q2: isn't Peterson's [Nietzschean] view of TRUTH as a value for life itself "postmodern"? 19:20 postmodern view: in mid-60s, multiple disciplines realised there are "infinite ways to perceive the world"; postmodern thinkers concluded that therefore "there's no justifiable grand narrative" for world-orientation, and ironically fled to a Marxist collectivist narrative 22:00 Peterson's (darwinist) view: scientific truth is (somehow) distinct from ethical truth, which evolves from animal behavior into "the central axioms of civilized human behavior", based on fixed patterns/rules governing functional interaction between organisms over time (e.g. to play, big rat has to let small rat win 30% of the time)  24:50 so yes there are infinite interpretations of the world, but only some are practically operational, all following a general pattern which is first acted out, then expressed in stories and images, and only then consciously articulated 26:35 the truth, despite postmodernism, is that "there is something that approximates a universal human ethic built deeply into our biological and social structures"  Summary of the whole argument: A general ethical pattern governs the interactions between organisms most beneficial to their survival and flourishing (their pursuit of value) across the long term. This natural pattern is first implicit in behavior, then represented in mythology, and then articulated in philosophy and science. Western liberal democracy (and its narrative of sovereign individuality, itself preceded by the Biblical doctrine of man's creation in the image of God) is its highest expression, sustaining history's best-functioning societies by keeping the irreducible tension of hierarchy and equality in balance through free discussion. Postmodernism flees from the problem of competing values into Marxist collectivist narrative, masking it as political correctness, a misguided and malicious attempt to destroy this implicit and explicit ethic, which can result in nothing but destruction of life.  Question for discussion: Is it really so that of all cultural systems, only Judeo-Christian > Enlightenment 'individualism' succeeds in maintaining and perfecting the natural ethic, while all non-Western models are a blind and destructive 'collectivism'? Does this not contradict e.g. Peterson's own admiration for classical Chinese civilization? Nietzsche knew perfectly well that we aren't masters of our own house, and that our actions are a product of a multitude of unconscious drives. He said that very often the way we feel about something on a particular day could be influenced by something as trivial as what we had for dinner the day before, for example, and that rationality is merely an instrument of the unconscious. He also knew that the average person isn't capable of consciously creating values. His "Superman" concept is a new type of human with an integrated unconscious who is capable of generating values. Other than that bit of misleading information, this is a great talk by Peterson.

Mon 11 Jul 2022 19.24 EDT  Nasa has released an image of far-flung galaxies as they were 13bn years ago, the first glimpse from the most powerful telescope ever launched into space, which promises to reshape our understanding of the dawn of the universe. Itâ€™s an historic moment for science and technology, for USA and all of humanity.â€  Bill Nelson, administrator of Nasa, said the image showed the light of galaxies bending around other galaxies, traveling for billions of years before reaching the telescope. â€œWe are looking back more than 13 billion years,â€ he said, adding that more images to be released by the space agency would reach back further, to about 13.5 billion years, close to the estimated start point of the universe itself. â€œWe are going back almost to the beginning,â€ he said. Experts have said the telescope, three decades in the making and launched last year, could revolutionize our understanding of the cosmos by providing detailed infrared images of the universe.  The initial goal of the project was to see the first stars and galaxies formed following the big bang, watching â€œthe universe turn the lights on for the first timeâ€, as Eric Smith, Webb program scientist, put it. The nebula is about 7,600 light years away and is home to many enormous stars, several times larger than the sun.  Other areas of focus include WASP-96 b, a giant planet outside our solar system that is made mainly of gas; the southern ring nebula, an expanding cloud of gas surrounding a dying star thatâ€™s 2,000 light years from Earth; and Stephanâ€™s quintet, notable for being the first compact galaxy group discovered in 1877. Â Rainbow ChateauÂ  Jordan Petersons 12 rules for life most certainly had the most impact on me. You have to start from the ground up and go through discomfort to move forward. Getting up early, making my bed every morning and keeping my personal space clean, tidy and organised was a good foundation.  I then started doing push ups every day as exercise, and then cold showers, cold showers had a massive impact on me after a few weeks, it taught me to go through discomfort, and then other little steps which became easier and easier.  It is very important to not just make little improvements but to remain consistent with them everyday after a while many good and positive habits will compound over weeks and months and will build into much bigger positive things in your life.  I now wake up at 6.30 am most mornings without an alarm, my home is spotless and organised, I wild swim every morning workout 3 times a week, read one book a week, with all this on point work and grinding towards my goals is easy, I do have short lapses where I put things off to the next day, but if I try and do that I have my own mental prosses to just do NOW, just don't put things off, just do them now.    12 rules for life helped me immensely on my journey and pointed me in the right direction but bottom line it's your journey and you have to take action yourself, if you can't help yourself then no one will.    Look in the mirror and ask your self is this a reason why I can't do something or just an excuse, bottom line you have to take action and be happy being uncomfortable at the start.   Hope this helps

Â @MarcusHitchÂ  Well, I don't mind if people are idealistic. It's when they violently reject ANYTHING/EVERYTHING which opposes their ideals.  That is fanatical.   When I mentioned his sentiments & being arguably incorrect, I was referring to the entire body of his interviews that I've seen, not this video specifically.   But, I was really just pointing-out that I'm not some Peterson "fan boy," I DO disagree with some of his opinions.   Example: This is literally off the top of my head, so bear with me, but he strongly suggested he believes that a broad sense of responsibility is congruent with "individual purpose" and/or "giving life meaning."   For him (and people like him) this is absolutely true.   But, people who are "free spirits" (like me) are only ever BURDENED by responsibility. I've had corporate management jobs in which I was responsible for millions of dollars of equipment, dozens of employees, and the daily delivery of 4,000-10,000 parcels of mail.  I was NEVER so unhappy in my life.

â€‹Â @mycommentpwnzÂ  If following an ideology was simply being a bit "idealistic" I'd concur, but I don't think being ideological and being idealistic are the same at all... I'd freely admit to being a bit idealistic at times. I'm autistic and the two can go hand in hand, in my opinion. But my idealism accepts it doesn't have the all the answers, and is still open to persuasion... It also admits it doesn't even fully understand what would be "ideal" and knows that my notion of ideal might not be the same as everyone else's in any case, and therefore seeks a rational, moral consensus.  Ideology doesn't work like that. It knows the answers. It's already decided what the goal is, and how we get there... anyone who doesn't agree with the ideological position MUST be therefore trying to oppose the stated aim, even if they share the stated aim but merely disagree with how it can be achieved. I don't think the ideological mind can imagine it is heading in the wrong direction tbh, because it always sees itself as "working towards the goal" even when it's actions are obviously counterproductive.  In fairness I'm not looking for a fight. I think we are broadly in agreement, and I freely cede that you didn't specifically state his arguments here (I don't agree with all his conclusions either. I see a certain bias towards a traditional nuclear family... for example, we cannot argue that marriage is necessarily best, because we cannot repeat the experiment with the same child if the parents who couldn't stand each other stayed together "for the children" - I come from such a home and it was emotionally crippling. I wouldn't wish it on anyone... ahem...)   Oh, and of course I clocked the "arguably"... everything is arguably incorrect, so I certainly don't think you misspoke in any way... just a point on terminology... and I don't think your description of cult is all that far off tbh... ğŸ‘

Jordan seems to be making the same mistake that most liberals and probably many conservatives do in believing that hierarchies create inequality. This isn't accurate. The inequality already exists. Talent, resources, desire are already unequally distributed in the world. Even in a non-hierarchal structure you'd still see those with more talent performing better at those tasks. Hierarchies really just organize inequalities into a structure the exacerbates inequality and makes it more noticeable. Hierarchies are simply the best way to address that there are inequalities and get the most value from them. It is this added value that really highlights the inequality. After all when everyone is hungry and has very little it may be hard to see who is the poorest, but when the group is much richer it is easy to see who is the poorest.

To Jordan Peterson:  I was just rereading bits of Carlos Castaneda, the part about giving back to people who gave you something.   I can give you a little.  50 years of psychotherapy with drugs made me very sick, physically and weak mentally and emotionally. I was called disabled by someone who was a malpractitioner, plain and simple.  But I, knowing he was off base, still accepted the  whole 30 years of it.    That isn't what I have to offer.  I was religious, increasingly, and once a therapist, utterly unable to understand me, started to practice Hindu medicine, which she had spent 3 weekends learning (a 5,000 year old practice, as I  understand it) my spirit was wary, and then she did something extremely wrong and for the first time in my life I heard a voice, not standing there.  "Get out and don't come back"  I was stupid, and I told her.  But I left and then kicked me out formally.  I got off the 30 something pills a day, opiates, antipsychotics,  muscle relaxers, three antidepressants, Gabapentin, ativan, etc... and within 3 months the excruciating pain caused by more and more drugs my body could never withstand from the  beginning, went away completely, along with the anxiety, the depression.  I went from walking hard breathing so bad E.R. physicians would throw me on a gurney thinking I was either having a stroke or a heart attack, walking bent over with a cane to walking 3 miles a day with no problem, no cane...no shortness of breath.  God  worked with me 24/7 for 8 months. I was troubled when I had started by being thrown out by a husband so his girlfriend could move in,  and then more troubled by the therapists  abuse for 30 years.   And the journey now is worthwhile.  I learned a little later complementing what God gave me, that I took a little of from Henry Cloud.   My parents had been extremely emotionally abusive.  And my mother became more so.  And I left that relationship.  But I went to school to a master's program, and they fought me, put obstacles, because I am religious.  The "woke" school.  I had never heard of it. But such cruelty.  I know  now, but didn't then, that they had really no power.  I made a mistake in thinking for a long time they did, and resenting it  for a long time.  When I left, the doors shut.  I couldn't go back.  I knew i wasn't supposed to.  But I didn't want to fail to finish.  I didn't know one can cut  anything off anytime, like Castaneda says, though I had read him in the 1970s.    When I left, God showed me scriptures, and as I pondered it, he showed me one more, especially.  One was he took me from "hands too strong" and at the time they were stronger than mine.  The other was as I prayed and meditated and as I had been for 30 years, wrote Morning pages, suggested in The Artist's Way by Julia Cameron, I found myself writing a Manual of Works, ways to write (I had been studying poetry in graduate school, but wanting to write plays, and I am also a visual artist.  I had undergraduate degrees in both art studio and English literature.  In school they said, we don't do plays here, but they let me  take an elective in Ceramics and I took 3) and paint and write not only poetry but plays, songs...And I found the other scripture...."The Messiah is the only  teacher."  And I had seen the messiah, over 25 years  before in a church when as an atheist and a suicidal, drugged to stupor by the doctors woman, I had  gone  back to church (I had  been saved at age 20) for all the services during Holy Week just "to see if something is there".  And when I saw Him the gospel was being read, "Blessed are those who have not seen and yet believe."  I wasn't like them.  I always had to know or I would not believe anything.  What I am saying is, the  path leads a long way, and for me it is still very fruitful.  There is more to the universe than a mindset in psychology can know. Jesus said, "the way is narrow and few there are who find it."  Castaneda's Don Juan said, people who believe there own thoughts measure things enough, who are  mostly concerned with themselves and what they think, forget they are going to die and Castaneda's books, like Jesus fierce focus when he knew how close the end was, make it apparent, we have little time.    But inside people, they have their desires.  And outside people, they have a marvelous universe, well beyond their rooms, however clean they are. Jesus said that one woman, a  Mary, chose best to listen.  One wanted her to clean the room.  It is odd how things recur.  Take a look at the  gospels.  Maybe at Castaneda.  Break up your  psychology school inside.  You are helping certain people, but I get the impression you are helping them push back at the lies or the categories, or the whole culture they can't find a place in.  They might have some time.   Jesus said there is a single way.   Don Juan says there are millions, but you have to pick one "with heart" and stay on as long as it has "heart" then get  off  because anything else  will destroy you.  This is all I have for you. He completely ignores the reason why political correctness became a thing in the first place.   His description about collectivist/tribal approaches is absolutely right. BUT, political correctness was an attempt to ensure that an individual would be treated with respect and NOT denigrated on the basis of their belonging to a tribal group seen as 'other'.  Has political correctness gone too far? Yes it has and this is a common failing of the left (and I am of the left). We try to go too far, too fast, and end up alienating the majority of people who tend to agree with our basic premise.  Peterson is an extremely intelligent man and although I disagree with a lot of what he says I find him stimulating. My disagreement with him is that, as with political correctness, he has a tendency to skate over inconvenient points. His speaking/lecturing/debating style is highly effective and highly deliberate. He speaks very quickly and does so to make it harder for his opponent and/or his audience to spot the gaps in his argument.  Take the 'gender pay gap'. He makes a very convincing argument as to why it is overblown (and I think it is grossly over-simplified) but one of his key tenets (that women do not negotiate well) ignores (deliberately) the role of socialisation. Females are socialised to be feminine. Ask most little girls what they want to be when they grow up and 'a princess' will feature prominently. Females who attempt to be more like males in some respects tend to be criticised for it. They are accused of being 'aggressive', 'domineering' 'mannish'. Look at Thatcher, Merkel for example. Their femininity is denied and they are ridiculed for it. A woman who might have the confidence to negotiate successfully has to weigh up the possibility that her attempt will backfire in a way a man does not, and she will be taken LESS seriously for it.  That being the case, I think he summed up western political history extremely well and it was worth watching the video just for that.

There are a lot of problems with trying to rectify historical inequalities and atrocities with gestures of economic/positional advantage.  Most fundamentally, can they ever truly make up for past horrors (since it isn't actually the victims that are being compensated, but rather, their descendants) and at what point is the debt consider repaid?  How exactly can we measure when the debt is repaid?  If it goes on indefinitely then you are codifying  a tribal advantage (i.e. an advantage based on identity which necessarily excludes everyone else).  Also, how can we expect that this won't then perpetuate a cycle of inequality when those who are outside the favored group inevitably feel the sting of being left out?   Another problem lies within how humans grow accustomed to these advantages as to form a new baseline of expectation to the point that when they are one day ceased, you then will leave the subsequent generation who by happenstance of arriving to the party too late, do not get enjoy the same benefit.  These actions do not, and necessarily cannot rectify inequality--they simply kick the can down the road.

I believe you are cherry picking Dr Petersons auguments to suit your own theories and beliefs. Hierarchies seem to exist in most human activities & endeavours.   However those hierarchies must be examined and challenged when they threaten and damage the balance and stability of the whole. ie:- countries/societies. And impede the individual's ability to live lives as they seem fit within the law. Or to be allowed to challenge that law within the mechanism of that hierarchy without threat or harm.   Throwing out labels, insults & epiphets like "Neo-Marxists and Leftists" or conversely "Nazis and right wingers" is a very convenient tactical way for us to ignore the actual issues & practicalities of complex situations & problems.

Â @moosic2iÂ  : The problem becomes when people think hierarchy = government, when this is not the case.  Governments, while a function of society -- and thus a political collective -- also should only be involved when one individual trespasses against the rights of another individual. That's the function of government, which is the preservation of individual rights.  The collectives I'm talking about are more the types that think that the "greater good" is more important than the sovereignty or the autonomy of the individual, such as the Neo-Marxists and the Progressive Left, who are, without a doubt, trying to use identitarian intersectionalism to convert a society that is supposed to be about each individual being equally protected under the law, to one of a caste system, where a political intersection of sex or race determines one's worth, thus one's position within the society as part of a group identity or group community.  This is why, rather than talk about individuals who might be black, for example, or Hispanic, you never hear talk about individuals, but rather the "black community" or the "Hispanic community," despite the fact up until recent years, those communities were first and foremost part of the American community. This is also why there is never talk about helping all those, irrespective of race, who are at a certain economic level in society. That would blur and destroy racial or gender differences for policy reasons, yet the Left doesn't want to let go of those differences, despite the fact that helping one group over another would be discrimination against a group not helped. For example, instead of having "opportunity zones" for black communities, how about making it easier for all people, groups and individuals alike, to have access to opportunity zones? This is why Trump actually did a couple of good things with the First Step Act and Music Modernization Act -- both things that, while taken advantage of by mostly blacks, is accessible to everyone meeting a situational condition: Being in prison (FSA), or being a singer-songwriter (MMA).   These are but a couple of examples where government did things right, despite the motivation being to help one group -- black people -- over others. This is why affirmative action failed as a policy, yet the First Step Act has been a resounding success.  In essence, always give an individual a set of conditions to meet, instead of biasing a policy for one group, and against another. Doing so always backfires.  And believe me, I'm always about questioning things like social hierarchy and challenging it -- but if I find it to work, after such an examination, then that's what I'm going to say and not question it further at that time. Besides, the first things I look at is the claim against something being a problem, and making sure it's a valid and sound claim. After that, I try and determine, in the case of hierarchies, why they might not be good, or might not be working. And then go from there.  However, I will give the major difference between men like JP and a Neo-Marxist or Progressive: JP, like me, believes in merit and choices an individual makes, which is something an individual can control -- thus outcomes are controllable. Neo-Marxists and Progressives want outcomes based on things a person has no control over, such as biological sex or race. This is why the Neo-Marxists and their allies are pushing for political identitarian intersectionalism. This is no different than a traditional Marxist thinking that because a person was a "worker," that they were somehow a victim of the "capitalist," who "owned the means of production," and thus was stealing allegedly surplus labor from the worker. The point that classical or traditional Marxists miss is that first, an employment contract is one the worker agreed to, legally-speaking. Second is that the Marxist never takes into account the autonomy a worker can exercise and change economic positions. I also think that classical Marxists make the mistake of thinking that workers in 1840 are the equivalent of industrial serfs, which was not the case, as workers in both the UK and US were technically free to choose something other than what they ended up doing.

"Marxists want what never was, and never will be: A society without hierarchy."  I beg to differ.  They most definitely want a society with a hierarchy; but one in which they're at the top of that hierarchy.  To achieve that goal, however, requires they destroy the existing hierarchy.  Their talk of utopia, egalitarianism, equality, and a class-less society are simply covers for their malicious designs as well as appeals to the well-meaning but naive members of society who are taken in by their rhetoric.  The thought leaders of post modernism and Neo-Marxism need cannon fodder for their "glorious" revolution; because they certainly aren't going to risk their own necks fighting for what they believe in.  Better to volunteer somebody else to do the killing and dying on their behalf.  Make no mistake: they want power and they consider no price too high nor anything too sacred to sacrifice in achieving it.  Thus must they always be guarded against; most especially in the universities where young, impressionable, and idealistic minds are easy prey for their corrupt ideology.

Â @JohnDoe-zl6qwÂ  : I can honestly say that I, and JP, would most certainly agree with everything you've said.  Interestingly enough, your reply is exactly what Orwell wrote in Animal Farm, about how the farm animals kicked out the farmers (destroying the existing hierarchy), but at the end of the book, the pigs basically became what they had destroyed. Therefore, I see no reason to even doubt, let alone refute, what you've stated. And you're also right that the leaders of Neo-Marxism and Post-Modernism, those who have picked up the mantle from the original thinkers, they are doing everything they can to basically train their officer cadre and NCOs for what they see as a militant revolution. And, no doubt, those leaders would never actually lead from the front. As Magneto said in the X-Men movie where Jean Grey died, "Ah, ah, ah. In chess, the pawns always go first."

Research presented at theÂ ACM FAT 2020Â conference in Barcelona today supports the notion that YouTubeâ€™s platform is playing a role in radicalizing users via exposure to far-right ideologies.  The study, carried out by researchers at Switzerlandâ€™s Ecole polytechnique fÃ©dÃ©rale de Lausanne and the Federal University of Minas Gerais in Brazil, found evidence that users who engaged with a middle ground of extreme right-wing content migrated to commenting on the most fringe far-right content. I started with a fairly negative bias against JP because I came to know about him from articles and videos that were critical of him. There is a great video series called the alt-right playbook (its pretty good work, and well presented) which avoids naming him but it has lots of criticisms of certain points of view, and a comment stated that some of the viewpoints were those of JP. Another was an article which vilified JP for defending James Damore - who i think seriously lacked foresight and made a staggering blunder. I mean, he stated in his posts that women were more susceptible/sensitive to negative feelings and emotions. That itself should have warned him how women and thereby google HR will see it. Also, he probably didn't have the eloquence or knowledge of JP to back himself (even if he had, he wouldn't be given the chance to defend himself anyway).  These sources had formed a very negative picture of JP in my head... However, I was curious about how JP did it!! I mean, the way his points of views had been presented to me - thy were almost indefensible to any sensible person. How did JP do it? What did he say that millions of people (who I had no reason to assume were malicious) had been so affected by his words that they had decided to side with these seriously flawed, seemingly extreme and possibly harmful points of views (as they had been portrayed to me)?  Once I had seen a few of his videos... I am completely blown away. I am appalled in the way the left leaning sources have tried to malign his message - its nowhere near how it has been portrayed. They are seriously doing themselves a disservice, and losing their credibility in the process. They might gain a little in the short term, but will lose big time in the long term, as people come to know the underhanded and malicioius ways they are operating. Morality exists for humans and for animals and for rats. Morality is a system of interactions between entities, which over time, seek to make those interactions less hostile, less confrontational, less likely for them to get into conflict with one another.  In essence, the players in any social system, gradually learn how to "get along" with eachother, to greater or lesser degrees, so that they don't end up fighting with one another.  To a large extent, the creatures are trying to create a system that is "fair".  This is a widely-sought goal amongst many people and animals. Also from a singular point of view, having fewer conflicts during a day, means that you don't have to spend as much energy, each and every day, fighting against other entities in your world.

The weakness in Peterson's evolutionary construction is exposed by the question asked at 39:00.  His position contradicts his idea of Logos and follows the Hegelian notion of dialectics, i.e., that truth derives from the conflict between thesis and anti-thesis.  This completely negates the concept of Logos not existing in the realm of discourse but in the realm of necessity.  If the Second Law of Thermodynamics is true at all then certainly it includes the realm of ideas.  In any transfer of energy there is loose, so why does this not include the process of discussion? And if it doesn't then the Hegelian dialectic is nothing more than the de-evolution of Human understanding.  Though I think Hegel was on to something (although rather simplistic if applied to Human understanding) as a process it may have value in the realm of engineering.  The error of Hegal is to assume this is a progressive process within philosophy when in fact all out scientific data suggests it is in fact subject to entropy to where the result of the process is less organized and less complex.  Anyone who follows history should at very least question whether our own culture is the product of progress or teetering on coherent collapse and materialism.

Except that a rock can fly, in much the same way an aeroplane can, by the external application of force. Also a rock can be something else; it can be transformed into a sculpture for example. Who goes to see Michelangelo's David and says "wow, look at that rock"? A rock is only a rock by virtue of human categorisation. Granite and limestone, for instance are chemically completely unrelated. They're both rocks only because humans find a convenient equivalence in both of them being "hard stuff on the ground". A=A does not hold if A is Rock.

Â @ekkithump783Â  I would suggest Aristotle (who was a man of great thinking) explained his quote in this manner so even the simplest person could understand it.  An external application of force is just that, External, Not of its own Accord.  For example,  A bird of Prey can fly on its own Accord, without any external application of Force, whereas a Pig Cannot! I often remind myself Knowledge is Power,  But not without Wisdom, And Wisdom is knowing how little we know!

Â @johnhsmith9207Â  Unless the bird's wings are injured, for instance. Don't get me wrong, I'm not questioning his law of identity as a logical construct, but when you try to take Aristotle's insight out of the realm of pure logic and into the real world, you quickly run into the problem that any "thing" which human consciousness identifies is not a single thing at all, but a set of different things grouped under one label for some reason. Which is fine and good enough in some circumstances. Let A be "tiger" and you have a hunter gatherer who doesn't get eaten, and the fundamental non-identity of tigers be damned. On the other hand, let A be "fuel" and you have diesel in your petrol engine; let A be "a black person" and you have racist stereotyping. I would suggest that wisdom in this case is knowing that in the realm of human life and thought, A usually does not equal A, but that sometimes, if we're careful, it's useful to pretend it does.

Â @mrrandom132-x2nÂ  One of the theories that I've seen is that the contents of the big bang were everything that was in the previous universe, that expanded like ours and eventually started shrinking again until everything was in a single place, then it exploded, "restarting" the universe. 29:46 For what it's worth, I am a Liberal who shifted from questioning the existing order to questioning the ideas of those wishing to overthrow the existing order.  The way I see it, I've already figured out a lot about the existing order... it's something finite which I've already lived within the bounds of, so that is an easy task, relatively speaking.  The possibilities outside that existing order and their potential outcomes are a far more vast and interesting territory to conquer.  So no one should assume the Liberally minded will only be interested in tearing down the existing order... there's far more spoils of war in bringing down the onslaught of bad ideas amassing at the gates of our existing order.  Likewise, I do not see why anyone would assume the enemies of our existing order would all be the Liberally minded when their own schools of thought have already become very structured and dogmatic, and have their own hierarchy and increasingly malignant order of their own.  It's foolish to not see the dogmatic cultural Marxist as a type of conservative who is just trying to force an old idea to work.  Tribalism has caused people to misuse these sorts of terms as names for teams in the sport of ideas, when they are more like positions on the field held by both teams.

This is exactly the essence of Hinduism, all inclusive .. He has very good intentions.  Let me make one more try to explain.  Think of history as peaks and valleys.  The valleys are the calm self stabilizing periods where deviation is pulled back away from the slopes of deviation.  Deviation is going uphill to higher and higher resistance.  The peaks are the unstable periods.  Deviation upsets the balance and a little bit of change can pull on the whole mass and move attitudes quickly in a radical direction.  Socially and politically we live on one of those peaks and being pulled by a relatively few towards madness.  Trying to sit on flag pole maintaining your balance during a wind storm is suicide.  In periods like these you have only two choices.  Total resistance or appeasement.  Jordan Peterson path is appeasement and in the short term seems less painful but there is a crash at the end.  Total resistance is harder and often times futile but if you survive you will be there to pick up the pieces of the train wreck that society is heading for.  You will be battered and bruised but you will have the ultimate victory.

This is logical fallacy because you can't understand mass with respect to itself.  You have to have a reference point where similar patterns occurred before in history.  It won't transfer perfectly. Peterson has incredible mental focus.  But I get the sense that he falls into some common traps for psychologists, like teleological thinking and anthropomorphizing (for instance, here, describing the primitive orienting reflex in terms of higher understanding, rather that just as a reaction to novel stimuli) or in wanting to use Darwinian evolution to make psychological phenomena more material and less ephemeral or epiphenominal. (Biologists are said to have physics-envy; psychologists seem to have biology-envy.)  The views of evolutionary psychologists (and anthropologists) often violate basic principles of evolution, genetics and developmental biology, frequently along lines of neo-Lamarkianism.  "Extended manifestations of the orienting reflex" might be very adaptive, but insofar as they aren't themselves heritable and the apparent capacity to have them is an unlikely target of selection they are probably off the radar of evolution.  And even if an embued sense of 'meaning' in a person might reflect an "optimal" negotiation between evolved, adaptive instincts and de novo functional reactions in a variable environment there would be no selection response for any particular solution (since it would not be heritable) and likely no movement of that individual's lineage across the fitness landscape of the population for this phenotypically "noisy" trait. Even Peterson, himself, says, "The brain operates AS IF the most real thing is the meaning of something".  Only in models is evolution omniscient.  Sub-optimality is reality.  Generalists often out-perform specialists... while going unnoticed by selection.  Even if evolution overlooks it life is pretty sloppy.

So the premise is that 'if you're going to pursue something of value, then you have to move forwards' and that the pursuit of these 'things of value' is how we offset the 'suffering' that is life. Beyond that, the hierarchy is untenable without this pursuit. Sorry Jordan, but that's the the point at which you lost me. Its a fundamentally flawed tenet on which you've hung the entire balance of your argument. I suspect that this highly intelligent snake oil salesman is fully aware of, is that it's the very pursuit of what he refers to as 'value' that causes is us to be unhappy. The question Peterson acolytes refuse or are unable to ask, is what is this 'value' that to which he constantly refers?  The truth is that real wealth and happiness is somewhat simpler to derive if one is prepared to be open to the metrics by which such notions are assessed. Frankly, I'd also take Mr Peterson more seriously if he could discuss these 'principles' without the endless references to which of his books contain them.   In summary, I suppose the simpler truths would be less satisfying to those who can't find meaning in their life, for the most part part because like Peterson, they think there is some higher level or because they need some reason to justify their endless pursuit thereof. In reality, however, if you wish to find joy and happiness, the path is clear. Open your eyes and be as open to seeing what is wondrous in life just as often as you do to examine what you perceive as being missing. That singular process will offer more of a quantum leap to a higher understanding than any number of Mr Petersons expensive tomes.

I understood clearly how JBP defines "value", as did Shakespeare when he wrote, "To Be, Or Not to Be", or Sartre when he wrote, "Being and Nothingness". You may think you have chosen a different path than an "endless pursuit of an undefined value", but for you, as with all of us, the pursuit will most assuredly end.  Make Hay while the sun shines my organic cell based friend, who cannot help to grow, change and pursue value by choosing life over death.

Â @nuqwestrÂ  I think if you read my comment again, then yours, you'll find you've actually reiterated, in some regards, the very point I made. That said, I'd strongly dispute that the line Peterson is pushing is that the 'pursuit of value' is merely the choice between life and death and you yourself have stated, quite rightly, that were that the case, the latter option is inevitable in any case. I do agree that we should 'make hay while the sun shines', as you put it, but that philosophy requires no 'pursuit', but rather a greater appreciation.   As in all things, it's a case of each to their own. By all means, my fellow 'organic cell-based friend', adopt and adhere to Mr Peterson's world view if it benefits you. That is after all preferable to to the alternative. My point was simply that there are valid alternatives that are less rooted in one's sense of self. I've simply offered one option that is rooted in being more open to allowing oneself to acknowledge wonder, love, enjoyment where we find it. Put simply, all those emotions and feelings that make life not just survivable, but joyous.   Thank you for your comment and interaction in any case. It's good and healthy to assess these things from time to time and I appreciate you sharing your thoughts with me. I suspect our world-views are not so vastly different when observed outside of a Peterson-inspired framework and in so much, I wish you all the best for the future.

Â @nuqwestrÂ  you don't cancel them, but the people with larger audiences have them for reasons. The flat earth society isn't banned, but neither do they have view counts in the millions, because most individuals find their model lacking. The "we live in the Matrix" perspective has even fewer adherents, and they don't need to be banned. And certainly there's no need to push "we're all just figments of imagination" as a perspective, so it's clear that merely "having more perspectives" isn't a good goal.  Jordan seems to agree with the questioner that having a multiplicity of viewpoints is virtuous unto its own self, and I'm of the opinion that it's not. Having the ability for new best ideas to rise naturally to prominence is different from seeking out more new ideas regardless of accuracy just for the sake of saying "lookit all the diverse ideas!"

Â @michaelsorensen7567Â  I've heard JBP speak on "Free Speech" many times, he is not an absolutist 53:20. I fear your model because it is the tyranny of the majority, and pure democracy does not give us the greatest good for the greatest number.

Â @nuqwestrÂ  to be clear, I'm not for officials limiting speech. It's just that the questioner seems to think that is everyone's obligation to entertain every harebrained idea the same way they do people who actually know what they're talking about. Jordan got the platform because people agreed with him, not because the government promoted it. I'm not advocating for the government to stop the harebrained ideas, but it'd be nice if the government weren't pushing them for "equality" either. Jordan mentions how "we've done the experiment; the results are IN!" So imo there's no need to keep entertaining that flawed idea. People who want to can keep looking into it I suppose, and I'd certainly not want the truth to be suppressed regardless of its popularity, but promoting flagrant falsehoods purely for sake of ideological diversity seems to me a flawed approach.  In essence, I'm arguing for a less regulated status quo, where a "market of ideas" allows good ideas to rise and bad ideas to sink. Only I'd prefer it if the government and traditional media/social media weren't pushing for certain narratives.

In 1987 I began research on a subject that was not well published, and I would wait weeks for a book to arrive on inter-library loan, which I then had to return in 2-weeks. That drove me in 1994 to become one of the first WWW publishers, and to promote services like Wiki and search algorithms. Hypertext was a revolution in publishing. Unfortunately, there have been many unintended consequences from that revolution yet to be rectified and corrected. In 1994, Al Gore officially commercialized the WWW, and in doing so, pushed an economic model of EYEBALLS for sale. This was not the only choice at the time, but one forced on us by both government officials and economic predators, neither would consider the consequences of their actions. We tried, there was a "White Paper" suggesting a "public utility" version for bandwidth delivery, and a model of commerce less driven by "the mob", but it was ignored. EYEBALLS, 30 years later, are the product, more's the pity.

The conundrum he mentions about there being an infinite number of ways to see the world... is easy to resolve in a logical way when we recognize that there are two reciprocal types of truth. ABSOLUTE TRUTH is exactly what is, but we cannot know that truth. I step on a scale and it reads 160lb. But that's not what I actually weigh. That's just a RELATIVE REPRESENTATION of the [absolute truth]. The less accurate the representation the more relative it is. The more accurate the scale is that does the measuring, the closer to being [absolute truth] the measurement is... but no measure can ever express an actual [absolute truth]. Because even if we had such an infinitely accurate scale, it would take an infinitely long time to read the measurement. Thus absolute and relative truth are necessarily complementary (but incompatible and reciprocal) properties. Our goal is to express absolute truth, but the only way to do so is by using relative truths. And each of us mentally processes what that absolute truth is in a slightly different relative way. And that is the connection between the idea that the world should be a specific way and the reality that each of us sees the world in a unique way.

Â @noblermind8782Â  Thank you for the reply! That was a great summary and I agree with all of it.   I guess I'm trying to figure out what to do about the inevitability of losers in the system. His response seems to be that as long as there are not enough people with nothing to lose to destabilize the whole system, the system will last. He goes on to say that they would not be resentful if the system is not rigged by the wealthy i.e. it's not tampered with to become unfair.  However, it seems like we are already in that situation, both with too many people having nothing to lose and with the system being rigged.   His response is that we should fix the rigging and corruption of the system. I agree with all of this. However, I do think those 'people with nothing to lose' now need assistance to rectify the failings of the past, regardless of their source, but especially because it results from a failure to keep the system fair and that they are destabilizing the system.  The area I am struggling with is that many of the people who have nothing to lose are in that position because they are naturally predisposed to ending up in that position, by no choice of their own (this can be linked to key indicators along the Perato distribution). So shouldn't the system be setup so that even the losers would have the basics of human decency (food, shelter, hygiene etc.) to not only stabilise the system, but also have the added benefits of a reduction in crime (which is driven by inequality), return order and cleanliness to shared areas etc.  This would not remove incentive as it is still the lowest tier in the hierarchy and fear of failure would still exist.  This leads me to believe that Welfare Capitalism is the only reasonable response to this. And since that is further left than our current political system, it seems reasonable to be more left oriented in our current system.  This is by no means an extremist left view, which I think  can also be attributed to the fact of a too large number of people with nothing to lose, not only being driven by universities as he claims. We are already further down the road than he seems to think we are in this regard and the extremist left viewpoint is the resulting instability which he talks about.  A moderate left stance has no other choice to affect political change but to side with the left, and with the right only seeming to respond to the vocal extreme left minority, it seems the right is attacking the strawman of this group  and not allowing the system to rectify by a moderate shift to the left (which would be the most likely outcome with our moderate government always being driven by the healthy left-right interchange which is being driven by democracy) and therefore involuntarily contributing to the destabilization of the system by maintaining the downward spiral and enabling the extreme left, who are the manifestation of predictable instability.  There's a lot to unpack there, but your thoughts would be welcomed, thanks!

I think he is a brilliant man, but just as most intellectuals tend to think, there is an abstraction that takes place in the mind that allows for the argument to even be made. Like the concept of a frictionless plane; you will not find this anywhere in the world, but this concept can be used abstractly to understand certain theoretical properties of physics.  You can also, as he does, abstract the ideas of these motions and meaning towards a goal. But it really only works in abstraction. The reality and complexity of the human condition cannot be understood in these bilateral lines of position; conservative and liberal. These conditions have emerged in our recent history as human beings, but as far as we know that before large organized societies were on the scene there was no need for this dichotomy. So much of his argument makes sense as long as his base propositions are assumed true. And Well are they? I would argue no. Humans do not always work for goals that are about betterment of a persons individual position. He Rationalizes, "why then would you do it?" This is a failing in his imagination. And a failure to see reality beyond as it plays out beyond his abstractions. People sacrifice their lives and time and health for others. Soldiers fight wars and die. How is that moving toward a goal that is better? People risk their lives in all kind of ways. And yes, there are many people, individually and otherwise who do not make progress. They are content with the routine of their life. And yes, some do move ahead. But the real question is why, if it is not exclusively for improvement, for value? What other reasons could there be? Well we are quite malleable creatures as well. And first we also need to acknowledge the hierarchical regimes that emerged from distorted people who created or heavily influenced the hierarchy to the harm of many. The group did not establish value and create a hierarchy of competence. Not to mention social systems that promote incompetent people at the top. And furthermore, the very nature of hierarchical dominance is stubborn, but in a way he failed either to recognize or mention. In that supposed competent people get pushed to the top. But what of their children and other forms of nepotism? And inclusion of people with low competence. Just look as those who hold office today. Competent?  People can be motivated to move in all kinds of directions even toward things that have no value. And there is no consideration of wandering; not having any specific purpose at all, that could prove very dangerous and harmful or beneficial. This whole argument only works in the very oversimplified abstract notions that he proposed. Now what about the real world not this abstraction? Dr. Robert Sapolsky and he research on Baboons. I won't got into it here, but take a look at his findings. Also Richard Wilkinson and his team on social stratification and what he discovered. From the research literature that uses real world data the trend is seemingly toward equality. Things improve for the whole group the more equitable it is. Like how much more peaceful life was when you didn't have these large heavily populated social systems that need slavery to function. Who said that humans need to be organized in this way at all? The world is broad and complex and even for highly intelligent people this is true, the world is to big for a single individual to process and understand.  And therefore, as part and parcel to his work, he has to carve out an idea that ignores many real world pieces and full on spreads of data in order go anywhere. These abstractions only work in the imagination that strips away all of the noise and inconsistent incomprehensible data that we cannot wrap out singular heads around, effectively creating a notion that is only real when the very large body of incalculable data has been distilled into the fantasy of a narrow human imagination. It is not more than an idealistic middle ground that presupposes the permanence of dominate hierarchies that history itself does not attest to.

Noam's message challenges norms and provides real historical references as to the origin and intentions of certain political movements and stances. Libertarianism is NOT what you think. In fact, the highest ideal in such a society is to have as many slaves as one can.  The private sector is NOT accountable to the public. In truth, only a strong government can prevent large cooperations from abusing power against its workers, such as making them pay when people get injured for instance, prevent them from destroying the ecology, such as with Formosa in Texas. Only a strong government that is responsive to the people can do that. On the other hand if the government is weak, it is easily corrupted and cannot enforce its own laws and you get anarchy and various forms of violence at many levels. Libertarianism is about preventing you and me from telling the ownership class what to do with their power and influence. Again they are not responsible to the public. Sometimes the intentions of people who call for political correctness can be good and produce good things in an otherwise heartless society. It's not good to value sensitivity over truth. But it isn't good to undervalue an individual for the sake of truth either. One shouldn't value a truth more than the person that a truth was meant to value.  I see it like this; there are those who are concerned about whether to say "Happy Holidays" or "Merry Christmas." Well, if you have a problem with someone saying, "Happy Holidays," then you don't know the meaning of Christmas. And if you have a problem with someone saying, "Merry Christmas," you don't know the meaning of "happiness."  But if you have a concern about offending others, there's nothing wrong with wanting to say the right thing for the sake of another. There is nothing wrong with having a concern for offending people. What is wrong is when we become overly concerned with offending people. And who can judge the balance of that teeter totter accurately.  But, yes, we are, on the whole, too worried about saying the correct thing about many things. Still, I don't call a black person a negro. That doesn't mean I'm too politically correct. It means I have some character and sense, and yes, sensitivity. But what I find most interesting and ironic about the whole issue of political correctness is that the people who are so concerned about others being too easily offended, sure seem to be too easily offended.

Whilst I agree wholeheartedly with Mr Peterson regarding individual responsibility there are times when one has no choice but to form a tribe particularly when one is not being heard as an individual. Simple example. I hlive in a new build and across my road is a communal space that is a designated Green area. This area needs to be maintained every couple of weeks for which there is an annual fee.  The area is covered in weeds, it has been half seeded half turfed and surrounding trees are dying.  I go to the housing development company and ask for it to be investigated.  Nothing happens.  I ask three times, no response.  I decide to put posters through neighbours houses asking how they feel about the negligence of the company.  The majority respond and agree with my sentiment and concern.  I forward the emails to the construction company and on this occasion I get a response.  They are now listening to me.  Surely this is an example of where forming tribes is necessary in order do good for a community.  I was being rebuffed and ignored as an individual.

Jung revealed the distinguishing skill that catapulted Nietzsche into the league of Plato beyond perhaps even Schopenhauer, and Emerson. Nietzsche was highly trained as a classical philologist immersed in the original sources of Greek, Latin, and Hebrew. Hence, Nietzsche gained a profound knowledge of the greatest minds of antiquity and could read the source material in a direct first hand way and not rely on second hand accounts. Imagine being able to understand all the nuances of source material from the Bible in Hebrew or Plato in Greek to appreciate the nuances and meanings of texts directly rather than to accept second hand some other scholars interpretation of the passage. Nietzsche's devastating critique of the intellectual edifice of the times originated because he knew how the professors of the time masked the truth to push an agenda, protect an intellectual moat, or just hide the truth from themselves or others for either lack of courage, intellectual depth, or other sinister reasons. Nietzsche lived and breathed for the truth.   Just as a world class poker player has to live, breathe and sleep poker to be a world champion, a philosopher on the Olympian level of Nietzsche has to breathe the mountain air of truth every day in a way not possible for a man involved in a daily business or practice such as Jung. Sure, the business can keep the man "grounded", but to reach Nietzsche's Olympian level and full spectrum dominance philosophical level you need the foundational basics of classical philology combined with a passion and instinct for truth based off actual reading of ancient wisdom in the original. As German philosopher Schopenhauer observed, unless a man can read Latin and Greek in the original, there will always be a hole in the scholar's education that undermines the depth of his intellectual thought. This observation is a bitter pill for us all in a vapid age of mass media and hollow men. Nietzsche was just such an intellectual tour de force that we will probably never able to appreciate his greatness or sublime gifts to humanity. Greek and Latin are not emphasized in today's propaganda mills of liberal arts universities or even at the time of Jung when studying Latin and Greek required hard work most were not willing to endure.   Nietzsche was a sublime gift to humanity, and in fact his Navy Seal like attack on the soft, descendent Western philosophers and clergy of the time came with devastating force and mountain lightning speed. Ultimately though, Nietzsche's attack came out of a deep love for man and his no limit potential. Once the blinders came off and courageous, disciplined men were made aware of what the actual classical and Biblical texts meant free of some political or mercenary agenda, Nietzsche allows us all to share in the love for the search for truth. In this sense, Nietzsche, in exposing the agendas of many "translations" and university moat protecting "degrees" brings us all back to ourselves and our higher man potential once we breathe the mountain air of truth, and discover how the truth makes us all free from the agendas and deception of the establishment.

I found Peterson's introduction touched on some core fundamental truths. It's remarkable how his two propositions are loaded with spiritual wisdom. His analysis shows how humanity's misguided values have evoked a perpetual political and social movement availing to no real solution to the human problem. I'll provide the context for the above statement further down.  I'll give a summary of his two basic propositions first. 1. he observes correctly that mobile creatures have to move forward in the world as a requirement to keep them alive or even for them to want to keep alive. We move forward towards things we value, which reveals that we always live in a framework of value and that this is out of necessity at a physiological and psychological level given that life is suffering. The way to transcend suffering is to pursue things of value.   2. he observes that if people being social creatures are going to pursue something of value in a social setting, they're going to compete and cooperate with people around in the pursuit of that value. That eventually will produce a hierarchy of competence in relationship to that pursuit. It's inevitable that only a minority will be superbly successful while a majority will merely stack up at the bottom, an iron law of 'distribution of success and hierarchy) based on Price's law reflecting the Matthew principle from the new Testament ("For to the one who has, more will be given, and he will have an abundance, but from the one who has not, even what he has will be taken away." - Matthew 13: 12). He concludes that from a left-wing perspective if we're going to have value and hierarchy, then we're going to have inequality, which would morph to a form of tyranny due to the subsequent power (that corrupts) gained through hierarchy. The inequality and tyranny would most certainly cause excess suffering at the bottom of the pyramid to those who have nothing to lose. These might just aggressively flip the hierarchy on its end and we'd have an unsustainable society. He points out that in a political and social landscape we should never allow it to go so far where people have nothing to lose but rather take precaution to strike a balance between the left and the right in their proper positions.  Peterson asserts that the conservative's need for hierarchy and the liberal's fight for equality will be permanently at odds with one another yet we need hierarchy for pursuing value although it will be inevitable that as a result we'll produce inequality. He backs the latter by quoting Jesus Christ that 'the poor will always be with you' hence we need the left to fight for their cause.   So, his description of our chaotic world is spot on accurate. But it is my opinion that if everyone (I mean everyone in a utopian sense) applied the spiritual wisdom at the spiritual level as originally intended by Christ, we'd actually achieve law and order at the secular realm even down to the existential level. No more need for conservatives nor liberals! I want to qualify that statement by saying it is not achievable by religion either as has been proven throughout history! Indeed Jesus didn't aspire to create a religion but to address the human problem in a most practical way only a creator of a system or species will do. Alas, He'd also given us free will to choose... ;)  So here below is my interpretation of Jesus' words. To understand what I mean you'll have to keep in mind Peterson's 2 propositions stated above in relation to the 2 passages referred below.  1. Matthew 6: 25-34 (https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+6%3A25-34&version=ESV) Jesus places the highest thing of value to pursue is Truth or rather God's design, which Jesus refers to as God's Kingdom and Righteousness. Suffering is a given in the fallen world but one overcomes or transcends suffering when seeking Truth above one's existential cares. God the Creator provides the necessities for those that love Truth. Therefore applying the principle of pursuing value in material goods leads to the anti-climax of life, which is death and suffering - the reality we see manifesting in this world. If we read other passages in the old and new testament it will be clear to the reader that those that love Truth are the ones also chosen for a calling to spread the good news to others who are also suffering and yet unaware of the Truth.   2. Matthew 13: 10-16 (https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+13%3A+10+-+16&version=ESV) The Matthew principle (Price's Law) that Peterson applies to material possessions is actually in direct reference to possessing spiritual wealth in Matthew 13 (to know the secrets of the kingdom of heaven). Since God is faithful as an overseer (the ultimate and incorruptible leader) He will provide the necessities for those that respond to His calling to facilitate their work in His Kingdom. So with a just God at the helm there will be no need for human hierarchy nor would there be a need to fight for equality. From a strictly utopian perspective IF everybody valued the secrets of God's Kingdom over their basic necessities, there won't be any more poverty!  So, just based on the 2 biblical passages above, I see that Peterson's analysis using the two propositions applied on the political and social levels is a flip-side of Jesus' ultimate teaching. Hence our reality is the opposite of Utopia that has led to the undesirable outcomes for humanity at large. One can almost hear in Jesus' words, 'the poor will always be with you' (John 12: 8) at work perpetually in Peterson's propositions: pursue misdirected values to transcend suffering and you'll have a need for human hierarchy and the fight for equality permanently at odds with each other, resulting in poverty for the majority.

Note taking for myself as I watch this video. And also to see if what I managed to glean from his arguments was in fact what he meant. 1. Hierarchy The existence of humanity and of every living being is codependent, or rather, co-exists with a hierarchical structure that society revolves around. This is proven by the fact that for life to have meaning, it must have pursuit of a goal(?) and that in a species some members of the species will simply be better than others at this pursuit. Thus a hierarchy of ability and competence is born. The problem is, with a hierarchy, that it is not equal and in a hierarchy there are always those at the bottom (the poor and disenfranchised) this is a major flaw and must be fixed. Also the distribution of power and influence is affected most severely by a hierarchy in such that a great deal of power goes to those at the top(?). This becomes a serious problem when your hierarchy is too steep and there are too little people controlling the direction and purpose of humanity. On the matter or liberals and conservatives and how they fall into this system is the way that these two mindsets/ideologies are most prone to think in. Conservatives are good at construction of algorithmic solutions and systems and good at implementation of said systems into hierarchies and can climb hierarchies built under such a manner. Liberals are good at creating new hierarchies and covering new ground. We need a balance of both because in a hierarchy ruled by conservatives, the system stagnates and that is untenable because the state of the world is ever changing and we must similarly adapt. With a hierarchy dominated by liberals, many new systems and more new ground can be broken but it is inherently an unstable hierarchy prone to collapse.  A mix of both would be in the best interest of the continued functioning of human society.

Blew my mind in the first 5 minutes. Everything I've been trying to say to my parents when they were alive about why I cant just sit around and be grateful  that I have what I have which is a lot because they are wealthy and worked very hard and spoiled me endlessly, but I did not value the excess and luxury of wealth - what others refer to as privelage I refer to as a psychological trap. We need purpose and in order to have that we have to be moving to something of value and moving to that value as a forward motion is fundamental biological principle that even unicellular life understands as necessary for survival. So that's why you have people in the streets fighting for some made up utopian ideal , because they are trapped in a political fantasy revolution that they have to keep believing in or else t hey have no underpinning reason to be alive at all - quite literally every day they get to riot and protest is another day they prolongate their existence - the day they break they will spiral into mental illness and suicide/.  This is why it is so concerning to me that our entire societies education system does not prepare us to tackle life in this step by step way that makes sense and is definable and fits well within what we understand about our own biological imperatives. I am one of those girls who's got that psychological complex of suddenly I've got a trust fund full of money and nothing of value to move forward to and thats just x + y = z and z =  baby craziness lol. It's like its DNA begging me to reproduce even tho I never before this point considered doing so because the life course I was on was fatalistic and my day to  reason to be alive was simply kept afloat by drugs and anti depressants.  The fact that a man like JBP has awakened so many of us to reality at an age where so much of the world has already passed us by and we are now scrambling to cling to a forward moving reason to be alive and to have value in society is insane to me. Why we don't teach kids, hey you dont just "need to go get a job, and have responsibilities of an adult NOW GO PULL YOURSELF UP LIKE YOUR GRANDPA DID LOL" the entire bootstraps thing is the same message but the wording needs to be YOU WILL NOT VALUE DAY TO DAY LIFE WITHOUT A REASON TO BE. There fore you have to have something to move forward to, a goal, a greater good - you have no choice now that God is Dead via the enlightenment   There's almost like a profoundly overwhelming depressive state that I get into when I listen to JBP say " now that you understand reality you need to go and tackle it" and im left almost speechless just forming arguments as to why he is absolutely correct but t hat this needs to be told to everyone by many many people in their lives and I don't understand how civilization reached such a technological and social apex point in the 20th century only to allow the generations of children who now had an economically secure bungee cord that the parents just never cut off. It didn't matter that they knew I was an addict, my dad would be so awash in confusion as to what to do to "help me" that I of course I had him shower me in alcohol and prescription drugs, that was the only thing I found worth justifying existence and its so much harder now existing without those  things and knowing my people in AA and NA are primarily okay with simply existing as day to day admitted addicts is somehow their own noble new purpose in society and thats just not good enough for me. I didn't choose that route, and many of them didn't either but man, is that the totality of my accomplishments do you guys think? It is a difficult thing to remain sober but that I am  of course I want for the things normal people have, relatiosnhips, marriage, kids, a future to move forward to... but had I ever understood that those things were the eventual goal and  that really we should never have ever had this idea that its okay to just go to college and party because the moment you start self medicating with sex or alcohol, you are sorted into the 25% of people who leave iwth a degree and problem that will more often than not gradient their entire life course with substance abuse. LIKE WHY DIDNT ANY ONE TELL ME - lol - "just say no to drugs!" and at the same time giving no real valid explanation as to why we could possibly find ourselves trapped in a cycle of bad choices should we ever say yes.... its just not a concept that I and many young people listened to or cared about - to millions of us , that was the point and the purpose and we just thought it all would fall into place later and we'd get our act together. No one ever considers they will be the one with brain damage and a variety of permenant disorders as a result of doing so many and for so long and at such high doses.  Plz if you think your kid is in college and is on drugs or alcohol - find out if they are or not and do something about it, my parents knew I was and they thought that they didnt keep enabling me that I wouldn't love them. The exact opposite is true, I was always without a way to say it suffering - we all are if we are trapped in that with no future, it doesn't matter what we say. Shake them by the shoulders and plz plz plz do not let them grow into their late 20s and 30s resentful and hopeless - death by overdose is a fate I wish I had befallen after finally getting sober - because now my fate is just the fact that after 34 years of being alive, all I have is a circle of folding chairs containing people who gather to keep each other from relapsing and dying and then being truly nothing, it's like come on what the fuck am I supposed to do with money, with property, with life when all I am now capable of feeling is reward is that I get to say I made it one more day to a group of people that if we congregated any where else but in the basement of a church we'd get people concerned for the safety of society because we are so adjacent to criminals, to the homeless :( how do I go from here doc. ?:( ... :(   Anyway besides all of my own personal issues - on another note: it's interesting  and makes even more sense as moving forward to value something It helps back up evolution as a constant need for increasingly necessary resources like food sources obviously must have driven fish to evolve into amphibians and repitiles right? They could sense the need for growing legs through their sense for the existence of a greater value of resources on the shore? I love how douchebags pop into the comment section of every JBP video and call into question his intellect and knowledge.Â   I mean disagree on the issues as much as you want (would be nice if you included an argument to back that up â€“ weird idea, i know), but three things I noticed over the years since I first heard him speak on JRE in 2016:  - whenever I dug into a claim he made that I had a hunch could be oversimplified or cherry-picked to further his agenda, investing many hours over several days/weeks each time to form my own opinion, I had to come to the conclusion that JBP absolutely knew what he was talking about and was well aware of the relevant literature. he doesn't just seem like the kind of guy who does his homework, thinks shit through and chooses his words carefully, he really does. Again, feel free to challenge that, but if you don't back it up with some serious proof (not opinion), you're just making an ass out of yourself.   - I had to take a break from all things JBP some time in 2018 because I had just consumed so much of his content (both 2017 UofT Psych lecture series, most interviews I could find and a bunch of other talks/lectures, including most of the bible series, as well as reading both his books), and there being multiple universes of interesting topics to learn about, thinkers to listen to and books to read. Since then, this was the first JBP content I watched â€“ and I just have to say that I don't know many thinkers that can claim to play in the same league when it comes to crafting cohesive arguments from such a broad background in response even to weirdly framed questions, on the fly.Â he was constantly debating people for years, in public, with many just salivating at the idea of him making a mistake and getting tripped up. what have YOU done proving YOUR intellect and knowledge?  90% of the "JBP is the stupid person's intellectual" haven't read a single book/research paper of the caliber that JBP casually cites, and integrating material to that point of mastery is a different ballgame all together (gnosis & epignosis).  - and maybe most importantly, JBP isn't afraid of admitting when he is wrong about something, judging from the very few examples I saw happen across roughly 120-160 hours of content. that really impresses me, as he knows very well that he will be attacked viciously by political enemies for the tiniest mistake.
