Political correctness: Mean spirited people sometimes use words to harm people. Solution: make certain words illegal. Problem: mean spirited people use legal words to harm people. Solution: Outlaw a bunch more words. Problem: mean spirited people now use the remaining legal words to harm people. (insert recursion).  Notice how any word that describes an undesirable characteristic will eventually be replaced by a more "politically correct" term that will eventually become politically incorrect and be replaced by a new term that will become politically incorrect.  It's like trying to stop violence by making rocks illegal. Rocks are not the problem. Violent people throwing them through windows is the problem. Words are not the problem. Mean spirited people using words to harm others is the problem.  What's the solution? Not sure but making certain words illegal is DEFINITELY NOT the solution or even remotely helpful. It just makes it harder to have a discussion that could lead to a real solution.

It's definitely possible and worth researching, especially because it could contribute to our understanding of the genetic basis of human intelligence. Charles Murray has a new book out that you might like. However, I don't think that genetics/biology is the right level of abstraction when thinking about civilizations. I think you'd be better off thinking of geographical, technological, cultural reasons why civilizations differ and exhaust the myriad possibilities in those domains before trying to explain civilizational differences as a consequence of biology. For example, if I wanted to compare two family businesses, I would first look at their business practices, the market situations they're operating in, their respective financial statuses, etc before trying to formulate an explanation based on the genetic differences between the families running each business.

I too wish that simple answers were easier to come by but the truth is that simple is usually not correct.

Â @52trips97Â  Funny you say that.  I have found the exact opposite to be true.  In fact, if you add too many variables in a machine learning algorithm it comes to wrong conclusions more often than if you give it a simple set of variables.    The same exact logic can be used almost everywhere.  I pride my work of building "complex" systems in a way that the person that looks at my work afterward says, "yeah but that was simple".   I see many software developers building complex systems in a complex way.  Then I see another set of developers building them in a easy to understand way. ("simple")   The easy to understand solutions model the business better, are easier to maintain, are easier to explain and easier to adjust to new conditions.

That's the one thing that seems to hold Peterson back the most. He forces this dichotomy between a free exchange of ideas and tyranny, when in fact the free exchange of ideas produces its own tyranny of normalization. His philosophy would work best in an ideal world without inherently discriminatory normalizations, but our world is one of rampant bias and irrationality, elements that do not befit at all a rational marketplace of ideas. He may even agree that doing away with "arbitrary regulations" would necessarily allow discriminatorily irrational persuasions because the alternative is war and death, but maybe that opposition is false - maybe the alternative is not a slippery slope to abject despair but a more dynamic route whereby we increase regulation so that we construct the material conditions in such a way as to increase the benefit:cost ratio of future deregulation more than otherwise.

I think Peterson fundamentally misunderstands the left.  They do not think we should "sacrifice the sovereign individual view for the collective tribal view."  They believe that society is organized based on the tribal view now but that it shouldn't be, that "the most important thing about you is your group. . ." right now but that it shouldn't be.  The whole point of ending systemic racism and homophobia and chasing equality is to stop organizing our society based on what demographic groups people are a part of and to achieve a society where these groups don't matter.  In other words, a society governed by individual sovereignty.

Summary: - By moving toward that value (by dedicating, studying, practising, investigating, whatever your want) you will build that value in your life.  And from this base, then: - Your social circle will be more likely to be related to that value (with people moving toward the same value), therefore there will be a pyramidal hierarchy (a minority of people that  is fantastically succesfull at the top, and a large number will stack up at the bottom)  - Hierarchies are dangerous because they can create inequality and tyranny. Because there will be people that use power to attain status in the hierarchy.  - If the hierarchy is too steep, people at the bottom will have excess suffering and nothing to lose, and he says that is not a good way to produce a sustainable society.  Then he starts to talk more about the political sides: - The right is basically that portion of the population who's temperamental proclivity is to admire and support hierarchies and work effectively within them (a conservative) and are low for trait openness (creativity).   - On the other side, the liberals, are very good generating hierarchies, high creativity, less consciousness, bad working within a hierarchy.  Therefore, a society needs both parts: - Liberals to build new value, new hierarchies. - Conservatives to actually implement them.  Without liberals, society would be too static and would not adapt to a environment transformations. Without conservatives, liberals would create new possibilities but they would not be able to build an actuality.  Finally, he concludes that we need a voice to make work in both parties in cooperation.

90% of what he had to say to this audience was uncontroversial. Suffice it to say that hierarchies of competence are produced on the right and on the left of the political spectrum. They even arise in dictatorships and empires and universities. And hierarchies of competence atrophy into power seeking in every scenario, given the chance. And no traditional political party believes that hierarchies disappear, giving way to utopian peace and good will.  But it's presently on the right that one finds considerable skepticism (if not total rejection) of hierarchies of competence. Climate change is the latest such manifestation. In economics, it's the myth that tax cuts create more government revenue, or the concept of the righteousness of a flat tax -- both of which are really talking points of the very rich. As to freedom of speech, it's in the greatest republic the world has ever known that the words liberal, progressive, and socialist have all been trashed together and obliterated from political discourse -- without a single law having been passed outlawing them.  As to the last question about what he would ask the Canadian prime minister (who is supposedly a left winger), the point to note is that Mr Peterson would never even be able to ask the current American president (who is a declared right winger) about anything he should reconsider, because, as the former has openly proclaimed -- he has never been wrong about anything.

Dr. Peterson,Â   When the woman in the balcony threw the curveball at you that you were blanketly categorizing people by classing them, and their motives/instincts, into such groups as "conservatives" and "liberals", in the same way you accuse identity politics of doing, I sensed you were slightly thrown back on your heels, though you did respond sufficiently weightily, if not piercingly (we can't all be piercing all the time).Â   But what occurred to me as I watched it--from the stress-free luxury of my armchair, where I was never under pressure to come up with anything to the questions tossed at you--was that her challenge was rooted in an egregiously specious confounding of the descriptive with the prescriptive.Â   If it walks and talks like a duck, it's a duck. That's descriptivist.Â   If a man wants toÂ conserveÂ things (like, for instance, the "hierarchy"), he's a conservative.Â  That's a descriptivist assertion. Â Nothing in the least like what identity politics does.Â   Identity politicsÂ prescribes, on the most factitious, contrived, politically self-seeking premises.Â   "Ah, you're black. Therefore THIS is: what you think, want, strive for, feel, resent, who you vote for, what party you belong to, how you'll get ahead in the world, who you'll depend on to see that it happens, and, finally, OUR role by divine right in your life."Â   The woman's challenge was a rank conceptual manipulation, not a serious intellectual query; a gotcha moment, no pursuit of understanding.Â   PossiblyÂ I judge her too harshly. Â My "gut" seems to know othewise, though, because Â  the difference between your description of conservatives and liberals Â (a veryÂ limitedÂ description of qualities that broadly represent themÂ as such--whatever else, we confidently assume, they may be in addition to that) and the classifications of identity politics (based on nothing but wishful thinking and propaganda) is such anÂ obviousÂ difference that it really requires a sort of idiot not to get it. And my gut also tells me the woman wasn't an idiot. So...well, we'll leave that there.Â   We always describe. I'm sitting in a room. It "walks and talks" like a room, therefore, it's a room. Call that my prejudice, by bias, my Western linear thinking, whatever you like, but I won't apologize for calling it a room. That's not to say anythingÂ moreÂ about it. I haven't mentioned which room it is. Or how it's decorated. Or whether it's a well-defined self-enclosed room of the old-fashioned sort or opens out into others on an "open concept" plan. I've stated the very minimum. As you seem to have when giving us the observed and quantified behaviors/attitudes that go into the descriptions "conservative" and "liberal."Â   The woman in the balcony was scraping the bottom of the barrel in her attempt to turn that kind of minimalist, observation-based description into the equivalent of identity politics (with which, apparently, she is sympathetic).Â   The comical thing about it being, she was effectively saying, "So you're just as BAD as WE are!"Â   Except you're not. But there she is, left high and dry, self-accused.*  We can'tÂ talkÂ without describing.Â   But that, of course, would suit the Left just fine. They don't wantÂ anyÂ of us to describe. (Which is why "That's such a pretty dress you have on" is hate speech.)Â   Or evenÂ talkÂ for that matter. ("Your identity excludes you from having anything to say on this issue." )Â   "Just leave us toÂ prescribe, while you submit" appears to be their driving agenda.Â   That's how it worked in the Soviet Union, which is where I happen to live, in a "post-" fashion, of course--Ukraine, to be precise. And one of the first jokes I heard from a Ukrainian after arriving here in 1995 was: "Everybody was happy in the Soviet Union. You never heard anybody say otherwise."Â    *I noticed this tactic many decades ago, before the fall of the USSR. Even in my early 20s, when Phil Donahue was on his Russian-DÃ©tenteÂ kick, hosting American-Soviet "chats", I noted with a vivid disgust that absolutely every single time a question about Soviet atrocities was posed, the well-trained Russian would reply with something about America's darkest historical dimensions, e.g., slavery, the extermination of Native Americans, modern poverty and civil injustice. I noted with equal disgust that no one, either in the audience or Mr. Donahue himself, ever had the guts to challenge that and say, "Ah, so you're saying America has done wrong, even criminally,Â just as muchÂ as the Soviet Union has? IsÂ thatÂ what you're saying? If so, here's how America is trying to make amends for these real wrongs.... Now, how (to get back to the QUESTION if we may) isÂ the Soviet UnionÂ attempting to redress its real, historical wrongs? Shall we begin with the genocidal Ukrainian Starvation of the 1930s?" Nobody had, it seemed, either the presence of mind, or the courage, or even aÂ yenÂ to challenge these guests, who smugly smirked and batted away inconvenient questions with their strictly prepared script. And a strictly prepared script is the polar opposite of genuine reflection, unless of course your own genuine reflection wentÂ intoÂ it and you're ready to honestly entertain feedback afterwards! The profound comfort I draw from subsequent history is this: you can hornswoggle an audience, but you can't dupe Reality. Whoever you are, wherever and "whenever" you are in history's perpetually reconfiguring schema, Reality's coming for you. Sooner or later. Absolutely. "There is nothing hidden that shall not be known." Truth will out. You can tell the difference between two types of people, by the way, from how they respond to the proposition that "truth will out." The one type gleefully whispers to himself, "Good. So I'll be provenÂ rightÂ in the end" (as, I've no doubt, Donahue's Soviet guest-stars were certain...and certainlyÂ wrong.) The other type quietly reassures himself, "Good. So then, it doesn't all depend onÂ me. And wherever I was wrong, the Truth will beÂ better." The former mind is a hollow, brittle carapace of self-involved desperation--in the words of the prophet Jeremiah, "a heart of stone;" the latter mind is one, again in the prophet's terms, of flesh: feeling, growing, vulnerable but vital.

The volume provides close analysis of some of the most important decisions made by Latin American national courts, as well as those made by international legal bodies, that affect the rights and interests of these groups. Specially selected for their depth of argument and value as exemplars, the studies of good legal practice chart the path of the regionâ€™s normative values of justice as they have evolved away from a partial, and patriarchal, exercise of the law. They show how cases with vastly differing contexts such as, property rights and domestic violence have resulted in a mixed body of Latin American law.  Some decisions are protective of womenâ€™s and minority rights. Some assess the wider social impacts of case law in which recognition of the discrete legal identities within households challenges established precepts, including religious ones. Other cases have been chosen as cautionary examples of bad decision-making and for the poverty of their legal debate. Updated to include the latest relevant jurisprudence from across the continent, this book is an informed, cohesive, and comprehensive guide to understanding womenâ€™s and gender-based rights in Latin America.â€‹

My take on Jordan Peterson: A psychological, sociological, philosphical genius who earned his fame for the simple trick of speaking common sense. His ideas on how a man should approach life are very interesting and logical, and have allowed me to reshape my life entirely. However, in the fields of religion, economics, and politics, he is not a figure of authority and some of his propositions are quite foolish. I agree with him on his stance on Canada's C-16 Bill, as well as his assessment of equality of opportunity vs. equality of outcome. However, he is not a particularly intelligent gentlement when it comes to the fields of Capitalism (which I support fully), Socialism, and Communism. He's a wonderful ideologist and philosopher, and he's right about the nature of society and the existence of indestructible hierarchies in society, however he is not a particularly good defender of Capitalism or politics.

Â @Richard_is_coolÂ  Most of the results returned by your search terms focus on dismissing the messenger instead of inspecting the ideas he's put forth.  Is JP wrong about some things?  Yes of course.    But that does not mean you can simply dismiss en masse the huge amount of work and insight he has offered.
Â @tux1968Â  The videos mostly hold that he is not acting in good faith.

Â @Richard_is_coolÂ  That's the classic way to dismiss a messenger espousing views you find objectionable.   Ideas are ideas regardless of who puts them forward.   If Hitler was the one to discover and say that the Sun is the center of our solar system, it would still be true even though he was an evil bastard.  For what it's worth, i am acting in good faith, and have learned many interesting ideas from JP.    Even if he is an evil man, (which I don't think he is), his ideas are well worth inspecting for yourself.

Â @tux1968Â  Well, in my view, he starts with things that are true (like "clean your room", an obviously correct albeit basic advice), but then slowly proceeds to utter untrue statements on philosophy, gender, and so on. Sort of like a cult: first starting with true and nice things, and slowly building you up for the more radical thoughts.  What specific ideas of his do you like? :)

Â @Richard_is_coolÂ  Well he has made a huge contribution of ideas to public discourse, I could barely begin to list the ideas that have struck me as interesting.   Here is just one: that the bible myths encode deep evolutionary knowledge that is critical to our survival, but do so in a way that precedes our ability to articulate what that knowledge is or how it is important.   Such  knowledge bubbles up and has a larval stage that exists before it could ever be spoken of in rational terms.   That humans often have to make decisions before a rational treatise can be formulated to help decide, and that we should be tapped into and respect this pre-rational process and not reject it just because some of its ideas have since been honed and better understood rationally.

Â @tux1968Â  Thank you. I would include this in the camp of basic true facts. Of course mythology is extremely important for a society. Of course the Bible (or Iliad or Odyssey) is the most important book. He definitely wasn't the first to notice the importance of myths for a society (most famously, there was Jung). Nor the fact that myths do contain literary truths. That is a given. Now, if this is what you take from Peterson, then he truly did not yet manage to sell you anything that is untrue. However, he definitely wasn't the first to say it (all the priests have been talking about the Bible, of course, since it was written), nor did he say it most eloquently and aesthetically (there you would have to go for Jung). He merely popularized it for present YouTube audience of 20 year old atheist males, basically. Which again, is good, just in my book it is on par with telling them they should clean their room. Basic. True. And obvious. If you dismiss the Bible, or Vedas, and so on, in you understanding of another culture, you're making a grave, yet for others obvious, error.

Â @Richard_is_coolÂ  I am of course paraphrasing and summarizing what he has said, only to the best of my ability.  He goes into much more depth; he is a deep and honest thinker.   That doesn't make him infallible, but I don't think it makes him a bad faith actor.  If you can dismiss everything someone says that you agree with as "obvious" and anything they say you disagree with as proof of bad faith, there isn't a single person in this world who would avoid being burned at the stake.  You seem like a smart and honest person, I'll just offer you my own take.  Peterson is not a messiah, he is a flawed person like all of us.  But he is smart and has a valuable view of the world that is in short supply in our culture today.  Even if you end up disagreeing with most of what he says, you should value and defend his contribution to the ongoing public conversation we need more than ever.

The postmodernist desire to shackle free speech is one that I find the most troubling to a free society.  In his book, "12 Rules for Life, an antidote  to chaos" Peterson said:  "When you have something to say, your silence is a lie and tyranny feeds on lies."  And what the progressive might say, in favor of hate speech laws and policies that oppress free speech, is something like: "If you don't have anything nice to say, don't say anything at all."  The road to hell is paved with good intentions.

Letting the hateful speech be uttered offers a clearer sense of the speakers intentions, and perhaps will signal what appropriate mode of action needs to be taken by a responsible audience. The curtailing of free speech could bring, as a result, an uncontrolled course of action no one suspected of and desires of graver consequences by the hater.

He's nothing like Socrates. Study Socrates and you'll see why. Socrates (insofar as we know how he conducted himself from second-hand sources) was an early originator of a priori reasoning. He would force people to break down any argument into its constituent tenets (not "tenants" incidentally Mr Peterson - they rent property). His students became the leading figures in classical philosophy. His teachings remained relevant millennia later. Anyone applying a cursory level of scrutiny to Peterson will find numerous logical holes peppering many of his statements. (His notion of consequentialist truth being an obvious one just off the top of my head.)  Peterson has some interesting things to say about psychology. In philosophy, not so much. And in science, next to nothing. No Socrates for sure. Almost no one will know who Peterson was in 20 years, let alone 2,000.

What if you are well read in Foucault, do not see yourself as in the camp of grad students that love Foucault, and at the same time are very supportive of the type of discussion Peterson encourages?  22:00  The connection b/w ethics and perception is a project that some very famous academic philosophers who are alive and working, have been making some headway on for the last 40 years, but also the last 10 and 2 years.  Not just Brandom, McDowell, and their recently deceased professors (Sellars, Rorty, etc.), but also Bernard Stiegler, Manual DeLanda and others seem to provide some sense in which not only is consciousness commodified (your attention is worth a lot to marketers), but the process in which the advertisers sold us to the newspapers renders any theorizing as open to suspicion.  Peterson needs to realize that Foucault is not the problem.  Foucault is not the problem.  You cannot understand the academic landscape without Foucault, at least in terms of how the organization and documentation of the European is a historical event in which, once understood can render the idea of 'participation' as a higher good than 'correctness' -- or that if we are to understand (to get the meaning right), we must look into the 'terms of participation'.  I get that this would read vague, but I hope I can gesture at the idea that it would be helpful to argue with Peterson about what the grand narrative should look like, as a matter of taste, not truth.

And importantly this effect of wanting to get at the truth or validity of ideas is something that universities were set up to do in the first place, that there's an unwritten expectation that it's a battleground of ideas and you don't go there to win by having your argument come out on top. The winners are the people that learn something new and useful whether they agreed with it initially or not. I think this was displayed extremely well in the Peterson vs Harris 4 part debates. Sadly I think that it's something the universities and maybe not necessarily Oxford are losing extremely rapidly due to the onset of disciplines which are ideological in nature, and these are post modern ideas, things like social justice, feminism, which are sneaking marxism back into society through the back door. And the resulting fallout of this is students asserting to professors that Uni's must be a safe space, it's absolutely appalling.  Also to add to Peterson's reply on this specific issues one thing I think can also soften the blow of the problem that people feel excluded or too anxious to speak their ideas, is you can do assertiveness training, you can through practice and through therapy learn to overcome a lot of anxiety, and that can in theory ameliorate some of the suffering people feel when they put forward their ideas. It's also worth noting that sometimes when you do feel uncomfortable putting out counter ideas to someone else who has done the same, you can't just assume they put their ideas out without also feeling anxious about it, sometimes the people you're debating have also suffered but they put out their ideas anyway and took that suffering on the chin.

Â Al GarnierÂ  I never said anything about opinion, please don't put words in my mouth. It should be about knowledge backed by data, but data is the end result of a long process where you start with a hypothesis and then design experiments and then go and perform them, write up the papers and then the papers are peer reviewed, published, and then discussed back and forth, attempted to be replicated or falsified. That whole process necessarily requires that people be able to stick up for ideas they believe are right and pursue those ideas even if those ideas are offensive to some people. And in the arena where these ideas battle each other the hope is that if any are correct that will come to the surface and we'll learn something new. And so shutting down research and ideas because you find them offensive and it makes the university no longer a "safe space" is corrupt to the very core. I think the idea of how certain religious and Hebraic scholars interpret the idea of "Hashem Ish Milchama" or "Hashem is a man of war"  and how it is conflated with the reinterpretation "Hashem Ish Mi Lechem" of "Hashem is a man of bread" with the explanation given that god only sanctions war when his people are in need. I.e he only sanctions war from his people when they are in some of privation.  To me this distinction between one translation and another is only a way reiterating what the verse said with further context afforded to people thousands of years later to make the verse seem more forgiving which is why I agree with Sam Harris on the point that the more you reinterpret a holy text the further you stray away from the text itself and into a sort of quasi moral relativism that a detractor can make claim has nothing to really do with your religion.   I don't think any of this or your argument detracts from my wish that world religions be replaced by the notion of Cultural romanticism however, but perhaps that's my fault for not cogently stating what I mean by this. Essentially religious romanticise past misdeeds and use god as a vehicle to profess a moral or ethical lesson (I never once stated the morals directly correlated to the idea that the phenomenology of the prophets meeting with the actual literal reading that god actually exists, just that it was framed as such with the inception of each new idea derived from each story). To use the term cultural romanticism I simply mean how a culture uses God to reconcile with an ugly past to retain some form dignity for future generations.  Of course the editorial process of any top down structure in control of such texts perverts the texts with each translation or reinterpretation the further we divulge from the culture and initial instance in which it was written, which is why i think we should just shelve these books and go enough already! This is what you're book says and you can either like it or lump it.  In essence I'm suggesting that we should move to a tacit or implicit understanding that these books are fiction. It may be a fools errand to hope for as much but this is where I view the relevance of such books.   Unfortunately for us therein lies the problem that people who read and ascribe their life to what they've read in these books believe that deriving meaning is the same as deducing fact and use faith as coping mechanism when confronted on this fallacy. I have been a humanist myself ever since I decided that the works of Kurt Vonnegut at the age of twelve held more meaning to me personally than any one religious text and as a computing scientist and STEM ambassador I couldn't agree more that intelligence is the driving factor of humanity, but intelligence moulds itself to the times in which it was born in the past and the most intelligent people used religion to get what they want or to unite a people in times of strife. it's not an effective model for intelligent people in modern times as it flies in the face of scientific reasoning, but it definitely held more of a benefit then as it does now even if it still amounts to a mode of control. All this being said, I value your opinion on this with perhaps the exception of your interpretation of Jordan's intent with his arguments. If you could clarify on why you view his arguments as bigotry I would love to hear that. I wouldn't mind you delving into your religious upbringing if it's not too painful to do so as I have my own past with evangelism through certain friends of family which has it's good points and it's reprehensible parts which I in turn could go into in another post. I think we got off on the wrong foot due to my initial attack on you but I'm really enjoying this back and forth now.

I appreciate those last two sentences. Some of these countries have the same legal protections for foreign nationals that they have for native-born citizens. Some don't. And in more depth:  Jordan Peterson, Full Address Oxford Union: â€œPeople can transcend suffering by pursuing things of value, people who have no purpose in life are resentful.  If you are going to pursue something of value and you are a social creature you will pursue that in a social space, you will produce a hierarchy of competence in relationship to that pursuit.  You and other people vary in your ability to manage that pursuit effectively.  If it is a valuable pursuit, there will be a hierarchy of people who are very good, of competence, a few people will be fantastic at that pursuit, and most of the people will stack up at the bottom, that is a manifestation of the Priceâ€™s Law, the Preedo distribution, the Matthew principleâ€¦if you are going to have value and you are going to have hierarchy you are going to have inequality.  You have to produce something of value, people can use power to attain status. If your hierarchy becomes too steep, too tiny a fraction at the top, it is unjust and unfair, that is not a good way to produce a sustainable society.â€   Letâ€™s look past the smoke and mirrors self-important delivery of JP to what he actually says here:    1.  You want value in your life â€“ yeah, but what is your point?  2.   If you are trying to achieve things you work along with and in competition with other people â€“ yeah, but what is your point?  3.  Some people are better at some things than other people â€“ wait, isnâ€™t Oxford University supposed to be a haven for smart people?  And they are inviting a guy to tell them that some people are better at some things than some other people?  What is wrong with this picture?  4.  JP has to cite three sources to validate his remarkable conclusion that competence is not equally distributed to everyone?  Help me Jesus.  5.  JP points out that if your hierarchy is too steep, e.g. the 500x income gap we have in the US, it is not good for a sustainable society.  I agree completely, but if I have known that for decades as completely obvious, can I be invited to speak at The Oxford Union â€œworld's most prestigious speaker and debating society, with an unparalleled reputationâ€ also?

Â @jerrygreene1493Â  Firstly thanks for your polite reply and what sounds like genuine interest in the answers. If only everyone approached disagreement the same way; the world (and the internet especially) would be a better place.  Anyway, you raise a lot of interesting questions which I'll do my best to respond to (though it may have to be in installments as my steak is about to go in the pan!). 1) Your first point around who is saying that. Well, a lot of people who believe that hierarchy in the western world is a social construct (just like gender) rather than an evolutionary biological mechanism and necessity. This is based on the left's tendency to describe everything in terms of a power dynamic i.e. oppressed and oppressor. In this case the left states that hierarchy is not a natural state but a result of elites forcing a structure into society that then privileges them and supports their elevated status (or something like that). JPs response is that hierarchy serves many purposes in the animal kingdom and is very evident (even in Lobsters). That is not to say hierarchies don't get abused by the human animal (JP is open that they do tend towards tyranny and can cause problems for those at the bottom levels) but that is a different problem to "man makes hierarchies to be self-serving" which can be the claim. 2)  I think this relates to the first point that hierarchies and the related structures serve a purpose across the animal kingdom so inevitably you will encounter them wherever you look as they have utility and serve a purpose for the given species. In relation to man I think there may be a wider point here that some modern social activists on the left may even acknowledge hierarchy to be an evolutionary necessity (most don't)  but believe that we can and have evolved beyond these mechanisms that are millions of years old in a few generations. The fact we can understand and articulate what these mechanisms are is wonderful but it doesn't mean they no longer exist, they are embedded in our genetic and social coding.  3) I read that as JP highlighting that the far-left believe that the current social/cultural landscape of the west (e.g. capitalism) is responsible for sustaining  inequality and unfairness and basically all that is wrong in the world (e.g. wars etc.).   Jerry - I'll pick this up over the weekend as my good lady is telling me that dinner is ready - let me know what you think and if this is helpful at all.

OK, Picking up after a good nights sleep - the steak was fabulous btw! :-) 4) I'm sure of the context as I couldn't find the quote but I don't for one second think that JP is saying we will evolve beyond recognition in the next 100 years. I think he is more likely making a more pessimistic point that the survival of our species is by no means a certainty given the current set of existential threats that exist (most of which are self-created). It could be that the "too few" element of his reply is predicated on this pessimistic view i.e. if we have a plague, thermo-nuclear war or the planet cooks us there will only be the pockets of survivors remaining. Not jolly but as JP often highlights existence is tough and over any significant period of time species survival is unlikely. 5) That one is straight-forward (I found that one) in that he is saying the right should pause before countering the left's fundamental move to identity politics as the foundation for their thinking and not fight fire with fire i.e. the right should not start to do the same thing and position things on the same group identity basis which just makes the problem more universal. JPs logic here is easy to understand i.e. how does it help create a Utopian world of one people one tribe one purpose if we are constantly separating out people and bundling them together in arbitrary groupings? All that does is make us more not less tribal which is obviously counter productive (and dangerous as he points out based on what history tells us) as that emphasizes difference rather than ignoring it.  That is the fundamental deceit in the whole identity politics game - that by focusing in and spotlighting on any group characteristic it will help the spotlight on that characteristic fade - illogical and divisive and only used to support the predictable oppressor/oppressed narrative that then supports the underpinning ideology.    Let me know if any of the above is useful or if I am making matters worse!

Here's one thing I don't agree with: collectivism invariably leads to tribalism and chaotic violence. The LIMIT on collectivism that is imposed by ethnic, linguistic, racial, gender etc. boundaries is what leads to "tribalism". Collectivism can be extended to encompass the entire human race, even all of life on earth â€“ something we need to cultivate if we want to change our economic tendency to destroy the planet).  Distance and isolation are the biggest factors today that lead to "tribal" mindsets. Those that have little to no contact with (or should I say, who have crudely/poorly mediated contact with or caricatured experiences with) Muslims, blacks, gays, natural ecosystems etc. tend to have the biggest problem with them. Another factor: righteousness about one's thumbnail sketch of reality and the assertion of its dominance over other cultures' sketches. When we do have continual contact and we breakdown the "tribal" barrier, we might come to argue over the best way to integrate and create a coherent vision of society that best serves everyone and their regimes of value. When we argue we are at risk of building up those barriers again if different cultures are unwilling to compromise on some of their values to resolve the conflict, if one asserts dominance (moral, scientific, philosophical, religious etc.) over the other.  So, we do need individualistic values, as he rightly proposes, but, we must not grasp at them whilst dropping collectivist values, for it is only collectivism that can ameliorate inequality, it is only collectivism that can make us transcend the boundaries of individual instrumentality to stand in solidarity with others in our society and around the world. And, in fact, individualism and complete collectivism are not at odds with each other, only individualism and partial collectivism. Once we all stand in solidarity with the entire human race (which is inescapably full of variation and very obvious (as well as subtle) differences) then we can come to appreciate each individual. The same goes in relation to other species. We simply must acknowledge that different ways of doing and thinking and seeing exist for our benefit, that compromise is the mother of cooperation, integration, and acceptance. We must come to understand that neither individualism nor collectivism, reason nor passion, creativity nor stability etc. are at fault, only various combinations of the two which we can address and adapt to our needs.   SECOND problem: The idea that hierarchies will automatically create inequality is too simplistic. For there exists hierarchies in competence, no doubt, but Peterson obviously takes strict individualism as an axiom here when he purports that this must lead to inequality (in the real world at least). He assumes that one only acquires that which is valuable to keep it for oneself. There is a choice to be made by every outstanding individual and group of them who manage to attain that which they find valuable, and that is whether to keep it all for themselves and use the power they get from keeping it to further advantage themselves over others or to share it with society. When the former is done, we reach our current state of affairs where wealthy elites are able to write 80% of the laws in the US to further benefit themselves and their ability to acquire more at the direct expense of those at the bottom. Peterson is a highly talented thinker and rhetorician, but I fear that he slides into the abstract-ual abyss sometimes, giving primacy to his logos and its two-dimensional congruence over the complex nature of its manifestation into the real, three-dimensional world, its splintering and interaction with other aspects of reality.    THIRDLY: hate speech. I find it difficult to believe that regulating just the most extreme forms of hate speech cannot be done effectively and won't better our society. I think that as a society, it is much easier to define the most extreme forms of hate speech than it is to resolve many of our issues that are more nuanced and that he says we will manage in the absence of hate speech regulation. There is always room for leniency in regulation based on reasonability and general consensus to weed out crude accusations resulting from someone being made uncomfortable. BUT, when we don't regulate it (and THIS is where he completely falls prey to the abstraction of his reasoning out of reality) we are at constant risk of the political mobilisation of hate speech (especially in big crowds, where people's better judgement is subjugated to the fervour of the group) to incite violence and hostile attitudes towards others based on a mere matter of race, religion, nationality etc. Peterson completely ignores the reality of powerful individuals using their public platforms to shape opinion and attitudes for their own personal gain, and therein lies the biggest fault in his argument against any kind of regulation on hate speech. But, of course, because he is articulate and his thought is nuanced, the crowd laps his words up (again, in the spirit of crowd mentality) without thinking through the downfalls of his abstract reasoning when faced with real world problems.   I respect him as an intellectual, I just take issue with some of his stances, and I hope we don't blindly accept all of his ideas just because the standards are currently so low in public media with regards to such reasoned debate. Go watch talks with Akala, Mehdi Hasan (something other than his head to head series though), and Yannis Varoufakis as preliminary checks just to see that there are others with this level of intellect espousing different ideas so that we don't treat him like a messiah. Because based on the crowd reactions, comment section and personal experiences, I'm starting to get the feeling that this is happening.

Something I've thought for a long time that seems to resonate with how JP feels about the individual...we should all act in our best interests, with the largest scope possible in regards to time and space.  Meaning that you should make decisions that include your best interest as far in the future as you can, as well as your best interests internally, and as far out reaching as you can to include your immediate family, larger family and friends, communities, state, country and so on.  That I believe is the equivalent of wisdom.  And the interesting thing is that your scope is largely dependent on knowledge...everything new you learn, whether academic, or just experiential, increases your scope that you can make your decision based on.  But no matter how large your knowledge base, you can still decide to have a small scope and make decisions based on what your best interest is now, and only taking yourself into account.  This is what I consider to be ignorance, and what is often referred to as selfish, and ultimately ends up not being in your best interest at all.

Why all of a sudden does a certain segment demand to be identified as something unique? It appears as a weakness to me. As I said, I dealt with this issue respectfully decades ago. If someone is so insecure or fragile, they hang their validation on a pronoun, I would probably avoid knowing such a person. Being liberated from such idiosyncratic behaviors and expressions is the sign of a truly liberated mind. I don't care who thinks what about their sexuality. In the spirit of the Stockholm Declaration that states: â€œWith humanity still scarred by â€¦antisemitism and xenophobia the international community shares a solemn responsibility to fight those evilsâ€ the committee on Antisemitism and Holocaust Denial called the IHRA Plenary in Budapest 2015 to adopt the following working definition of antisemitism.    On 26 May 2016, the Plenary in Bucharest decided to:    Adopt the following non-legally binding working definition of antisemitism:  â€œAntisemitism is a certain perception of Jews, which may be expressed as hatred toward Jews. Rhetorical and physical manifestations of antisemitism are directed toward Jewish or non-Jewish individuals and/or their property, toward Jewish community institutions and religious facilities.â€    To guide IHRA in its work, the following examples may serve as illustrations:   Manifestations might include the targeting of the state of Israel, conceived as a Jewish collectivity. However, criticism of Israel similar to that leveled against any other country cannot be regarded as antisemitic. Antisemitism frequently charges Jews with conspiring to harm humanity, and it is often used to blame Jews for â€œwhy things go wrong.â€ It is expressed in speech, writing, visual forms and action, and employs sinister stereotypes and negative character traits.   Contemporary examples of antisemitism in public life, the media, schools, the workplace, and in the religious sphere could, taking into account the overall context, include, but are not limited to:  Calling for, aiding, or justifying the killing or harming of Jews in the name of a radical ideology or an extremist view of religion.   Making mendacious, dehumanizing, demonizing, or stereotypical allegations about Jews as such or the power of Jews as collective â€” such as, especially but not exclusively, the myth about a world Jewish conspiracy or of Jews controlling the media, economy, government or other societal institutions.   Accusing Jews as a people of being responsible for real or imagined wrongdoing committed by a single Jewish person or group, or even for acts committed by non-Jews.   Denying the fact, scope, mechanisms (e.g. gas chambers) or intentionality of the genocide of the Jewish people at the hands of National Socialist Germany and its supporters and accomplices during World War II (the Holocaust).   Accusing the Jews as a people, or Israel as a state, of inventing or exaggerating the Holocaust.   Accusing Jewish citizens of being more loyal to Israel, or to the alleged priorities of Jews worldwide, than to the interests of their own nations.   Denying the Jewish people their right to self-determination, e.g., by claiming that the existence of a State of Israel is a racist endeavor.   Applying double standards by requiring of it a behavior not expected or demanded of any other democratic nation.   Using the symbols and images associated with classic antisemitism (e.g., claims of Jews killing Jesus or blood libel) to characterize Israel or Israelis.   Drawing comparisons of contemporary Israeli policy to that of the Nazis.   Holding Jews collectively responsible for actions of the state of Israel.   Antisemitic acts are criminal when they are so defined by law (for example, denial of the Holocaust or distribution of antisemitic materials in some countries).   Criminal acts are antisemitic when the targets of attacks, whether they are people or property â€“ such as buildings, schools, places of worship and cemeteries â€“ are selected because they are, or are perceived to be, Jewish or linked to Jews.   Antisemitic discrimination is the denial to Jews of opportunities or services available to others and is illegal in many countries.      Antisemitism and Holocaust Denial Share icon

The basis for the postmodern claim that truth is relative is a reaction to earlier forms of liberalism that discounted the subjective in favor of the objective (e.g., logical positivism, utilitarianism, scientism).  This extreme emphasis upon the objective was parodied in Dickens' novel "Hard Times".  Postmodernism is an overreaction in the opposite direction; it emphasizes the subjective (i.e., opinion and emotion) over the objective as described in the postmodern masterpiece titled Libidinal Economy by Lyotard.  One of these days, liberals may get it right and realize that epistemologically, both the subjective and objective are necessary, but I'm not holding my breath.

It appears you missed the point about hierarchies being inevitable. Democracy cannot extinguish hierarchies because every single person in that democracy will be in pursuit of the things they value, and prioritize those things according to their own hierarchy, with the things they think are the most important at the top. So that's one hierarchy, a hierarchy of values. If a group of people either help each other to seek that thing, or even compete for the same thing, another type of hierarchy emerges, a hierarchy of competence.   In other words, if you think your family is more important than your job or vice versa, you have a hierarchy. If you go to work and somebody at work does a better job that someone else, that's another hierarchy.

Peterson follows Jean-FranÃ§ois Lyotard in describing the postmodern condition as â€˜the end of all grand meta-narrativesâ€™. Since, for Peterson, this loss necessarily results in nihilism, he accuses postmodern philosophers (Derrida specifically) and the universities in general of recycling defunct Marxist dogmas â€œto provide them with motive force in the worldâ€. Yet doesnâ€™t he commit exactly the same â€œintellectually untenableâ€ mistake by praising British liberalism? Doesnâ€™t this â€œforget about the complexityâ€ of the postmodern problem and ignore an obvious contradiction? As the late great Richard Rorty wrote of Nietzsche:   â€œNietzsche is notorious for his vacillations. He wavers between criticizing the very idea of objective truth and proclaiming that his own views are objectively true and everybody else's objectively false. On one page he tells us that â€˜[w]e simply lack any organ for knowledge, for 'truth': we 'know' (or believe or imagine) just as much as may be useful in the interests of the human herd, the speciesâ€™. But a few pages earlier he had said that â€˜even we godless anti-metaphysicians still take our fire, too, from the flame lit by a faith that is thousands of years old, the faith of Plato that truth is divineâ€™.â€   https://chicagounbound.uchicago.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=5416   Despite claiming that no morality can be rationally vindicated, in â€˜Thus Spake Zarathustraâ€™, Nietzsche reverts to a philosophy of the sovereign individual just as naÃ¯ve and simplistic as Ayn Randâ€™s Objectivism. Jordan Peterson is the Canadian Ayn Rand.

Studies of chimpanzees are of limited value in assessing the potential of our own species, and Peterson perniciously and hyperbolically runs roughshod over these limitations. Give two human infants a task they must work on together to win some candy, and they will do so, then share the spoils. Chimps canâ€™t accomplish this because they fight over the candy afterward. We neednâ€™t resuscitate a Rousseauian ideal of â€˜the noble savageâ€™ to acknowledge that the better angels of human nature are often thwarted by competitive socialization. (Refer to the work of sociologist Alfie Kohn in â€˜No Contestâ€™ and â€˜Punished By Rewardsâ€™.) The low-resolution warring thumbnails of â€œindividualismâ€ versus â€œcollectivismâ€, and the nauseating buzzwords of â€œtribalismâ€, â€œpostmodernismâ€, and â€œpolitical correctnessâ€ become so many empty signifiers, devoid of content, in Petersonâ€™s pseudo-intellectual lexicon. Who today argues for sacrificing the sovereign individual to the group? Certainly not transgendered individuals, for example, who are merely asking for their civil rights, just as women, ethnic minorities, and gays before them. And conservative reactionaries, as with every previous emancipatory egalitarian movement, have framed their noble protest as a call for â€˜special rightsâ€™ and as a threat to traditional hierarchies or even Western civilization itself.   Perhaps readers of Michel Foucault or Jacques Derrida may lack the nuance of the original authors, but by what leap in logic do we arrive from there to Stalinism and the Borg Collective? Like a high school student who sees a Nuremberg rally in every hometown football game, Peterson insistently exhibits a simple-minded phobia of any gathering of primates for a common cause.   Perhaps some ancient ethic of fair play, deeply embedded in our neurophysiology, is worth preserving and learning from, and perhaps there are cultural universals like language, music, and art which the social constructivists too readily dismiss and on which we can build better freer societies (as socialists have long maintained), but if various circles in literary criticism and the humanities submit this (Kantian-Marxist) optimism to criticism, why does this implicate all universities and why is this â€œappalling beyond forgivenessâ€?

As alluded, social hierarchies do not necessarily reflect variances in competence, because the relatively incompetent can accrue power sufficient to stay on top. Some in-bred hereditary monarch may be inept at governing, for example, but the undue importance placed on their genealogy may legitimate their reign. In fact, the myth of meritocracy often rationalizes un-meritocratic hierarchies, which is what Marxists call â€˜ideologyâ€™ or we might more colloquially refer to as â€˜self-flatteryâ€™/â€˜victim-blamingâ€™. If youâ€™ve won a competition, youâ€™ve a lot of incentive to attribute your success to talent and hard work rather than injustice or dumb luck, and youâ€™ve little incentive to ask whether the competition is worthwhile or wasteful. Which is why such abstract meditations on metaphysical value can underwrite outmoded oppressions in the here and now instead of meaningfully contributing to human flourishing and progress.

Just one assertion which intrigues me is JP's statement 'that ethic manifested itself at the level of behaviour; we don't understand it' (around 25:30). He goes on to say that the chimpanzee cannot articulate or represent it, (or something similar to that). Since chimpanzees are not able to verbally communicate with humans, nor are most other species for that matter, I wonder how he can be so sure about just how deeply they understand things. I don't see how we can know this. Obviously we are all guided by instinct: humans are too; but we interact with each other and the environment in very complex ways. Our brains are structurally altered by our experiences, and the process goes on for generation after generation. How anyone could draw a figurative line and say which behaviour is purely instinct, or purely learned, is beyond me.

Peterson claims: â€. . . as many great religious traditions have illustrated and proclaimed life is essentially suffering," which he regards as a consequence of humankind's innate limitations. He then says of the religious notion of existential suffering: "I believe that to be a fundamental truth." Peterson's reasoning leaves much to be desired. First, he offers no reasons for holding this belief. Indeed, compare his uncritical evaluation of these â€œgreat religious traditionsâ€ to his assessment of secular proclamations on society and human nature. Second, Peterson endorses the religious proclamations and description of a human essence. However, where are the data, which he often asks others to provide, supporting these traditions' proclamations and description? Is human life, in general, replete with suffering, or some lives? Do monarchs, Popes, political leaders, and corporate magnates through the ages lead lives of suffering? Of course not!! Third, Peterson's criticisms of injustice are extraordinarily selective. In his analyses of suffering in the Soviet Union, Maoist China, and North Korea, Peterson launches vitriolic, moral denunciations of its perpetrators. By contrast, he does not address the Gulags created by political leaders in Imperial Portugal, Spain, the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, Italy, France and Britain in the Americas, Asia, the Pacific, and Africa. The â€œgreat religious traditionsâ€ get a free pass. Peterson's ire is directed mainly at â€œMarxists,"  "feminists," and egalitarians who, albeit often clumsily, express a passion for economic and political transformations. Fourth, Peterson's subsequent admission, in this presentation, that human beings are also impelled to value remedial changes betrays a significant inconsistency.  He does not recognise the fatalism implicit in his â€œfundamental truth.â€ In other words, given the "fundamental truth" of existential human suffering, surely endeavors toward its eradication are bound to fail. Jordan Petersonâ€™s worldview promotes a religious conception of human nature that excuses the tsunami of violence, hunger, illiteracy, and physical maladies that plague human existence. It presents a cornerstone of the Abrahamic religions--an intrinsically impotent human species--to explain harmful consequences of actions taken by a minority of human beings. God and Jordan Peterson are on this minorityâ€™s side.

The answer is no.Â  There is no reason to curtail speech because a group might make you feel shut out because of your opinions or whatever.Â  The idea that one would do soÂ actually lays the ground work for the very same problem they thought to counter.Â  Now, I say that in the legal sense where no legislative or policing body might stopÂ them or you.Â  You are however, free to oppose them and bring up counter arguments which is the whole idea of free speech.Â  I say this as someone who has been in that very same position.Â  Going through school, I was not the popular type and it was considered quite cool or trendy to ridicule my religion or to simply dismiss me out of hand no matter what I saidÂ with absolutely no consideration to my feelings whatsoever.Â  I have no right to stop them from speaking, nor would I want to stop them.Â  The only roll the State has in the issue of Free Speech is to protect that right for all.Â  Agreement or disagreement is up to the rest of us.

I very much appreciate Jordan Peterson but I do have one bone to pick with his reference to the "Matthew Principle" (start listening around 6:05). Presumably this comes from Matthew chapter 13 verse 12 where Jesus says "Whoever has will be given more, and they will have an abundance. Whoever does not have, even what they have will be taken from them."  It's reasonable to assume Peterson - and the economists he refers to - consider this to mean material success. However if you go to the source, that's not at all what Jesus was referring to when after teaching the parable of the sower (seeds scattered in different places led to different outcomes) his disciples asked him why he spoke in parables https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+13&version=NIV  10 The disciples came to him and asked, â€œWhy do you speak to the people in parables?â€  11 He replied, â€œBecause the knowledge of the secrets of the kingdom of heaven has been given to you, but not to them. 12 Whoever has will be given more, and they will have an abundance. Whoever does not have, even what they have will be taken from them. 13 This is why I speak to them in parables:  â€œThough seeing, they do not see;     though hearing, they do not hear or understand. ___  Jesus was speaking about spiritual understanding, not material wealth. Context is important.   If you want further understanding of what the Bible says about excessive material wealth, I refer you to the commentaries for Isaiah 5:8  https://biblehub.com/commentaries/isaiah/5-8.htm  That actually concurs with what Peterson says about hierarchies having a tendency to become corrupt and unfair.

"Meaning" {and "meanings"} is about ideals, morals, ethics, values, and the fine good sense that says:  * this is important.  * this is UNimportant.  * THIS is valuable.  * THIS is worthless and/or destructive.   But above and beyond all this: GOD MAKES THE RULES,  and you are not God. Therefore, finding AND HONORING GOD AS THE Moral Authority is tremendously important. Especially when you find out and come to understand that HE IS THE JUDGE OF EVERY SOUL. Selah.

Peterson doesnâ€™t seem to be too familiar with any social science more recent than Durkheimâ€™s, though, and all of his psychology seems firmly stuck in turn-of-the-century â€” 19th century! â€” Vienna. If someone has never actually studied much science beyond remedial high school classes, or some very broad introductory college courses geared for humanities majors at z-tier universities, then maybe Peterson might sound science-y? to them? He does throw around a lot of Attic Greek â€¦ not from medicine, though, but from Aristotelian philosophy â€¦ and he even misuses that!  (Like in this talk Peterson uses telos several times â€¦ but Peterson doesnâ€™t mean it the way Aristotle meant it. Aristotle meant it as the â€œfinal causeâ€ â€” one of the several literal causes for which Aristotle posits the whole of the cosmos exists. But Peterson just means â€œself-actualization,â€ a very 1970s self-help term. And he could just say self-actualization! But no: this is just one of several times Peterson takes ordinary everyday anecdotal talk â€” the sorts of unverified claims and preconceptions that people carry around their whole lives and donâ€™t bother questioning, because theyâ€™ve always kinda heard them somewhere or another, â€œWomen should behave a certain way to become self-actualized as women! They must be caregivers and nurses!â€ â€” and then Peterson gussies it up with some fancy misused term, maybe in Attic Greek, and then regurgitates it back at his audience, and the believers among them think â€œOh, I always sorta thought that was true, and he just said it in Greek, so it must be true, boy am I smart, I like this Peterson fellow!â€ Thatâ€™s his whole act.)  And he doesnâ€™t cite studies, at best he throws around raw data that heâ€™s drawn very naÃ¯ve conclusions from. Like when he throws telos at the young woman in the audience, he then says something like â€œEven after years of social engineering in the most Marxist countries in the world, the Scandinavian ones, there are more female nurses than male nurses!â€ What he doesnâ€™t ask is: anything a real scientist would ask! Such as: â€œWhat are you aiming to prove and how would you prove it? For how long has the â€˜social engineeringâ€™ taken place? If there isnâ€™t perfect parity, has there been any change at all? Has there been more change in the Scandinavian countries than in the countries with no â€˜social engineering?â€™ If there is greater change in Scandinavia than elsewhere, then how many generations of â€˜engineeringâ€™ will it require for there to be parity? What would be effective vs. ineffective â€˜engineering?â€™ Are other factors at play, such as wage considerations, time constraints? Could it be that social constraints are placed more rigidly on one gender than on the other? Has there been a greater move towards parity between genders in traditionally male occupations? Is the ratio of female police officers to male police officers in Scandinavian countries changing? Is it changing more quickly than the ratio of male nurses to female nurses? Again, is there more change in law enforcement occupations in Scandinavia than in countries with no â€˜social engineeringâ€™ towards gender parity?â€ Etc. etc. etc. Nope, Peterson just yammers out anecdote after context-less anecdote, and then pathologizes everyone who disagrees with him.  Peterson doesnâ€™t practice science, he practices rhetoric. He has a conclusion, it supports his audienceâ€™s preconceived bias, he finds one anecdote that he can twist into supporting his conclusion, and then he phrases his trivia, factoids, and warmed-over Viennese psychology in as Byzantine a manner as possible â€¦ preferably with some (misused) Aristotelian terms in Attic Greek borrowed and thrown in for added window dressing. He probably knows what heâ€™s doing, is the cruelest part, and itâ€™s effective towards his goal: not getting published in peer-reviewed journals, but instead selling mass paperbacks to a sad audience of outcasts who want to feel smart. In fact, that heâ€™s so easily debunked and so outside the rigors of science actually contributes to his goal: when real scientists scoff at the nonsense he peddles to his audience, he can claim to be the victim of a â€œMarxistâ€ academic conspiracy, and use that to â€¦ sell more mass paperbacks to the rubes!  But thereâ€™s about as much science to his jabber as there was to, oh, what was that book Oprah loved â€¦ The Gift? The Wish? â€¦ the one with the â€œscienceâ€ of wishing things true. I love Jordan Peterson, and everything he, so eloquently, articulates. Sometimes I am concerned with the idea that he may be almost too clever, like a fairytale, possibly too good, almost completely faultless/seemless in his thinking/arguments to be true/for real. What exactly are his motivations? Obviously, he makes a great deal of money from what he does, and good for him, I suppose. No doubt he earns every penny of it, and certainly seems to feel that he is more than worth it. From a biblical point of view, is it possible, or feasible, he is in, fact, the anti-christ, hungry for power and dominance, masquerading as a charming man of peace? I certainly hope not. He does seem preoccupied with the theme/subject of power, 'tho. Also, if it is the case that all hierarchies are intrinsically unequal, and tilt towards, tyranny/corruption/violence, how come no-one ever seems to discuss a reasonable, functional alternative to them. Has this ever really been adequately attempted, an alternate substitute? No hierarchy equals no meaning, is his message. Across nature, all organisms. All cultures. Throughout our entire history. And long, long, long before us. Perhaps I am too much of an idealist. A utopian. A day-dreamer. Is that heaven? I would like to ask him if he believes in a heaven, a biblical one, or any other form of one. I know that he said that he behaves as though exists, which he points out is a very precise answer to the question: do you believe in God? Well, what do you mean by believe, he says, and what, exactly, do you mean by God? I feel the same way that he does about that question. I mean, I find that a very very difficult question to answer, simply. Put simply, yes. But it is I'd more complicated that a simple yes or no. I do not see faith as an insurance policy, just in case it it true, I will say I believe. I really do believe. But in what, exactly, is a bit more complicated to define. Sometimes I feel like this is fudging it. Anyway, food for thought. I always find him interesting to listen to. He is not God, 'tho. And being fascinated/enraptured/in love with your own ideas, and yourself, does not, necessarily, mean that you are right. xx.

Â @PITA-kd2jnÂ  Thank you for your courteous reply. I, personally, would be in favour of a non-hierarchical, high functioning society, more than anything, but Peterson has this thing about people organising their structures in to a pyramid type set up, whereby the strongest, fittest, most useful and dynamic individuals, naturally, inevitably, rise to the top of this, and almost all of the useless, unmotivated, lazy and stupid, uneducated ones remain at the moment, where Peterson seems to think they all belong. I am not sure if he is all he seems to be. I like him, and listening to him, but he consistently runs circles around people, less dynamic, less forceful, less articulate, and substantially less educated, and informed, than himself. Does this make him right? Well, probably, about some things. Certainly not about everything, though. Sometimes, I think, he falls in to the trap, or habit, of doing exactly what he accuses his critics of doing. That is, over simplifying things, for the sake of his own argument. I hesitate to say that his is conceited, or arrogant. Confident, yes. Where does confidence end, and arrogance begin? It can be a fine line. Easy to cross. Also, I am not convinced by his displays of emotion, when he starts to cry, publically, while talking about all the people who tell him how much they have helped them, and how much it means to him. I have nothing against grown men shedding a tear, publically or privately, but I have seen so it several times, now, and it just seems ever so slightly contrived. You know what I mean? Someone, I forget who, called him a fake. When you examine, in depth, what he is saying, it is not really all that profound. Just, relatively obvious, common sense, which a lot of the world seems to of done away with! One could say the same thing about Sam Harris. Lastly, I find it disturbing how much he talks about power, Does he secretly want to take over the world, and destroy everything, for his own ends? He might very well be the anti-christ! Well Jordan views on political correctness is not all that straight forward.  Nonetheless, I will give it a go. It is 3 fold.  First, hierarchies are about competence.   secondly, Jordan believes the best way to interact with each other is by viewing the other as an individual; an individual with their  rights and responsibilities in tow.  However as per Jordan, the opposite worldview of that is where people view  and interact with each other through the prism of their group identity. And this can be on the right or left.  Thirdly, and to tie it to political correctness itself;  Jordan believes those predominately on the left aisle of  identity group politics view hierarchies as form of power and tyranny; not competence. And  the politics been deployed by those people in an effort to dismantle the hierarchy of competence is political correctness.

No hierarchies until the 1800s?  That's whacked.  I don't buy it.  True enough that one could opt out and go off the grid, but that was only at the good graces of the powers that be. I think that one of the issues that was not mentioned in their exchange is that young people today are raised to be more sensitive to verbal offense, to validate a little feeling of being offended rather than sloughing it off and moving forward. A huge part of the problem of "offensive" speech is the failure to hold the offended responsible for their free choice to amplify their own offendedness. We all have these choices, though they may not be immediately apparent. And when the drama-queen response becomes habitual, automatic, and unconscious, we can choose to change our mental and emotional habits. Anger management classes, AA, and cognitive therapy (Aaron Beck) are examples of consciously chosen programs of this sort. A J - No, it's impressive because it's so rare nowadays within out self centered culture. It used to be prevalent in society and I'll illustrate with a quick story.   My dad and I were driving home from lunch when I noted that one of his friends was outside speaking with the police. I suggested we stop and see what's going on. To which my dad did the exact opposite and took another route home. When I asked him why he did that. He said that his friend was an adult and could take care of his own situation but what would make it worse was if he knew we saw him in a compromising situation. It was a move to save face and dignity, which is important in our culture. Dad didn't ignore the situation but knew that interrupting would have caused more harm than good for his friend. It turned out to be nothing serious but I learned a lesson about caring for the dignity of others that day.

I don't really buy into the idea that to be left you can't allow for hierarchies of competence, it's just that you believe those hierarchies should be sustained through non-material rewards so as not to create a class division - which Peterson agrees is destructive.  It's also pretty rare in modern society and history that you find a hierarchy that is truly competence or value based given how little, say, the financial world currently contributes to global progress and the general standard of politicians, or the mostly hereditary process by which hierarchies were (and in many cases still are through inheritance) maintained. He seems to be falling into the libertarian trap of drawing a very logical diagram on paper that just does not translate practically into the real world - although I accept the general concepts that he talks about, they obviously do feature in society just not so cleanly as he suggests here.  And as for the identity politics crusade I don't think they deserve the label of the left at all, for the most part they are privileged middle class kids with no knowledge or interest in class struggle or the history of left wing ideology. Their authoritarianism and hostility to free speech makes the term "liberal" totally useless in describing them, but more than ideologues they seem to basically be standard narcissists more concerned with their own immediate surroundings and their own image than the actual society around them. I see them more as a byproduct of the breakdown of political discourse, mainly in the US, than as an actual world view on either the left or the right.   Their lack of consistent values can be seen in the way in which they are used by the centre right social democratic establishment to desperately maintain relevance. A centre right social democratic candidate can be promoted by their movement if they happen to be a minority, whereas support for genuine left wing candidates (eg. Bernie Sanders) can be discredited on their identity (eg. "Bernie Boys"). Of course when you find a left wing candidate who is a minority standing against an establishment candidate who is not, the issue of identity politics is of course quickly and quietly dropped.

40:13 That explains me.  I think I've found solution(that works for me) to the issue a person who is high in openness, low in conscientiousness and high in neuroticism has. The issue is that they question every structure that exists and they trace that path until they reach a point where they question meaning itself, which is just a step away from Nihilism itself.  So what can you do about it? You can't just suppress your questions you have and just accept whatever system there is that is to be implemented. That will lead to dissatisfaction and build resentment over time.  So what I do to solve it for me is this: whenever I see myself digging a question to a level of resolution of truth that is understood by and is evident to be true, I check to see if I am at a territory which is closer to a place where I can go to radical rejection of meaning withing few more steps. Then I trace my entire way back to where the question's been generated while checking all the assumption I made during the journey and then  I dig reverse to question the origin of the first question and dig deep to find all my presupposition and evaluate all of them.  After that I can find new path where I can dig deep to the original question that does not lead to Nihilism.  Let me know,  what you think about it?

When it comes to the realm of intellectual ideas that Peterson is operating in, it becomes very quickly more about the concepts and the references to those concepts than the actual words. Like, you might have a perfect understanding of English, as good as any native speaker, but that doesn't mean one would necessarily be able to speak intelligently about evolution, psychology, history, or law, all disciplines which operate a lot on shared references and ideas that only come from study of those disciplines.   Among many other references, JP references a lot of Judeo-Christian stories as well as popular fantasy stories (Disney, Bible), psychological work of Jung and Nietzche, the work of Solzhenitsyn and other Russian psychologists (which I had never heard of until today), the history of Marxism, biology, psychology, and probably more. If you don't get these references it has nothing to do with English, it's from lack of exposure to these concepts.

Peterson's assertion that hate speech should not be regulated is unconvincing. When asked whether hate speech is a bigger threat to free speech than regulating hate speech, Peterson cops out of the question and offers no support for his claim that regulating hate speech is always worse (51:46 and 56:10).   To summarise Peterson, 1. Free speech is valuable because it allows society to come up with solutions to difficult problems, is a facet of individual liberty, and can ensure communal/familial harmony.  2. Harmful hate speech is a very common problem and the world would be a better place without hate speech. The problem of hate speech is that it impedes free speech by making the targets of hate speech afraid to talk. (57:26, 58:18) 3. Regulating hate speech is dangerous because it will impede free speech.This is because if we define hate speech too broadly as speech that simply offends someone, people with dissenting views will be afraid to talk. (59:16) 4. The best solution is to let people utter hate speech freely. People are generally more wise than they are foolish, and they will "by and large" not be convinced or influenced by hate speech to act violently. (58:30)  So Peterson admits that hate speech can be a threat to free speech (#2). Yet he bases his opposition to regulating hate speech on the same harm, i.e. that regulation is a threat to free speech (#3). So if both hate speech and regulation are a threat to free speech, where is the justification for why regulation is always the bigger threat? This is exactly the conflict that the person asking questions was getting at, and instead of answering the question Peterson essentially restates its premises.   Regarding point #4, that people are more wise than foolish and will therefore not be convinced by hate speech... Well, you just have to look to Nazi Germany, apartheid South Africa or modern-day Myanmar or Charlottesville to see that this is not always the case. Sure these massacres are rare, but I would argue that when they do happen their consequences are catastrophic compared to the small negative impact that limiting hate speech would have on the quality of societal discussion, individual liberty and (ironically enough) communal harmony (#1).

According to a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights, â€œ.... it may  be  considered necessary in certain  democratic  societies to  sanction  or  even prevent  all  forms  of  expression  which  spread,  incite,  promote  or  justify  hatred  based  on intolerance ...,  â€ (Erbakan v. Turkey judgment of 6 July 2006, Â§ 56). https://www.echr.coe.int/Documents/FS_Hate_speech_ENG.pdf   In general, the ECHR holds that some restrictions to free speech (protected by Article 10 in the European Human Rights Convention) are allowed in cases where the speech contradicts the values of the human rights convention itself. So your right to free speech is a human right, but if you speak in a way that obstructs the human rights of others, your right to free speech can be restricted.   Has this led to a massive restriction on political discussion or other important forms of free speech in Europe? I certainly don't think so. So in order for me to buy his claim that hate speech laws lead to disaster, Jordan Peterson would have to clearly tell me what that disaster is and why it is likely to happen. So far all I've head are vague rants about 'cultural marxism' and Stalinism which I have a hard time believing.
