The individual vs the collective, represents the conundrum facing the modern first-tattoo seeker. "What symbolises me?" Often becomes "What tribal symbol do I want?" which pales and blurs quicker than the ink. This necessitates the next tattoo, to update the tribal identity which also of course complicates and must decrease the potency of the chosen symbols already on their body. If the new symbol is also tribal, it will also rapidly or slowly lose significance to its owner, if they have any imagination and self-reflection. And so a driver towards ever-greater coverage is created. The normalcy of tattoo coverage is partially proof of Peterson's premise that intersectionality is a fatal flaw. If the modern first-tattoo seeker is aware of this fatal flaw, and works hard to determine a symbol of their true individual selves, this too will fade in significance - though probably slower than a tribal symbol, because of the individual paths we take.  I have specified the modern situation here to identify my exception - archaic tribal tattoos and their modern scion, authentic tribal tattoos. In other words, people whose tribal identity was a global identity as far as they were concerned, and their modern descendants, whose tribal identity forms a very large part of their individual identity because of its unbroken traditional lineage.  I have first-hand observational experience over my entire life of the resurgence of TÄ-Moko over the last fifty years of MÄori cultural development, as a fifth-generation pÄkeha New Zealander. TÄ-Moko today represents what it always has: whakapapa, or tribal lineage itself. Its authentic form has grown into near-ubiquitous popularity today with MÄori (though often not using traditional methods, which are usually only sought by those of high mana), in part as a reaction to the many and voluminous negative aspects of the colonial tribal invasion. If you wear TÄ-Moko it identifies you as MÄori, so therefore many things, but very importantly not a member of the invading tribe - or at least not identifying with the cultural extermination that was attempted, even if most MÄori have pÄkeha ancestors these days. In my experience TÄ-Moko is never regretted, the more traditional, the more treasured. Significant is the tribal support you get from wearing TÄ-Moko, though I can only speculate here. I think this is the reason why tribal tattoos of this kind are the exception to my opening argument. Modern members of the quasi-American western cultural tradition aren't genuinely tribal, in that being members of a tribe doesn't actually support them in any way, or at least not sustainably, which is why their tribal tattoos fade in both ways.

Speaking only as an interested layman, I believe in evolution - a premise much of human psychology are founded, including some of what Dr. Peterson's conclusions, even if not made explicit at every juncture of discourse (e.g. his reference to Goodall's chimpanzee observation).  But from several books I've read (one being from John C. Lennox at Oxford and certain doubts raised by Francis Collins of HGP), Microevolution leading to variation within species has a substantial case for it and has been thoroughly developed: not much to dispute.   However, there still seems to be remaining unanswered questions, not only about the semiotic complexity of the genome (another huge rabbit hole in itself), but unavoidable gaps that must be filled to complete the macroevolutionary aspect of the overall theory: it seems to be especially lacking from the evidence of fossil records, surprisingly, which leads some to reasonably doubt or hold off judgement until further confirmation of this apparently unobservable and unverified transition from species to species is substantiated with stronger "proofs" or "evidence".  The general theory seems to be, from my perspective and little knowledge regarding the matter, overly reliant on postulations from comparisons between the physicality of existing creatures and correlations between their genetic make ups - and still has not yet answered the most cutting questions of biology such as the origins of life itself, though one can hold onto that faith. Obviously the theory is not on par with other scientific theories, in my mind, compared to say those in chemistry or physics, because under the traditional model of the scientific methodology - evolution lacks the key component of replicability (how can we reproduce evolution and manifest complex sentient biological life from subatomic particles in the lab is beyond my imagination). This sounds more akin to the methodologies engaged in history than the hard sciences.  Given this, since so much of our inferences and what are today commonly accepted paradigms (rampant in fields ranging from philosophy, psychology to the harder sciences especially) are so fundamentally based and entrenched in this basic premise that "we MUST be directly descended from some other humanoid ape-like species" it would seem appropriate to revisit this particular question (among many others) given the impasses in the Philosophy of Mind, Linguistics and other areas which seem to indicate something contrary to our existence simply being an miraculous emergent property of an accidental universe?  Perhaps evolution, both micro and macro, is most likely valid and perhaps one day will be absolutely undeniable to all, but on the off chance we're wrong...what if its NOT the case at all?   Hypothetically if in the future we find this premise to be false or unlikely: how much weight or credence should we give inferences made in the past and discoveries that are extrapolated from evidence gathered from other similar organisms alone. If it were not true, how do we even begin to restructure the foundations we've built the modern world on? We've built society and formed our minds to the point where our behaviour are shaped and formed as a direct result of this basic premise. If the foundations are faulty, then the building must crumble at some point.   So have we been building on faulty foundations (not necessarily just evolution specifically, but using that to illustrate a point) so much so that we're now at the crumbling point where we have to re-examine the foundations, the brute-facts of reality we have taken for granted or put out of mind? For example, we're largely indoctrinated into a secular anti-theist society in my generation. But if the tenants or model from which society is progressing and developed on, are possibly false premises or faulty yet-to-be-proven-beyond-reasonable-doubt theories - then how can we expect this tower of Babel built upon the pillars of subjectivist philosophy and the human might of modern industrial technologies to survive into the unforeseeable future?   Most if not all my friends and cohorts are naturalistically inclined philosophically and spiritually - which consciously or not, are aspects of our psyche that inform our values and thus our motivations and behaviour. But what if we're wrong? What if God is real? What if there is such things as objective good and evil? These things seem odd given our educational and social conditioning, but just entertaining the possibility that our premises are completely off-base, why have we not thought or made precautions in the event that opposing claims might be true?   It seems much of society has hedged their bets on a very narrow philosophy, riding on the coattails of a trend of thought reflective of the times and contemporary intellectual progression - but we do so without much thought about the possibility of us being in error about fundamental questions.   Anecdotally, people seem to be doubling down on their bets and inferred premises that anchor their entire world view, rather than - as is the philosophical and intellectual tradition - questioning not just others beliefs, but our very own too.  Should I believe in the validity of my worldview or belief-system prior to holding it to the fire and throwing every diametrically opposed concept at it?   Both naturalists and theists, the left, the right, or whatever -isms you are attached to, should be put through the same trial by fire I feel. If you really care about the truth beyond your own emotions and intellectual honesty to even just yourself. Undoubtedly some ideas will burn up in the fire of inconsistency or improbability given human experience. Some will emerge stronger and survive.   Why are we not taught this at high school or university? Why do I have to learn how to think from Youtube? Why have the very cognitive tools that are essential to autonomy and freedom been stripped from us, even in highly affluent first world countries? Are we intellectually regressing as a species, or being artificially regressed as a form of control by powers beyond our knowledge or understanding?  I'm only learning to do this myself - to bravely doubt my own convictions first and understand to the best of my ability, opposing points of view and interpretations of reality.   2 more cents.

Peterson makes a great point which I noticed during my studies: Blindly adhering to Occum's Razor (or in Peterson's words in terms of lower vs. higher "resolutions" when conceptualising) makes me feel that a lot of possibly valid theories will greater explanatory power, but with more variables or "moving parts", are thrown out and often left by the wayside in preference of seemingly simpler theories. Just 2 cents.

Saving Grace - A few things first off. I didn't imply nihilism was a postmodern idea. Metaphoric truth is because its based on axioms that rely on the subjectivity of the party within the environment rather than the absolute autonomy of the party. And my use of nihilistic was as a colloquial expression referring to the state of somebody who has thrown away their idealistic axioms. I wasn't referring to the actual philosophical ideology of nihilism. The colloquial phrase means a temporary fall into despair because all that you have known is no longer valid. This is how most people use the word, which is very loosely tied to the ideology. To remain in despair and not progress forward to a better understanding doesn't serve your own survival aka metaphoric truth. I probably should have stated it that way in the first place to avoid confusion. If the grand narrative that gives you your ethos or life meaning, has been taken away, to wallow in despair will achieve nothing but harm to yourself. You need to get up and build a new ethos or adopt another one.  Reductions to nihilistic tendencies are only temporary and are actually necessary for any kind of reform. I'm not gonna get into ideological nihilism because that has little to do with what we're talking about here.   Not a fan of Dawkins tbh. He's a theorist that makes a lot of value judgement errors. He conflates telonomy with intentionality all the time. That's to say his logic is valid but not sound in those arguments. And that can lead to some very serious ethical conundrums. One such argument is his ambiguous use of memes. Or rather his personification of genes in his book "the selfish gene". Genes do not have the capacity to enact their "will" but rather they are affected by coincidental interactions with the environment. It's a function of process structuralism that genes are able to copy themselves rather than any act of their own volition. He goes on to make some ethical statements based on reductive arguments/generalizations. Stripped of their context those arguments may not be sound. Like his example of a child's prayer before bed, reinforcing the behaviour into adulthood because the child doesn't comprehend the prayer and merely mimics the act. If the child was cognisant of what the act of praying means, he would stop because it's totally nonsensical. QED: So religion is bad. [paraphrasing] To which I say bollox. The mimicry of a child does not necessarily guarantee bias confirmation because reinforcing behaviour is a contextualized act. Every psychologist knows this. All that praying before bedtime does, is get us used to saying a prayer before bed. It doesn't mean you'll say a prayer at midday or while waiting at the bus stop. Dawkins has a bad habit of making specific claims from reductive generalizations like this. And you can't derive a specific claim from a general one and still be sound because you have lost the context. Anyways, enough about Dawkins.   It's good to see that you've pulled yourself out of the inherent nihilistic tendencies of losing faith and found something that works for you. Dillahunty and a lot of new atheists espouse aristotelian well being as the new life's purpose/meaning. If they wish to then good for them. But it doesn't work for everybody. As for me, my meaning is derived from the relationships I foster. I'm still holding onto JBP's theory for the origin of meaning because it has always worked for me. You do you, because we live by subjective truths not objective ones.

My way of looking at experiences have been so far that everything that we experience is solely our interpretation of things and events. The same type of experience is never the same one.  â€œNo man ever steps in the same river twice, for it's not the same river and he's not the same man.â€ [Heraclitus] Or, what I personaly experience as demanding or stressful, for example, can be a joy for someone else.   Or, once you can visit a new place and you may not like it, would it be for internal or external reasons. It may be only because you had a bad day. Speech should not be hindered because loud hateful speech from one party needs to be addressed by an equally loud counter argument from the another. At around 25:00, he says that there are an infinite ways of construing the world, but only a limited number of ways with which one can successfully live and interact in the world.  It hit me that the same is true with regard to food.  We can come up with an infinite number of dietary plans or ways of eating, but there truly are only a limited number of ones which will sustain human health generation after generation.  For instance, when human diets were researched almost 100 years ago, there was a wide variety, ranging from insects/nuts/fish on tropical islands to oil/fat/meat in the arctic, but all the diets still met certain narrow principles (A/D consumption from animal foods, fermenting grains/nuts/dairy, broth, salt, sea food, etc.).  No groups were vegan, for instance.  I suppose after hundreds of thousands of years, you sort of figure out what doesn't keep a population thriving long-term.    And (thinking aloud) we sort of threw it all out in the 20th century.  Progress at all costs, I guess.  Maybe there's wisdom in listening to the "democracy of the past"?  We now imagine we can eat any way, live any way, marry any way, raise children any way, and it will all work out.  Maybe it magically will, or maybe, as always, nature will select the fittest and the rest will die off, either with bad health or tribal warfare.

The idea is called structuralism. There is a definite structure to society or anything for that matter and there are reasons why that structure is the way it is. Or more concisely, a reason why that structure has survived and endured while others have fallen prey to natural selection. Diets, societies, languages,  evolution, design and just about everything else that humans have touched have this structure. It's just that we've never had the ability to see it and took it for granted. That is, until ideologies start dismantling it, without knowing of the Chesterton fence.

Thank you for that term: structuralism.  Yes, this pattern of "patterns underlying a superficial diversity" does seem to fit across diet, language, culture, biology, and so much of human reality.  I suppose the list of "human universals" points to this as well.  Perhaps it could be thought of as a Venn diagram where each person (or culture) has a circle, but a slight majority of all the circles overlap.
I don't really get how there are supposedly infinite ways of construing the world.  At least not from a basic human perspective.

Â @rationalthought9979Â  - I think infinite is the wrong word to use. Countless would be a better term. For the sake of the thought experiment, we could use the example of throwing homosexuals off a rooftop. That differs from throwing them off a cliff and jettisening them into space. We can see 3 distinct societies, although the main idea of intolerance to homosexuality is shared. The question is how does that affect societal fitness. Will a society constructed in that way survive or necessarily thrive? And why? The structuralist may say no because our biological empathy would destabilize that kind of society. The post-structuralist may say yes because biological determinism isn't a thing and behaviours could be controlled in part by social conditioning. That society does not need to be totally stable to survive or even thrive.    Note in this way JBP is taking the poststructuralist position because he doesn't advocate for a grand unifying narrative but the interplay of 2 competing factions. That of chaos and order. And accepts a certain amount of discord for the ultimate sake of progress. All the while railing against postmodernism/poststructuralism.

I can tell you personally from my experience and those I know, that the vegan has been fantastic to me (I have now been vegetarian for about 8 years and vegan for a bit more than 3 years - I switched from vegetarian to vegan around three years ago, to make it clear) . It is an absolutely fantastic means of eating and remaining healthy, at least through what I've experienced and seen in others that I know, that have been vegan even for far longer than me. But then again, everyone might have their own opinions on this and I respect this.  The only thing I can recommend is for everyone to listen deeply to their body and see what it wants - this will bring you to the optimal diet for your body. What the ultimate optimal diet for every body is, whether it is vegan or not, I cannot say, because I concede I do not know. However, through my personal experience, I would advocate mindful eating and deep body awareness above any other diet - it is this that has saved my life and brought me to the vegan diet.   However, if you do choose to continue eating meat and animal products, do think about the animals you are consuming and consider they too are living beings. Thus, if you must consume them, at least try to do so by eating animals that are raised in factory farms and instead try to get your meat, eggs and dairy from free range farms - where animals, at least, are given some semblance of respect.

Jordan Peterson has sound logic because he constantly forces the conversation into a tiny corner and removes all complexity and nuance. He talks about "political correctness" in a very specific way, in a very specific context, and does a good job sticking to his topic of expertise. The issue with this is that, as a result, his stance is actually very ineffectual in many other contexts where he must reframe the opposing argument to fit his narrative and perception. Which is actually very specific to his experience on campuses, and is quite far removed from the average persons experience. Just watch his Truthspeak debate alongside Stephen Fry. IMO, this is a great example of what I"m speaking about. The majority of the debate ends up coming across as nonsense because Peterson can't move away from his ultra-specific argument which has to do with campuses and Marxism, rather than reasonable discourse between adults.   He also becomes hyperbolic at times when he frames ideas he doesn't like or agree with as "slippery slopes" (a clear logical fallacy) into a dystopian Marxist nightmare. Unfortunately, many of us see this for what it is--- no different than the groups he criticizes and their attempts to frame the opposition as an "evil force" pushing the world into darkness.  Lastly, the "figurehead" worship Peterson receives makes many of us extra cautious. As with David Ike, Alex Jones, or anyone else who tackles very specific "alternative" subjects, figures that act as tent poles for ideology lose their objectivity once their career and their financial success become directly tied into their status as such a figure. Of course Peterson is consistent in his logic, and he holds a very clear and unwavering stance about certain things. But that's because at this point he MUST be unwavering in his ideology, his success counts on it. He isn't going to keep booking interviews paying him tens of thousands of dollars each if he starts to compromise and speak more a broader understanding, because that's not what people want from him.   Don't get me wrong, I don't hate the guy, and if he wasn't doing it, someone else would. But people need to take a step back and observe their own hero-worship of a man. He's just a guy, and if you watch enough of his content you WILL see flaws.

It's these ideologues that he takes issue with and unfortunately doesn't distinguish them from real postmodern thinkers of the past. hm, ok i only had a few minutes to think about this, but here is a question:  - he claims that individuality is paramount and leads to the most wealthy and prosperous societies, thus everyone should put his individuality first and not his group/tribe - he claims that hirarchies form naturally and have a purpose, and individuals are at first sorted by "skill" into the hirarchy (debateable of course, i would claim its blatantly wrong in the face of evidence).  so, if individuals put their well being in front of the well being of a group (=hirarchy), because thats what "should" be paramount as he claimes, than the position in the hirarchy is more important than the efficiency of the hirarchy for the individual as his personal outcome depends on it. on a second note, it can even be better to work against the efficiency of the hirarchy to further your position in it. if that is the case, corruption is the natural end of any hirarchy as ANY individual in it will fight for his/her position in it and not for the function of it.  thus, the conclusion would be that a quick turnover of hirarchies is necessary for a functioning society for them not to end in corruption, which is, by Petersons claim, not a strong suit of conservatives, but the left (they create quick turnover).  now, isn't what i observed above the definition of "warfare", just on an individual basis, the fight for positions in the hirarchy? its the same accusation he makes of "tribal systems", they also lead to warfare. also, how does that lead to "prosperity and wealth" as a natural consequence, as he claims?  what he describes is more of what we see in failed and corrupt states where the individual fights for his supremacy. wealth and prosperity arose in countries that freed themselves from that and put the functioning of society ABOVE the individual right, meaning  - the economy gets regulated, stops monopolies and powerful interests to subdue competition - civil rights stop the infringement on the rights of others, countering your interest to win over others - power gets restraint by moving it away from the individual into institutions that are regulated to serve society as a group/tribe (=police, military, firefighters).  i could go on but...its YT after all, and i said my piece. it is pretty clear that humans have to act on both, their individuality and their tribe, and find a BALANCE in it.  declairing that one is better than the other is not really an argument you can keep up, the obvious solution is: both, individuality on a small scale, tribe on a large scale.

52:30 This whole discussion of free speech. I really dislike the "sunlight is best disinfectant" argument basically because it's bullshit.  In Finland we're one of the world's most educated people. We're HIGHLY individualistic and highly rational. And when hate speech started to ramp up massively in early 2000 , it resulted in a far-right ultranationalistic blatantly racist "true finns" party jumping from 0.7% support to 19% becoming second largest political party in Finland.  So that's the reality. In the world's most educated country, rampant hate speech resulted in catastrophic political shift in FAVOR of racism and hatred. So please stop with the retarded sunlight bullshit, please.  HOWEVER.  More and more I think about it, the more his latter half of the argument and the argument that gets used less is actually correct. That while hate speech does exist and it ABSOLUTELY breeds hate, actually limiting speech is such an egregious assault on the very essence of our existence that it'll do more harm than allowing even fifth of the nation to turn into racist bigots.  Now I'm not 100% sold on that yet, because I've not obviously seen where it would lead atm, but I'm being more and more pessimistic about people's ability to think rationally on things, therefore it's increasingly paramount that free expression and freedom of ideas are promoted, to train critical thinking.

"Human beings cannot create their own values"...   What?  Why not?  Whenever Peterson waxes about Jung, it seems that he takes on Jung's pseudo-philosophical, New Age mystical woo woo and all that comes out is nonsensical word salad.  While it may be true that Jung's archetypes reflect things that once had survival value for humans, they're so broad as to be near meaningless or have been better articulated elsewhere.    Is Peterson trying to say that human beings can't decide on values from an evolutionary perspective?  That is, the drive to reproduce and pass on one's genes is intrinsic and cannot be "chosen?"  As a population or species, that claim might be true.  As an individual?  We ignore that biological "value" every day as individuals, and some do so voluntarily and for life.  Since he never explains what he's actually talking about, who knows.  It's just a nonsensical assertion.  When he gets to freedom of speech... Jordan knocks it out of the park.  This is the one issue on which I continually find myself in agreement with him.  Yet, I'll note... he speaks clearly and decisively on the issue.  No need for word salad or references to philosophers and mystical notions (though there are ripe pickings for the subject).  On this subject (and when discussing the science inventorying the differences between women and men) , Peterson actually sounds like he knows what he's discussing.  I only wish that were the case with his other subjects.

I am about a third of the way through studying his tome "Maps of Meaning" and have listened to most of his public lectures online and as Professor Peterson would say, "the devil is in the details". The details are embedded in a context which, in this case, is a room of what I assume to be mostly Oxford University students. I have listened to this 'lecture' twice and it is clear to me that he is tailoring his utterances to the audience. He is also engaged in various trains of thought that upon completion amount to rather complex arguments that, I admit, are sometimes difficult to understand. He does this much more completely in Maps of Meaning - the very detailed construction of an argument about a particular concept.  The details are also in what he means by 'belief' and 'god'. I cannot discern from your sentences what you mean by 'belief' and 'god'. Peterson's approach is from Psychology and I think one must view his statements in that context. I recommend this excerpt from a recent discussion in which his ideas about this subject are more fully realised and are indeed illuminating. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VVVuZ_0PUTU

So basically, if you have a healthy regard for your own family, your own nation, your ethnic or linguistic or religious groups, then you're a collectivist who will bring about tribal warfare? But I could just as easily, and wrongly, say that Jordan is arguing for a converse tyranny: an individualistic, atomised form of non-society, where it's every man for himself.  It's not a choice between having a jingoistic chimp colony or being a lone wolf fighting for individual survival against other lone-wolf individuals; these are absurd extrapolations.   You are an individual, but you are also part of a society, or many societies; and beyond that you're part of the human species, and part of the universe. It's not a question of collectives vs individuals. It's a question of right and wrong, depending on certain circumstances and certain contexts. Sometimes it is right to stand for individual liberty and the rights of the person; other times, it's right to stand up for your community, or your country, or your religion, etc.  Jordan Peterson is wrong.

Charles Lumia In the "free speech vs hate speech" debate, the first step is to acknowledge the things each side gets right. Free speech absolutists are right about the dangers of allowing the state (or indeed the "victim") to define what constitutes hate. And hate speech censors are right that certain forms of speech have no place in a civilised society.  See, I want to live in a society where you can voice your opinions, however eccentric they may be; and I also want to live in a society where racially insulting someone is not only impolite but illegal. The question is: is there some principle whereby I can have the former and not the latter?  Maybe there isn't. Incitement, libel and all the universally-accepted restrictions on speech are too little; hate speech laws as they are implemented today are too much. And there's no obvious intermediate step, in terms of legal/philosophical principle, between the minimalism of traditional restrictions and the excess of handing over the definition of hate speech to the "victim", the courts and/or the legislature.  My best stab at an intermediate step would be: only prosecute hate speech when it is actually directed at a specific individual or group - where there is at least one specific victim. Racially abusing someone on the subway or on Twitter would thus be illegal under hate speech laws. But generalised comments or opinions - such as posting "I hate n*****s" on YouTube, or having a loud conversation on your phone about how much you detest gay people - would not. This would ensure that unpopular and even downright unsavoury opinions are not censored in the attempt to protect individuals from abuse.

If I was to say to someone on the subway that I dislike them because of their ethnicity or the color of their skin - certainly I would hurt their feelings and possibly make them feel bad.  But is that really abuse?  Is it similar to me physically attacking them?  In my opinion true freedom of speech includes the freedom to say hurtful things. I worry that we are stepping across a boundary.  Our protective laws have always been in place to protect people from physical harm.  Now it seems like we are moving towards trying to craft a society where nobody gets their feelings hurt either.  While having a society where nobody gets their feelings hurt SEEMS like a good idea - I worry that the price we would ultimately have to pay is that we eventually lose the rights to free speech and the rights to say what we want.  Just my 2 cents.

Winston   My view is that people should be free to do what they want to do. Absolutely anything. Including bad things, murder, rape, etc.  To stop bad things from happening our freedom would have to be restricted a great deal. Sure we can stop all murders and rapes if we kept people separate but that's unreasonable. The very thought is ridiculous.  The same idea applies to "hate speech" (although it's subjective and as such not a good comparison to rape and murder). You can prevent "hate speech" but to do it would require a great sacrifice to liberty. It isn't a worthy trade off.  So people should be free to do what they want to do. If they unreasonably take away another person's liberty then the law should be there to punish them. That's the best system by far. Liberty is paramount.  Considering "hate speech" specifically: I think it will sort itself out. There's no reason to be racist towards a group when you don't know a single bad person in that group for example.  Lots of what is considered "hate speech" is perfectly reasonable. It's a very subjective issue. Personally I've been called a nazi many times and I have absolutely nothing in common with nazis or nazi ideology.  If the people who called me such things were in power or had influence over those in power I would be unreasonably harmed.  The core of the matter is that "hate speech" isn't taking away anyone's liberty. Preventing "hate speech" by silencing people is. So while "hate speech" may be bad, it isn't nearly as bad as restricting a person's freedom.

Life Sense  There are definitely consequences for our actions, including our words. I haven't argued otherwise, in fact I've argued against such ideas.  We should all be free to say what we want to say but there will be consequences of course. Examples: if my employee calls me something that I dislike, I'm going to fire him. If a server at a restaurant says something rude to me, I'm not going to leave a tip, will likely complain, and I may not even stay in the restaurant or visit again in the future.  In both of those scenarios the person should be free to make their thoughts known if they so choose but they should not be shielded from the resulting consequences.  The same idea applies to your examples where violence is a consequence. I can't honestly say that words didn't lead to violence in my younger days. It happens. Words can lead to violence. But violence generally has consequences too: if you physically attack someone because they said something that you dislike there are likely going to be consequences for you because attacking a person is generally seen as a greater wrong than mean words.  Liberty is the most important aspect in the discussion. We should be free to do as we wish. Being free to do as we wish doesn't mean that there aren't consequences. The government shouldn't be involved unless you take someone else's liberty. "Hate speech" does not take anyone else's liberty. Thus "hate speech" should not be regulated. It is an infringement on liberty. It's clearly wrong.

The idea is to let people speak, because the general population majority should (and hopefully) know better and know the hate speech is foolish - thereby the speaker becomes isolated on their own accord. In a way it is about self policing the group without rigidity of hard and fast rules that eventually create contradictions.  Example of contradiction and difficulties is the ratio.  When you're talking about 1:1 you might offend 50%. But when you reach larger crowds 1:10, 1:100, 1:1,000, etc you might offend one person, but then that's one issue/view and almost all issues/views could have a negative impact on another person. The contradiction then becomes as the crowd grows larger then the chance of offending someone grows higher and higher. Eventually, this is the question. If you aim to not offend anyone it means you censor virtually everything. There is virtually no limit.

I could have this wrong (and I probably do) but it seems to me that Peterson's answer to the second student's question about how meaning is derived was, in its ultra distilled version, that meaning is that which for what we've evolved to seek out in order to maximize our chances at successful survival and procreation and perhaps even any peripheral means to those ends.  That may explain things which carry extrinsic meaning (things that are a means to an end such as places and things) but I think Peterson misses an opportunity to grapple with those things which are intrinsically valuable (things which are valuable unto themselves, such as people).

Ryan Lucas But wouldnâ€™t that be relative to their utility? If so, that means they are merely a means to and end rather than being intrinsically valuable, that is, ends unto themselves.   Things such as diamonds, gold and money are given value by us and so may rise and fall throughout the spectrum of value and so are relative and subjective and dependent upon human opinion through the lens of usefulness to the world around them. I mean it's a pretty big question.  I think most of us would place a high value on a human life.  But what about the life of say Jeffrey Dahmer(American Serial Killer) , or a pedophile who's raped a child?  Or a school shooter?  In your example of a slave owner, I'd say the "master" views his slaves as animals not humans.  He views the slave as we would a horse, it's a work animal.  You can also look to Wars and Revolutions, where the value of human life was very little.  You could look to gang/cartel culture and argue life has very little value outside of their "tribe" , but a whole lot of value within it.

I agree that it is a big question and thank you for appreciating it. I also agree that most of us would place a high value on human life but what I'm trying to tease out is the possibility that the value of human life, whatever that may be (I personally believe it to be incalculable), exists independently of human opinion. We are unlike rocks, which are made of material the same as us, yet have no value unto themselves (so if there's a difference, it must be due to a reason which transcends the material of which we are made).   If you, Ryan Lucas, had suffered the unfortunate accident of having been born at a time, place and circumstance where you would have been a slave and your master valued you as he would a horse or dog, it rings true that objectively you would still carry a greater intrinsic value than that of a horse or dog despite your master's opinion.   This is similar to the idea that we are all born with certain unalienable rights, I think that those unalienable rights themselves are a natural manifestations of having unalienable value.

You do not need leaders who control by law/power/coercion.  The best/better/preferred will tend to rise to the top because people tend to prefer to deal with the best/better/preferred naturally. Karrlo SmithI think that's a false ideal of it's own, though I'm very much on board with the sentiment. Every individual need not be moderate. But as a group we must be moderate. There are things that being very liberal or very conservative benefit individuals and society by being, that if we were ALL moderates, our society would lack. Moderates often lack the certainty of their ideals to ACT decisively for change, and at the same time, lack the conviction of their societal foundations to STAND FIRM when some aspect of society is under assault, but is critical to NOT be changed. We need the structural strength of the very conservative at the same time as we need the fluidity and forward lookingness of the ultra liberal... the outcome of either position in extremis without the balance of the other, and the glue between them (the bridge) of the moderates, is ALWAYS catastrophe, regression, and disaster for a society. And also, conservatives RARELY bury themselves in a coffin of hatred. Hatred tends to come from your ultra Liberal types, who see how utterly pathetic Reality is compared to their lofty ideals. Conservatives usually express DISDAIN, not hatred. Hatred is typically the realm of the Reformers, the Revolutionaries, the Socialists, etc. Conservatives mostly just want you to not shout so loud, and get the hell off their proverbial lawn. I do believe the most WISE position is as the moderate, however, as there is a certain humility intrinsic to recognizing that picking a side based on any individual's fundamentally tiny intellect and breadth of experience is certain to induce error.  I believe it is the Moderate's role, and moral obligation to ensure that the Conservative and the Liberal have us as a mediator and a go between, who can validate the virtues of both, and repudiate the vices of both, while ensuring we do not fall into the trap of hubris, and thinking that we are superior to them, simply because we have but one virtue, the virtue of moderation in belief-... they have their virtues that are equally important to ours. I also think it's nigh impossible to truly "understand" the position of a true conservative without being one, nor a radical liberal, in the same vein. Sympathy is a start, but you only get empathy from similarity and co-aligment of yourself on the spectrum. And Empathy is the only doorway to true psycho-social-emotional understanding between people.

I don't really get why this man has so much appeal. None of his ideas seem particularly novel. Timing perhaps? Dunno. But if he's getting interesting ideas out to people who hadn't heard them yet, then more power to him.  I found the first part of his speech interesting, in that it almost perfectly illustrated why, from the perspective of Eastern philosophy, Western philosophy is limited in scope. His views highlight the most fundamental difference between the two.  This idea of "approach and avoidance" is now well anchored in Western thought, and is finding more and more support from the sciences. This maps on nicely with the Buddhist notions of raga and dvesha (basically desire and aversion). Interestingly the Buddhist tradition adds a third component, moha (confusion, delusion).  But here's the fundamental difference. Peterson argues that there is no escaping this. That if there is any way to transcend this, it is by searching for more value (more ragaâ€¦). It is a strange use of the term "transcend", since he isn't saying that we can get out of this system, merely that we can make the best of it by going in one particular direction (that of value). Eastern philosophy (and since I used Buddhism as an example, I'll just stick with that) proposes that we can actually transcend this duality of approach and avoidance, including "approach" as meaning not just want but need. In that sense, it is far more ambitious than anything Western thought has to propose. So when he concludes that there is "no human life without value" ("value" being what we seek to approach), then he collides frontally with Eastern thought. It is probably apparent where I stand on this particular issue. Anyways, I just found it interesting to find such a crystal-clear case of these two systems of thought colliding.

+sallyfieldrequired I do. I remember being fascinated as a teen by the picture of ThÃ­ch Quáº£ng Äá»©c, a Vietnamese Buddhist monk who immolated himself in 1967. He sat in the lotus position, didn't move a muscle nor utter a sound while his flesh burned away. I think at that point you can say that he had transcended at least avoidance of physical pain. That picture still blows my mind today.  I think that the concept of liberation, the end game of Buddhism, can in certain ways be summed up as the transcendence of approach/avoidance. I should add the disclaimer that by believing that actual liberation is possible, I'm putting myself in the camp of the slightly woo-prone not-entirely-secular Buddhist practitioners. I suspect a secular Buddhist would say that we can just get really really good at detaching ourselves from approach/avoidance, but may never be able to transcend it entirely.  Peterson mentioned that this was hardwired into our biology. It's interesting because I just finished reading  the book "Why Buddhism is true" by Robert Wright (who I suspect won't get much love from the Peterson crowd because of his political views: he's quite the lefty!). He put a spin on Buddhism that I had never thought of before. Basically, he argues that we are deluded because it is in the best interest of our genes that we be deluded in certain ways. The mechanism of approach/aversion is at the heart of this delusion. So, for instance, the fact that pleasure is short-lived can be seen as a way to entice us, the vehicles or our genes, to keep going for more and ensure the replication of our genes. To take the simple example, if you have sex once, it's nice but that pleasure is short lived. You'll want more. From the perspective of the genes, it makes sense. It pushes us to do everything to keep them going and bring on the next generation of genes. So he says that Buddhism is true in the sense that we are all deluded about the nature of reality (our view of reality is distorted by approach/aversion), and the reason we are deluded about the nature of reality is because it is in the interest of our genes that we be deluded. In that framework, the insight of Buddhism is that what is good for our genes is not necessarily what is good for us and "awakening" is what allows us to transcend the chains of evolution.  Anyways, there might be ways to reconcile Peterson's notion of "value" with this. They're just not apparent to me right now.

PeRK, great post! I think I could add something to this as someone who followed Peterson before his recent fame. I'll start with an assumption: I'm guessing you're either over 40 or had a really well educated life, something that is rather rare nowadays. Peterson's main appeal is how he can articulate a good defense of something that a lot people, particularly students agree with, but were unable to articulate. Particularly in regards to postmodernism/neomarxism, because despite how things are looking today, they had been winning the verbal battles for the last couple of decades, broadly speaking. The result is that more women are being educated in practically every western country, with most countries having 20-30% more female higher education graduates, yet the focus is still on how to get women to do better.  I agree that a lot his ideas aren't new, but he is breathing new life into them, causing new people to discover Carl Yung and Solzhenitsyen. He's also reinvigorating thought about IQ. IQ studies are very robust but have been shoved into the corner and you see it frequently maligned as being completely without value. This while it's the single strongest predictor in the psychological arsenal of a complete suite of lifetime effects, stronger than male/female even. Critics may say it's not perfect, but what tool is? It's a better diagnosis tool than any other tool psychology has.  Lastly the one new idea that Peterson brings is one of recent discovery, which is the fact that certain big five traits predict political leaning to a moderately strong degree. This tells us that it's inescapable to some degree that we won't all agree on politics. It could tell us a host of other things that we haven't figured out yet. It's what informing Peterson's view of that you need both the left and the right and it's one of the reason he has been more conillatory to the left and thus got media attention, while also being right and thus riding the current wave of politics moving towards the right across the west. I think that's a couple of the reasons that he grew so far. And on top of that he's ambitious and started to aim and work for it.  He might well have ended up fired/disparaged like Tim Hunt or James Watson, but he bet his job and fought tooth and nail and he came out on top, something that frankly, few people expected at the time.  I do agree that he collides with eastern thought and it's an interesting idea; though if merely aiming higher would be sufficient reason for another type of thought to be considered better, then marxism would be a better mode of thought, as it aims to create a society of full equality, a kind of utopia. It's aiming higher, but sometimes when you aim higher the results are more catastrophic. Like trying to jump into the deep side of the pool when you haven't learned how to swim yet. And to abuse this metaphor further; we might not even be able to learn how to swim fully, so until it's proven, it might even be safer to just try to learn how to not drown better.

+andrew Well, it did what Peterson tries to do for his patients. Pulled me out of a severe depression and put me on the path of a life that I consider meaningful. At the time (late 90s), 3rd-wave cognitive-behavioral therapy had not really spread all that much. A lot of what was being proposed for patients seemed to me either irrelevant or ineffective. This isn't a global statement, just a personal one based on my own experience of trying to navigate the different types of options that were available to me at the time. After a few years of running into the same ineffective options, I found an age-old tradition based on an empirical discovery of the mind with a promise of liberation from suffering. I'll leave it at that because if I really express how important that change was for me it'll get all mushy real quick ^^ I'm obviously not saying that that was the only way or whatnot (in Western traditions, we have Stoicism that presents a lot of similarities with Buddhism, including its focus on an empirical discovery of your own mind). +Mirjam Heijn Interesting. I can see his appeal as a sort of "popularizer". He is after a very eloquent man. There's value to popularization but I can't help but see the potential downsides. In this video he gives the example of a person who thinks he knows what there is to know about his car because he knows how to drive, but as soon as it breaks down he realizes that he has no clue how the car works. I think there's a very real risk of that with popularization. It gives a wide number of people access to important ideas. But more often than not that knowledge remains superficial. And personally I think the discussion about postmodernism and its effects have remained at a fairly superficial level. If you go down to the root of it, it gets really messy and hard to parse.   On the idea of certain studies having been shoved to the side, I agree with you. But I also think there's a tendency to misunderstand how science works, even outside of any influence of postmodernism (this ties back to what I was saying about the discussion about postmodernism remaining superficial. because many would say that if IQ is being dismissed, it's because of postmodernism, end of story but I doubt that's true). Max Planck famously said that science didn't progress by convincing your opponents, but by letting your opponents die off. Science advances one funeral at a time. I think that's much closer to the truth. It may be the case that IQ studies are being dismissed by a generation of researchers. But that would be just one example among countless other theories and empirical studies that are dismissed out of hand today, not on their merit or lack thereof, but because they don't fit in the particular model that current researchers have. Those researchers will die off, and the next generation will be more open to those theories. It's how it's always been in the sciences. So I don't know how effective it is for Peterson to try to make the case for IQ studies to a lay audience. The real change will occur later on, just as a natural result of generational renewal. He might be wasting a lot of energy on something that will just occur naturally, in due time.  On the swimming metaphor, I hear you. I find it to be an interesting topic for discussion, but in the end, what really matters is whether it helps people lead better lives. If the model that Peterson proposes is getting all these people to "sort themselves out" as they all say, then more power to them! The theoretical discussions, although fascinating, really don't matter in comparison to that.

+Robert Johnson If you want a very specific criticism of one point he makes, I think his comparison between human beings and lobsters is misguided. I would put it in the category of partial truths that omit important scientific facts. For instance, when he points out that if you give a lobster an intake in serotonin, it will get back up and fight. Serotonin does play a role in agressive behavior, including in humans. That's the "true" part. But if we're just going to take partial truths, then we could also make the exact opposite claim than Peterson, i.e. that increased serotonin levels cause a subject to be less agressive (in humans, not in lobsters because they don't have the complex neurological structure for this to work). Because it turns out that it is also true that low serotonin levels cause the communication between the frontal lobes of the brain and the amygdala do breakdown, thereby impairing a subject's ability to control basic emotions like anger, leading to higher agressive behavior. So, he's not wrong per se, he's just taking an extremely limited view of the topic because it suits his argument of the omnipresence of hierarchy in living systems. And I could take the other partial truth I described here and use it as an argument for the exact opposite of what Peterson is sayingâ€¦ Neither of us would be wrong. But neither us would be right either. The views I've heard him express about postmodernism suffer the same flaw. They are based on a very selective truth and other aspects are conveniently left out because it suits his narrative.

+Robert Johnson That's a lot of questions! ^^ I'll do my best.  So, first off I should say that you'll find a variety of answers to these questions depending on who you talk to. Buddhism is a long and rich tradition so I guess it's no surprise. In the same way, if you asked a Christian how salvation works you'll get a different answer depending on the denomination of who you ask.  The second thing I should say is that some of your questions aren't really relevant to a Buddhist context. The Abrahamic religions try to present some answer to the question "what is reality" (why are we here, where do we come from, etc.) While Buddhism does have some answers to that, it is really not the core of its teachings. You could say that Buddhism is more concerned about figuring out why we feel the need to answer those questions in the first place. That's in no small part why there's not much proselytism in Buddhism. The answers to those questions just don't matter all that much. To give you an example, religious Buddhists for the most part have some notion of reincarnation. But there is no strong insistance on anyone actually believing in it. It's just not what matters most in the teachings. The closest you'll get to a description of reality is the idea of "impermanence" summed up in the sentence "what has the potential to arise will also pass". If you're a secular Buddhist that might refer only to what happens in consciousness. If you're a religious Buddhist it might also apply to the physical world (I'll try to stick to the more secular stuff just to make it more palatable). In fact, I'd say that if you had to sum up the entire teachings of Buddhism in two words, it would be "everything changes".  As for the self and what it means to realize it's an illusion, Sam Harris had a nice definition of the self: "the sense of being a thinker of thoughts in addition to the thoughts themselves, the sense of being an experiencer in addition to the experiences themselves". For me, it's been more of a process punctuated by several insights instead of just one big insight. I think the first major insight was during a meditation retreat. At some point the "self" just faded away. The sound of the wind didn't feel any less part of "me" then my thoughts or whatever physical sensations I was feeling. I'm at a point where I can more or less reliably slip into that state of mind. For someone like me who was severely depressed at one time, this is invaluable. I could be overcome by feelings of hopelessness, sometimes anger. Now these feelings still arise, but since I can put myself in that state where I no longer feel attached to those feelings, they just pass without leaving a trace. Another way of putting it is that consciousness is a mirror, and the mirror doesn't take the shape of what it reflects. So when certain feelings are reflected in consciousness, you don't take their shape, they just appear but the shape of the mirror doesn't change. But even with that, I'm still far away from what Buddhists would call "awakening" or "enlightenment". Every step forward is a realization of something else that I hadn't noticed, some filter that my thoughts were going through without me even realizing it was there.  As for links, here's an interview with Stephen Batchelor, former Buddhist monk who now teaches a form of secular Buddhism (so, much more palatable to Western audiences, particularly in the fact that he doesn't buy the "no self" idea) : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WYXm6vAxOMI Here's a series of talks by Joseph Goldstein on most of the fundamentals of Buddhism, still fairly palatable but not entirely secular: http://dharmaseed.org/teacher/96/talk/6162/ but put together is more than 50 hours long! So it's really only for it you're really really interested (or just incredibly bored ^^). And if you want the full-blown religious approach, here are some introductory talks by Bhikkhu Bodhi: http://www.buddhanet.net/audio-lectures.htm

Robert Johnson Everything is an illusion, a subjective perception and creation of your own reality. It does not mean that you are fake and that if everything is an illusion there are no consequences, life is very real.  Rene Descartes famously said, 'I think, therefore I am,' that's just about the least amount of words you can use to explain that.  It can come as an intellectual epiphany if you've never considered it before, but for most people they already have a sneaky suspicion as to what's going on so it's not like the floors gives way beneath them.   In terms of insight you realize after a while that your brain can't always be trusted, for instance the other day I had a job interview, I thought it went OK at the time, but I didn't get a call back within a week. Suddenly my brain filtered out the good stuff and focused on the bits that didn't go great, soon my memory of the interview became negative so according to me the interview was a disaster (my brain had rewritten the past experience independent of the experience). I actually got an email about a week and a half after saying I'd got the job, I joked with the recruiter that I thought I was never going to get an answer. They were like, we got great feedback and they look forward to working with you. In that moment my impression and memory of the interview completely changed to positive...  a bit of a long winded way of saying that reality can be warped by our brains and they aren't as reliable as we would like to admit.  So when you say what is 'the self,' it's everything, your genetic predisposition to certain character traits, environment growing up, your interactions and how your brain changed because of them. It's also your conscious self and as Jung said your unconscious 'shadow self.' But mainly when people talk of the self it's the little voice inside their head and most meditation practices are about dissociating from that narrator of unfolding events and as you aren't 'in your own head' you live in the moment, that's enlightenment, being effortless with wu-wei, going with the flow etcetc  What is not an illusion is that your reality is a specific illusion to you. There are other things so say you and I are in a room together and you spot a blue chair, you then touch it, I also touch the chair. Because we have both independently witnessed the existence of the chair it is not an illusion. That's not to say that two people can't be subject to an illusion but that's a whole other can of worms.  I know you didn't ask me but they were interesting questions so thought I'd give my two cents :)

Rampas Inhumanas: you said "Everything is an illusion" Illusion: an idea or belief that is not true, or something that is not what it seems to be. https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/illusion) Those are two different things. We are trying to talk about things that are true, partially true, wrong, bad, good or so-so. We will succeed and fail. So why say "Everything is an illusion" if our dictionary definition is: "an idea or belief that is not true." That means you are stating that 'Everything is an idea or belief that is not true'. That doesn't make sense if you are trying to think about what is true (and what isn't for that matter).  You said my illusion is a specific illusion to me. But all humans share exactly the same in birth, death, body and mind (basic natural commonalities of impulse and feeling). Is all of that an illusion? Obviously not. And by the dictionary definition of the word 'illusion' it is not. So what is left (individually)?  Obviously idea and belief is more specific to the individual...that would be illusory if you state that Everything is so. And if you say "Everything is an illusion" (pertaining to idea and belief = all not true by the definition) then many people (hearing that and trying to digest it) might end up being undermined in terms of their creative individual expression.

The last question (and answer) is one of the best descriptors of the basic misconception of conservatism I have heard.  It's not that conservatives are racist, don't care about the poor etc etc,... it's that we feel that we have a pretty good (though not perfect) system going and that the offered solutions (eg welfare, open borders etc) are going to cause far more damage in the long term than they solve.  For example the establishment of welfare programs - as well-meaning as they might be - have unquestionably given rise to a large class of people who have become incentivised to stay poor.  Notice how progressives never are willing to discuss long-term impacts of their proposals?  It's always "Do this, because it's the nice thing to do" and that's the end of the argument - if you object you are simply mean (or worse).

Same, happened with me and my brothers instead. Imagine all the same stuff with you and your friend except experimenting with all the persuasion imaginable. Every kind of way to just inveigle them to play.  I learned that while letting them win every now and then has its 'balance'. If you try to win a teeny bit more, but persuade at the next session. Then you can retain a higher ratio of wins.  Another thing i found was to pair 'bad repeated sessions' randomly about good ones. So when i play, sometimes i would do shit and instead of winning a few times, he would win like half the time. Then i would get serious and he would still win (because im acting). Then next day i play more normal, with a few moments where i go over the top and play my best winning most if not all the games.  then back to a regular strategy. I felt that if they could see that i was an inconsistent gamer in a longer scale. They would be more willing to gamble on playing and winning against me, even if i could win just about every time otherwise.  So over a longer period i had the 70/30 styled splits. The 90/10 splits where i played normal. And the 40/60 splits where i got my ass kicked. When i did that my brothers would keep challenging me or responding to the challenges positively. Lots of fun.

Bonobos don't patrol their borders and they don't murder other bonobos. They help strangers get what they want too. They share and contribute without discrimination. So here's my question for Jordan Peterson.  In this age of abundance and engineered scarcity, does it make more sense to organise our economic lives like the chimpanzee, or like the bonobo?

Buy the way Peterson is contradicting himself. ,,If people can not create values, there is no way that We've ever could came up with the idea of God.'' Single person can not do it, that's true, but We can. Humanity can create values, We've been doing for millennia.
Ohh my God
Congratulations! You have found the exception to the rule.  However, the exception proves the rule.

Our two closest relatives. One, the chimpanzee, lives across a large range and is subject to resource stress. The other, the bonobo, lives in the Congo basin, a region that is not subject to resource stress.  I'll ask the question again if you like...
Before that, I agree that some individuals and countries have an abundance of resources but I don't see where we have "engineered scarcity".  Please clarify that bit.

Artificial scarcity describes the scarcity of items even though either the technology and production, or sharing capacity exists to create a theoretically limitless abundance, as well as the use of laws to create scarcity where otherwise there wouldn't be. The most common causes are monopoly pricing structures, such as those enabled by laws that restrict competition or by high fixed costs in a particular marketplace. The inefficiency associated with artificial scarcity is formally known as a deadweight loss.  In a capitalist system, an enterprise is judged to be successful and efficient if it is profitable. To obtain maximum profits, producers may be restricting production rather than ensuring the maximum utilisation of resources. This strategy of restricting production by firms in order to obtain profits in a capitalist system or mixed economy is known as creating artificial scarcity.  Artificial scarcity essentially describes situations where the producers or owners of a good restrict its availability to others beyond what is strictly necessary. Ideas and information are prime examples of unnecessarily scarce products given artificial scarcity, as illustrated in the following quote:  If you have an apple, and I have an apple, and we exchange apples, then you and I will still each have one apple. But if you have an idea, and I have an idea, and we exchange these ideas, then each of us will have two ideas.  â€”â€‰Phi Kappa Phi  Even though ideas, as illustrated above, can be shared with less constraints than physical goods, they are often treated as unique, scarce, inventions or creative works, and thus allotted protection as intellectual properties in order to allow the original authors to potentially profit from their own work

Think of the water supply. In many places it is illegal to place a water catchment system on your roof for your personal consumption, forcing you  to draw water from the main supply, or monopoly supply.  There's many, many instances like this.

Perhaps I'm misunderstanding Peterson, but what I got from his description of the two views of politics today with regards to how to view reality is that the problem with the left is the tribalism which leads to conflict. He prescribes individualism as the solution for this.   However the way I see it, all he has done is made the tribe smaller. Instead of being part of a small-medium sized group, you are part of a group with just one individual member (yourself). It is tribalism minimized to the smallest degree. It doesn't change our proclivity for conflict, all it does is that it makes the opposing tribes so small (single member) such that their potential for harm is minimized (would you rather fight against one individual or against a mob of 10 individuals?).   Rather, wouldn't it be better to enlarge the tribe to encompass all of humanity, and indeed the world? Instead of having 7 billion individuals fighting amongst ourselves, wouldn't it be better if we were all part of the same single tribe and so had no opposing tribe to fight against? There would thus be no need for political correctness. Perhaps one could argue that this is not realistically possible and so Peterson's prescription at least minimizing the harm. The reality however is that we don't live in a world where we are all taken to be sovereign individuals. Tribalism is unfortunately a reality and so hoping for individualism is just as much a long shot as hoping for one big tribe. We are caught in the middle.   Maybe I misunderstood him...let me know

One thing I appreciate about Jordan Peterson is how, despite being verbose and esoteric at times, it's still relatively easy to follow his line of thought if you take the time to listen closely. This lies is large contrast to speakers like Michael Eric Dyson who seem to use a greater-than-needed number of unnecessarily large words not be better understood, but to sound sophisticated and passionate enough to get an applause while ultimately just confusing the audience.  When Jordan Peterson says more than is needed to get a point across, you at least learn a little bit more about the specifics of his beliefs. When Michael Eric Dyson says more than is needed to get a point across, you'll probably find yourself rolling your eyes and rooting for him to get to the end of his passionate run-on sentence.

I found it was useful stuff. But i also found it could be better represented. For example, his points about freud and the environment's role in shaping inner forces lean towards Skinner brand behaviorism today. In fact, skinners beyond freedom and dignity is a fantastic read that dives into the kind of follow up that peterson does not do well in this precise case. Skinner was also influenced quite heavily by the Russian thinkers.  What i think Petersons biggest advantage is the way he has returned the 'dream' to psychology in the form of cognitive information resolution in the mind of the thinker. Peterson himself notes via his own introspection the varying levels that a philosophy can take.  In entrepreneurship there is the same exact process but instead of looking for a rigorous theory to support it. The intellect must just find a way to manifest the dream of the entrepreneur organizationally. And with sensitivity to the market.   The theories of psychology can be seen as a product of psychology. Similar to how a map is the product of a good geography department. And the psychologist and geographer are very similar in professional ontology. We are thrust into the world of mind and reality with very little understanding beyond our intuitions and agreed upon ideas. Hence the centrality of maps in both studies.   But petersons idea's ability to be used as an effective map is evident. Far better than skinner could have ever managed. Which i am absolutely certain given his publications that he resents. Despite is enormous influence in the field of psychology on a whole.  Much like Aristotle Peterson is uniting all aspects of human nature (especially the biological and political) into the psychological concept and presenting it in simple digestible and directly useful cultural format.  While its not immediately clear the value of say pop musicians to experimental ones. Or pop psychologists to experimental ones with the truly radical ideas. The more information there is, the more maps that allow better filtering of information themselves become embedded within a hierarchy of value.  Even if its not a new idea, its application is fairly new , tangible and timely. Our cultural and post modern problem can be reduced to 'too much information'. An unintended consequence of diversity and new ideas. Naturally we need a way to preserve the good without stopping new ideas. The political cognitive map of intersectionality has failed terribly here, despite its overwhelming popularity in policy.   In the same manner that intersectionality brought scientific and political power to tribalism or our tendency towards collectives. Petersons maps of meaning with all his talk of evolutionary play, heirarchies ect brings scientific and political power to individualism. This is the psychological experience hence its relevance.  I also somewhat found him lacking in explaining the benefits of collectivism. For example, corporate entities are collectives. So much so that they even have 'person hood' in spite of the individuals that compose it. This means the employees are collectivized under the corporate banner. And this is fantastic on many levels given that we can actually do far better through cooperation towards specific goals than we can do apart. Societies with strong corporations are far wealthier than those without.  Corporations as collectives have their efficiencies that can even be rendered crudely in politics. A fascinating example of this is when Castro used his entire nations wealth to genetically engineer a new milk producing cow and design their entire economy around milk and cheeze. He used communisms collectivization ethos to turn the state into a corporation that produced milk, milk related products and whatever else the dictator pleased (instead of what the people needed). But at least for milk, there was massive development that couldnt happen in their small economy at that time. Akin to a capitalist nations endeavors when matured. It was terrible for the nation's overall development and economically ineficient because collectives cannot possibly satisfy all humans needs. But by divesting the collectivized power to many many smaller collectives, individuals have choice to find a place to find meaning.  IF meaning is somewhat a product of the work we do. Then a corporate society is one which has a plethora of choice for how someone finds meaning. Especially if they want to produce more value.   There is a place for collectivization. Its in the corporation. Not government. Government should be for individuals the majority of the time because diversity is fundamentally a solution to oppression of ideas and of peoples.  While petersons ideas are not entirely fresh in origin. The realities he explores are very much what we need to explore to get rid of the pathological mentalities that infected our base notions of the individual and collective, given our current psychological cultural development today.

Gotta say, Peterson isn't suited for this sort of Q&A. Not because he is inadequate, but his innate predisposition. By nature of his topics and methodology Peterson doesn't simply 'answer questions'. He breaks them down and rationalizes every single smidgen of the tinniest piece, builds it back up, and then derives the answer. Of course this is in no way bad, but in a format where similar questions are brought up one after the other, Peterson's tendency to laboriously clarify his rationale simply doesn't fit. It gives a sidetracking feel to the answer. And while he comes back to it by the end, its filled with redundant paragraphs that takes away from the actual answer.   TL;DR: Peterson should stay away from Q&As, as his M.O doesn't fit the format. Stick with other forms of discourse (debates, speeches, therapy, classes, books, etc). Just my take on it.

I just completely disagree with Peterson's views on post-modernism. To get on board with his ideology it seems that you need to reject post-modernism, which is a pretty bold ideological perspective to take currently (although of course I'm not shouting it down). I'm just confused as to how so many millions of people who watch his videos have turned their back on post-modernism and post-Structuralism, without seemingly understanding those schools of thought in the first place? And everyone saying that the 'Lefties' don't like him because they're snowflakes obviously inherently misunderstand that many people fundamentally disagree with his philosophical and critical perspective, in a way which makes it almost impossible to argue against him as the two people will end up talking about different things (an example of which was his debate against political correctness).   I would actually be interested in hearing WHY, in this day and age, after all the varying schools of philosophy and critical theory that occur after the Frankfurt school and also preceding that - WHY so many of his 'followers' one might say, are so anti-postmodernism? And also why they can't see that when he 'owns' people debating against him, he's not winning, he's just coming from such an opposite philosophical perspective that neither his nor his opponents arguments are intersecting.

I think Peterson functions best in Q&A's. I just think that despite what he said ("That's a good question!"), the questions weren't actually very good questions. In contrary, Lafayette College asked questions that were to some degree beyond his ability to answer sometimes and as a result a much more valuable discussion.  Basicly if he can answer with his previous work (which he mostly could), you have not asked any worthwhile new questions. Though I suppose to some degree that is inevitable.

That's a pretty substantial aspect of my argument. Most people in a Q&A won't be able to ask worthwhile questions, especially when its a paragraph question -> 3-5 paragraph answer. Think if Oxford union can't do that effectively, it's a fair anecdotal example. By not worthwhile I mean questions too common or broad, where Peterson's consistent extensive answers aren't necessary, and therefore feel redundant.  That inevitability you agreed with is why I say avoid Q&As. This won't happen in my aforementioned alternatives, as those are chronological or at least patterned. I believe a debate / interview is where he functions best, as been proven by his many viral videos. General-public Q&As, not so much.

I can see why you say that. I guess I prefer the chaos and unpredictability of a Q&A, because even bad questions are telling me something about the environment they come from. I haven't seen a very good Q&A from oxford in a good while, for example and some really atrocious ones. So that tells me that Oxford is not going in the right direction as an institution, most probably.  I definitely see where you're coming from though. In this case I don't lay blame at Peterson's feet, rather at the people who gathered that day at Oxford's feet. I thought it was quite nice he kept his initial speech short, for example.

Agreed, Oxford has produced some especially terrible content in recent time. At least from what's been recommended to me; so this is coming from a semi-ignorant perspective, not enough to say wether Oxford as a whole is heading downhill. Some really intolerable talks though nonetheless.  But if the goal is unpredictability and unique perspectives, I feel a class' "question time" following a lecture or a debate involving multiple intellectuals with different perspectives (similar to the munk debate, but possibly a larger group) would accomplish said goal without that 'inevitability'. As they would all be aware of the basics, allowing further, more in-depth discourse / questions.   I guess my issue specifically was indeed the audience, like you're saying. I want to see how far this can go, what truths further dialogue would uncover, and in what ways it would enlighten me. Self proclaimed "Street-level", like 1:04:43, just won't get there. And it seems to me that's what public Q&As always are, regardless of the intellect of the crowd. I want great intellectuals convincing each other-- not the general public like a game of politics.  In a way Q&As just hit a different front, which I just don't really care for in Peterson's case. Probably biased my view of it in a sense.

There are plenty of funny moments in here, it's just not what I came for. Nearly all content out there is a mix of semi-serious discussion broken up with humor (e.g. all the DESTROYED videos); this is one of the few places I believe should stick to the serious stuff. This sort of ties into the whole format thing, where Q&A is more casual, while debates tend to be be strictly on topic and wholesome. Peterson is one of the few exceptions that's capable of remaining deliberate, thoughtful, and blatant throughout.   With political game I meant the idea of "as long as the other can't prove he's right, you're right". A game, or an act, attempting not to convince the opposition, but the audience.
