It's also worth pointing out the vaccine analogy, a vaccine is a microbe in a weakened form given to the immune system to stimulate it to recognize the agent as a threat, destroy it, produce antibodies to further recognize and destroy any of the microorganisms associated with that agent that it may encounter in the future, thatâ€™s also not the same as giving the body a strong (if not the strongest) strain and say Iâ€™m stimulating the immune system, you could kill that patient. How can his opponents misrepresent, oversimplify, and outright lie about his ideas and character? Anyone of sound mind who just spends 1 hour of their lives to truly listen and understand this video will have learned something new, whether you agree or disagree with any of his thoughts.  You can critic his ideas, and challenge and present counter arguments, but you must do so with the rigor, mastery, and effort of the person you are critiquing.  Anything less than that is disingenuous and just plain lazy.  And the worst part is that people will resort to malicious and unfounded character attacks with all the imaginable labels and epitaphs one can throw.  This person is attempting to find a solution to very real problems in the world right now, in his own learned capacity as one person.  He is not delusional that he is the savior of mankind, but he is humble enough to acknowledge that he is not certain of everything, and that everyone is needed pitch in, have dialogue and come up with a collective answer to move forward, regardless of whether you agree or disagree with each other.  We are all in this together, and it's in everyone's best interest to learn to navigate the world with each other rather than split into tribes and fight between ourselves for survival. That has been done many times throughout history, and the results have been devastating each time.

Jordan Peterson really needs to define "meaning". It can have so many different uses. He's using the Darwinian sense of "meaning" (i.e. increasing your chance of passing on genes) as the sole use. In a Newtonian sense, obviously we're just collections of matter and our "meaning" is to deterministically follow the laws of physics. In contrast, "meaning" could be what we want to do, what career we want, what we want to dedicate our lives to etc. etc. - basically there are loads of possible definitions. He bases his whole thesis on social structuring, right v. left wings, on hierarchies based on the Darwinian sense of meaning; I think this is a poor way to structure a society, as it will ultimately lead to a net decrease in human happiness due to increased inequality of opportunity and standard of living.

@Rampas Inhumanas Give me some examples. Fascism, for example, places extreme importance on hierarchy and authority - not a particularly happy populace (Hitler actually used Darwinism to persuade his populace that the Ayran race was supreme - amongst other things). Bhutan - places emphasis on togetherness and sharing, breaking down of many hierarchical structures as it were - one of the happiest places in the world. The examples are stark - basically find anywhere with a strong Darwinian streak to society and you'll get a pretty unhappy populace, and those places that offer people more power (i.e. diffuse power) and welfare are, on the whole happier. That's not to say that we should entirely reject Darwinism in the sense that it partly determines what we want as biological beings. There are so many other factors that influence what we want, what our "meaning" is, and Peterson seems to be claiming there is but one thing influencing how our society should (and partly is, which again is incorrect) be structured.   Anyway, have a top day!

@Josh C Incorrect. People have a massive range of likes and dislikes which will be somewhat affected by genetics but far more determined by upbringing. For example, one person might love tacky action films, but another thinks they're boring, laughable, and altogether silly. Are you telling me this is a direct result of evolution and has nothing to do with your environment / development? Are you telling me this is based on some sort of hierarchy? You may not be able to choose what makes you happy per se but it's not simply determined by genetics - that underlines a misunderstanding of evolution.   "In that quest for those basic needs to be fulfilled, you must be willing to engage in the social hierarchy and compete for validation and dominance" this is clearly wrong as well. Our basic needs are food, water and mates, in a Darwinian sense. This can be achieved in a multitude of different ways, as evidenced by the numerous, vastly differing tribal cultures around the world, almost all of which were actually far more democratic than our current society, lack strong forms of hierarchy (there will usually either be one chief that makes decisions based on the various arguments put forward by other tribe members, or there is a revolving council on which every tribe member needs to sit/participate), and existed for tens of thousands of years successfully. On the social side, literally just think about your own friends, partners etc. Are they all superstars? No, you value them for who they are, flaws and all.   You also say "... you find happiness in the escalation of the hierarchy". Some people might. Some people want to dominate others and be better than them, but those people are psychopaths or sorely lack self-confidence. Most people are happy doing what they love, regardless of if they're "the best". If I were you, I'd critically appraise Peterson a bit more, as basically your whole post was an unfiltered copy and paste from his writings / public lectures. There's a nugget of truth in what he says, but past that he just seems like a vaguely comical academic using too many words to describe too few ideas.   Anywho! Have a nice day!

I never denied that we're social creatures; I agree that we should live our lives as social creatures - many people find the most happiness and fulfillment by living their lives for others. This is unrelated to my above points, as what I said above and happily living in a community are not mutually exclusive.  "Wanting to be respected for mastery does not make you a psychopath". I perhaps poorly conveyed my point here. Of course mastery is something to be applauded, but mastery for the sake of dominance over others, as opposed to mastery for the sake of itself - to fully understand an idea or process - should definitely ring some alarm bells. Saying we're evolutionarily predisposed to dominate others at every opportunity is the same as saying that men are evolutionarily predisposed to raping women (both are behaviours exhibited that have clear evolutionary advantages in some circumstances). Even if it were the case, which is obviously isn't, why on Earth would we do that? "Because we evolved to be like that" is not a good enough justification.   Nor did I say we find "meaning" in our interests abstracted from real life. We find meaning in our interests in an abstract way (because we find the subject interesting, for whatever reason, dependent on many factors) and our learning about it. It may or may not be relative to other people, depending on whoever's interest it is (e.g. our position in these supposed hierarchies may or may not matter). Equally, I never said you can CHOOSE your meaning, but we can better define meaning in this case. Peterson's definition of meaning may be true to him - he wants to be the best at what he does and that's his "meaning" - it may also be true for you in your life (and that's cool - no big deal) but for so many other people it is irrelevant. Moreover, advancement in these supposed hierarchies, or just being "successful", isn't really valued by other people around you in any long-lasting way. If you're in communities that primarily value you based on your competitive achievements, get the hell outta there! Having lived my entire life in various well-knit communities (family, friends, academic, sports etc), I fully-well know that advancement in the hierarchy really isn't what is valued by other people and I'm sure the vast majority of people would agree if allowed to think about it. What is valued is if you're nice to be around, a nice person, if you will. Interestingly, I feel only people inexperienced in social skills would think that other people's valuations of them are based primarily (but maybe not solely) on how "successful" they are, which seems to betray Peterson's lack of understanding here.  I think I'm perfectly realistic about how we find meaning. I would simply say our "meaning" changes depending on the context - which Peterson's thesis lacks; he assumes one unwavering state that is not representative of the human world.

38:00 onwards proves beyond a shadow of a doubt that this man is an anti-Enlightenment charlatan.    Despite his deflection, the point he makes is extremely postmodern (or premodern):  he argues anything that helps a human's motivation to survive is inherently true ("Darwinian real"), and that this truth is at least as important as universalized observations based on repeatable tests ("Newtonian real").  Peterson's nomenclature confuses things, as I don't think Darwin would agree that what made his work true was its value to human survival--it's true because it describes biological phenomena observed in a reality external to human motivations (today we call this "science," though we might, here, want to say "natural philosophy" or "natural history" to avoid anachronism).    Indeed, Darwin's work ran counter to the meaning/telos that just about every thinker in his day ascribed to the world.  The point of natural selection was precisely that, in reality, there is no meaning to survival--just competition between species (or genes) within a finite and randomly/chaotically changing environment.  We humans might not like it that that's true--it might even be better for us if we collectively decide something else is true instead.  But, the fact is that it IS true--observably, repeatably, theoretically, demonstrably, objectively, etc etc.  To let go of this is to let go of any meaningful notion of the modern project (or "Western Civilization" as this guy likes to say).    You're being duped if you fall for this.  It's classic social-constructivist postmodernism, it's just in a conservative self-help voice, so y'all go for it.  Consider asking questions about why this guy wants to make human motivation a reality on par with Newton's laws--why he wants to present his worn out Freudian (!) readings of cultural history as a serious perspective on Darwinian theory.  As far as I can tell, he's trying to inject a conservative cultural agenda into fields in which it doesn't belong--and in turn to politicize reality.

As far as I know, almost no-one in the philosophy of biology (which is post-Darwinian synthesis, obviously) denies teleological views of biology now. A rare exception is Alexander Rosenberg, although even he's gradually shifted away from his early hyper-Humeanism. There was a real effort, for instance, to develop mechanical theories of biological explanation (and explanation in general) in the mid-to-late 20th century, through things like the DN-model and the SR-model, but as far as I know, contemporary philosophers of biology don't think that they can do justice to actual biological theory and reasoning.  So no,  post-Darwinian biology is NOT opposed to teleos. Quite the opposite: we can't explain biological reality WITHOUT talking about teleos, including those beyond natural selection. (I note that you had to be ambiguous about what is selected, and also ignored the fact that contemporary human evolution isn't even Darwinian, e.g. most humans don't die prior to reproducing. Social Darwinism would be incoherent if it WAS!)  "he argues anything that helps a human's motivation to survive is inherently true "  No, he doesn't. What made you think he does, especially since he explicitly contradicts that in this talk?  (Disclaimer: I don't agree with Peterson on truth.)  Finally, you mischaracterise the logical relationship between Darwinism and the existence of meaning. What Darwinism provided was a theory of EVOLUTION (not life in general) that was superior to those that interpretations based on the unfolding of some broader teleos or plan. For example, AT LEAST post-Darwinian synthesis, Darwinism is better supported than Intelligent Design. (Creationism hasn't been well-supported by evidence, ever.) Ok. What doesn't that imply for the existence of meaning? Nothing: their logical relationship is logical independence. Darwinism can be true and the most flowery theory of the meaning of life can be true. Darwinism can be false and the most thorough nihilism true.  Might I suggest you re-examine those shadows of doubt?

I don't share Jordan's representation of Jung's view of Nietzsche. Nietzsche was not arguing for a blank slate where you invent your morality ex nihilo. He was arguing for individualism, which means coming to your own morals through subjective means. In effect, this means that you will indeed come up with the same "solutions" as many others. However, the important points are: 1) you cannot just take these things on hearsay from religion as being moral and still be a creative individual, and 2) you may indeed discover some variance in your "meaning" to others depending on your individual personality traits among other things.  So by "creating your own morals" the meaning is similar to finding a career based on what you actually enjoy instead of it being dictated to you by a career counselor or the some kind of career bible that tells you what you should and shouldn't enjoy. He never said that these morals can be anything. However, let's say that someone did look within and find that their morals are to cause suffering as their highest ideal. This will obviously not work well in a system that is created for collaboration and procreation as humans are primarily built. However, the question as to if you should try to be someone else by adopting "normal" human values or not, or be yourself and likely end up in prison or dead but at least authentically so, is an open issue.  There are human norms, but they may or may not apply to you. Take having children. Sure, we are built to do this in general and nature will likely reward such a goal and give feelings of meaning. However, does this mean "you ought to have children"? No! You might hate it and be a terrible parent and be much happier not having children. This is what is meant by finding your own morals and values. Part of this is realizing the price of having various kinds of abnormal values. To be authentic, you have to be willing to be abnormal, if are are. That is the point.

You do not have to be careful of your rankings, but you do with your hierarchies. This is a key distinction and conflating these is confusing. Specifically, free trade hierarchies have very different traits to imposed hierarchies.  The left/right distinction is less primary than the consent/force distinction. Too strong sauce for a 15 minute summary? Probably, but it still is a key point. The open/conscientious distinction is also a false dichotomy, becomes some have neither and others have both. The fact that you have have both means they are not necessarily at odds.

It tends to go that way with popularity; Peterson's popularity is well deserved in my opinion and in general of a good to the west, but with that comes many people that have a poor understanding of his ideas and follow and defend him on superficial basis; I've run into that a couple of times. I had the same experience listening with his 5-10 minute answers, though when I went back to the question, I thought he really did answer the question, though in a deeper way than might have been readily apparent. I don't think I'm fooling myself with that either; my IQ is around 130, which is a good 20 points or so below Peterson's, so I accept that in general I need a longer time to digest his ideas before I fully understand them.  I don't think it's fully true that people will applaud him no matter what; there seemed more than a few in the audience quite anxious to applaud exactly that which challenged him and I consider that a healthy sign. As he continues to grow, the price on his head, or the value of someone being able to tackle his ideas to be more precise, will continue to rise. You haven't really challenged the core of any of his ideas, only accused him of a straw man, mentioned some personal pecularities and pointed out some people display the kind of annoying follower syndrome. So let's say you're familiar with Jordan Peterson and you've read the literature but you can't quite understand the reason for his particular method of articulation because it's something like... too elaborate, or too metaphorical. Okay. So then you put yourself in that perspective and go " How do I manifest my thoughts in such a way that I would extrapolate all my ideas in the most fluent and comprehensible way possible?" Then you analyze the method of articulation and you express this manner of speaking through a verbal game ... we'll call it "parody" let's say. And it still isnt easy to understand cause this is dense stuff. I mean... the ability to articulate your thoughs through spoken word is the single most dangerous weapon an actualized being can have in his arsenal. That's excalibur from King Arthur. Its the sword that you use to slay the dragon of social repression and rescue your father from the underground. I really believe that! And these things aren't trivial; they're complex. But once you get that down-- ooh that's deadly man.

31:30 "[Because] Human beings cannot create their own values. We actually don't have that capacity. We might be able to participate in the creation of those values, but we have to come to terms with our own nature while we're doing so. And I think the biological evidence for that is absolutely overwhelming. If you don't believe that, then what that means is either you don't know anything about biology or that you've stuck your head in the sand to the point where you're unable to see."  I feel that he didn't spend enough time on this point. He mentioned that we don't have the capacity to create our own values, and proposed that there was overwhelming biological evidence for this, but he didn't elaborate what evidence he was referring to. I also felt it was rather unnecessary for him to say if anyone disagrees they are ignorant or intentionally blind. I don't find it to be a good tactic of argument. I accept that there are sometimes fundamental tenets of a theory which take too much time to get into explaining to a layman like myself who doesn't have the schooling behind me to automatically know what biological evidence he refers to, but even if he could reference it in passing, call it by name, etc. it would help a lot in my opinion.  Is anyone else able to extrapolate what it was he was talking about in this point? What is the biological evidence that points to us being unable to create our own values?

Oxford resident here. The university is out of term. So most undergrads are out of town. The vast majority of undergrads are British nationals.  The only people left are postgraduates. There are a lot of international post graduates, because they pay a higher fee and make the university more money.  The British postgraduates will often leave Oxford to go to their home towns, as out of term there is less interaction between lecturers and students. And if they do need to come back, it's a short commute back into Oxford.  The international students don't have that luxury because a flight home will cost many thousands.   But what difference does it make? They are all very intelligent and richer than the average person.  And their questions reflected this.

I think it could be argued that he has a cult following, that is, a following that idolizes him and follows him uncritically, attacking criticisms of him out of hand.  I do think it'd be completely unfair to characterize him as a cult leader though, as his central stance appears to revolve around openness to criticism and ideas. He frequently will say something along the lines of "I do not properly know the answer here, I am instead exploring thoughts in the space."  Also, it's easy to conflate a statement like "he has a cult following" with "his followers are cultish." One implies a subset, and the other implies a totality.

I think his point is that we are not rational actors. We have a huge amount of subconscious biological behaviour which has evolved over millions of years and our rational minds are only rarely in charge of how we feel or what we do. Therefore the idea that we can rationally create our own "values" which will be acceptable to and acted out by our subconscious is hopelessly naive (as anyone who has written a list of new Year's resolutions can attest).

Well now hold on. I agree that the subconscious is a much more potent force to direct action than the conscious. To say that our rational minds are "only rarely" in charge of what we do I think is pretty subjective and open to debate. True, my conscious mind does not choose when I breathe or other unconsequential actions, most of the time, however when it comes to actions of consequence I do believe that we are able to influence how we act.  On the extreme other end of the spectrum, when it comes to knee-jerk reactions like running from a lion, I can once again agree that it is our subconscious doing the work. I think in the middle there is a lot of room for our rational minds to flourish though.  So now on to the values. I guess it's worth asking what is a value, especially when it would come to, what is a value we might suppose to have created ourselves? I would not consider anything so fundamental as survival or comfort to be values that we create ourselves, but values such as decency or the respectful treatment of those less powerful than you I would say are not an innate value which derives from our basic instincts.  To discredit our own role in deciding what values we consider to be a priority just because we learn from and observe others is also a mistake to me. Everything we know came from others. We aren't physically able at an extremely young age to survive alone so we depend on others to protect and nourish us, which unerring brings with it a transfer of values from caregiver to child. Yet this often does not result in an adult possessing exactly the same values as the one who raised them.  As to new year's resolutions, I would say those are one form of value but not the epitome of the subject. Some people might take them more seriously but I would think most rational human beings realize that putting yourself up to a strong about-face on habits you have held for a long time (which is generally what new year's resolutions are about) is not an easy task and not something to take lightly. Rather, the changes we are able to make to our actions and our habits throughout our lives and not just at new years are a better illustration of how we can craft our own values.  Anyway thank you for the response, I look forward to further discussion if you are interested!

Are you familiar with the work of Jonathan Haidt? He's a social psychologist who has written and talked in depth on this subject. His view is that rationality is very much the servant of intuition - usually we make decisions intuitively and then use rational arguments to justify our decisions. He invented the "rider and the elephant" metaphor, where the rider represents the conscious controlled processes and the elephant represents our automatic processes. The rider is "in control" only so far as he directs the elephant where it is reasonably happy to go, and the elephant always gets the final say.

I don't understand why JP goes to such great lengths to explain his rationale against defining hate speech, in a way that seems to in part entertain the possibility that hate speech advocates might even be right. This is preposterous, they are fundamentally wrong from first principles so there is no discussion to be had, do not even give them the satisfaction. To me it seems perfectly simple and the answer is blatantly obvious. In fact it is in the very term itself, hate and speech. Last I checked speech was free so that takes care of 50% of the problem. Hate is an emotion and while to some certain emotions are more valuable than others we can all probably agree that all emotions have at least some utility. They are there for a reason, they alert us to something that is happening internally and in the external world and I would say that even hate has it's use. Seeing as we haven't yet made emotions illegal it would be preposterous to even begin to address making the expression of hate illegal. Of course when we have an imbalance of emotions it would be safe to assume that this is not ideal but that is more a matter of competence, emotional competence to be exact. However we have yet to make incompetence illegal either. So it seems to me that these advocates for the policing of hate speech are just fascists or emotion/competence nazis that want to stamp down on what they perceive to be an unacceptable emotion or state of mind.   It is quite ridiculous, all the laws that are necessary to govern this sort of thing already exist(limitations to free speech), asking for more would in fact end up putting us in a totalitarian state. But at the end of the day they are forgetting the most powerful tool we have to counter what some perceive as hateful speech, and that is freedom of association(don't like what someone is saying, don't talk to them, distance yourself from them). Oh wait, they are actually trying to take freedom of association away from you as well? They say it is racist, xenophobic? They are trying to make best friends illegal at schools too? Oh wow looks like it's far worse than i thought these people will stop at nothing in trying to stamp their ought on the world, basic human rights mean nothing to them(the ends justify the means).   The ends justify the means, which gets me to my final point. To me there are 3 kinds of evil. The first kind of evil is perhaps the most benign, it comes in the form of ignorance, or evil out of ignorance. Some would say that is not even evil, but I would counter that ignorance is in and of itself can be a kind of evil. The second is typically a byproduct of unquestioned self righteousness which inevitably manifests in the attitude of 'the ends justify the means' which at it's extreme manifests in a willful ignorance of the means in order to avoid corrupting the ends. This is quite bad as it implies that the person is at least in principle capable of knowing the evils of their ways yet is refusing to question their actions at any stage. The final and perhaps purest form of evil is when one knows what they are doing is evil beyond any rational justification yet they do it anyway the epitome of which is evil for the sake of evil. Thankfully these leftists have not yet reached the levels of the final evil but seem to be playing around with the second kind of evil and that is in and of itself quite sinister.

John Nada I'd argue that it's merely a survival mechanism for those who feel threatened. Part of the fight-or-flight response, if you will. A lot of people enjoy "certainty" in their lives, or the confidence in the "rightness" of their beliefs. Certainty enables people to make quick decisions/judgements and it keeps life simple and straightforward. The downside of certainty is that it can stunt intellectual growth, restrict analytic thinking and be a slippery slope towards extremism. Life becomes black-and-white...and eventually us-vs-them. When someone presents an argument that threatens a deeply held belief, the easiest response is not to think or to make a counter argument, but to attack the messenger, to silence them, reduce their potency, to remove the threat as quickly as possible. It is irrational in a civilised society, where logic and reason are so rightly cherished. When you are unable or unwilling to make an argument, what else is there to do but shout and scream? A baby can't articulate why they're angry or upset, but they'll let you know that they are nonetheless. You see this play out in various cult groups, political, religious, you name it.

Whatâ€™s high resolution? Logical reasoning? If so, great! But he continues on leaving that undefined and makes a shallow point that itâ€™s much easier to think in low resolution and call someone a Nazi. Resolution isnâ€™t defined at all, but is a rhetorical device. Great to argue against name calling I suppose, but he mostly said...barely anything. (B) that line is a good representation of Peterson, as it precludes any nuance or possible objection. No, itâ€™s pointing out that fascism as a political ideology has happened before in one manner and events that are similar are occurring presently.   If I were to wager a guess I would say that many of us also find Petersonâ€™s ad hominem attacks on the role of the university, combined with the insistence that he knows better than anyone else what we should be teaching  - even in fields in which he has done no research...a bit off putting. Anytime Peterson says a complaint about universities it is almost always followed by a mocking jeer at an exaggeration of what really is taught in classrooms. Telling students to think creatively about different approaches to problems and about the meaning of justice may merely be a teaching tool used to help engage students who would otherwise prefer to be drinking (trust me itâ€™s a challenge). Moreover most colleges are so desperate for funding they canâ€™t afford to be ideological to either left or right. Schools now use algorithms that calculate students reviews of their courses, their grades, and campus engagement. The program will provide a score and analyze the likelihood that the student will continue or leave. Colleges know exactly which semesters are most likely to cause students to drop out and which professors cause students to be frustrated. Most professors are not hired on tenure tracks anymore and the worst thing about teaching is that the student who sleeps during class, uses google on their phone to answer a question about the reading, and richly deserves a bad grade for turning in a paper that is badly written or maybe plagiarized - if you give that student a grade they deserve then they will almost certainly give you a terrible review. The reviews are saved by the provost and they determine whether you will be assigned classes to teach and your entire career as a professor. So, what do you think most people do? Let the student with the truly disturbing views of Islam pass a world religion course? Let the adamant liberal submit something slightly off the assigned topic? I went into debt of $100k for a doctorate, because I love teaching and research and want to make the world a better place through education. How much incentive would you have to risk getting multiple scathing reviews from students, risk losing funding, and likely face a job market that is truly fierce and dying just to do what Peterson is saying we do - namely, push students to be social justice warriors? Peterson's theory about post modernism completely falls apart if you view postmodernism as a "descriptive" theory, as it is intended to be. Postmodernism does not prescribe a framework for acting in the world, it describes the infinite structures through which to see the world. It is up to you to figure out how to act within that description. You could be a utilitarian, or a pragmatist, or conservative, a liberal, a whatever. But if you wanted to reason yourself to a proper set of morals and values, you will be served by recognizing the vast number of perspectives in the world, and orienting yourself to what you recognize to be useful and intrinsically meaningful.

"So then his problem is with Marxism not postmodernism then?"   Primarily, yes. Which is why he always says both "Postmodern" and "neo-marxist" in the same sentence, which riles people up endlessly who do not understand why. He puts them together because he has no huge axe to grind with postmodernism by itself, it's just that alone it offers no way of moving forwards in the world, as Brandon noted above.   In order to correct this a lot of left leaning people slap marxist ideology on top of it as a framework and you end up with the left wing culture he is railing against.

"he has no huge axe to grind with postmodernism by itself" - Peterson doesn't like postmodernism because it can lead to moral relativism, nihilism and undermining the structure of Western post-Enlightenment society. He doesn't see it as invalid but as destructive.

Postmodernism is more than a recognition of the vast number of perspectives. It's also an ethical and epistemological claim: that all of these perspectives are equally sound.  Check out Larry Laudan's essay "Demystifying Underdetermination" for a discussion of this point by a philosophy. Even "There are an infinite number of theories that are logically consistent with the evidence" doesn't imply "There are an infinite number of theories that are equally confirmed by the evidence".
* by a philosopher.

Note: Iâ€™m just posting this even though I rushed it and my structure could use some work.    It's not impossible. It's just difficult, as it should be. Take the law for example. One way to look at the law in America is as a collection of rules that derive their meaning through precedent and are interpreted on the plain face of their text. And that may be true if you look at the right epoch or the right area of law. But how do you explain the judge who justifies a judgment without precedent that stands because of the popular will. How do you explain a judge who makes a call on a matter that has a subjective answer? Clearly, factors other than precedent could affect a judgeâ€™s decision, and they could even go unsaid. On and on you can see all kinds of caveats to what seems like an objective original description of the law. The answer then, plainly, is that there is more than one valid description of the law, and because of that, there are likely infinite descriptions. The most accurate, but still incomplete, vision of the law is one that incorporates multiple perspectives to account for its function.   However, you do not need to concern yourself with the infinite portion of that equation. To +Myndir 's point "There are an infinite number of theories that are logically consistent with the evidence doesn't imply There is an infinite number of theories that are equally confirmed by the evidence". I agree, but the point is that there isn't just one valid description of phenomena that is confirmed by the evidence. You don't need to acknowledge that all of an infinite number of descriptions are equally sound, just that more than one is. Our reason and view of the facts, while flawed in their own way, are tools that can help us distinguish between narrative that are plausible, those which are theoretically helpful, those of which are overreaching garbage, and those that are practically applicable. Because the point, overall, is that it is impossible to describe the world in a singular grand objective narrative.   The utility of postmodernism, to me, is a reminder that a singular description of phenomena is not to be taken for granted. The infinite part of that equation of more of a logical aside, there is very little to be gained from it other than â€œoh thatâ€™s interestingâ€.   To the point of other commenters: Jordan Petersonâ€™s representation of Postmodernism is annoying because he doesnâ€™t seem to understand it, and itâ€™s hardly reasonable to blame the rise of neo Marxism and Marxism in general (if this rise is even happening, show me the evidence) on postmodern theory. To me, heâ€™s incorporated postmodernism and Marxism as buzz words to demonize the left.

theawecabinet I think conservatives enjoy Peterson for a variety of reasons that anger leftists.  One of the main reasons is that he is helping form what they perceive as a coherent ideological description and refutation of progressivism.   The left has had the biggest burst of innovation and a rapid adoption of new language and rhetoric probably since the 60s. "white privilege," "intersectionality" "systemic racism", etc.  Peterson positions himself as an "antidote" to this and equips primarily young conservatives with a means of understanding the root of progressive ideology and allows them to make sense of all these new ideas and where they come from.   Unfortunately, mixed up in the answer he provides to conservatives is an old far right idea of "Cultural Marxism" which Peterson has repackaged as "Postmodern Neomarxism."  So, looking at this, you can see why Peterson is almost universally maligned by leftists and progressives and why they see him as such a threat. His discussion about gender differences are just old arguments against affirmative action and diversity/inclusion programs: the disparities we see in society are caused by inherent genetic differences rather than systematic oppression, therefore they are unfixable and we should stop dedicating so much time and energy to these issues. I am not sure which country you are from and therefore don't know the state of government or education that you are coming from but I am in Canada (BC to be more precise) and might have some insight into what Mr. Peterson might see.  First I would assume that most people that he identifies as postmodernists aren't actually aware of where and how their beliefs came from. They are not likely versed in philosophy and/or history and don't make any connection with their thoughts and beliefs and the ramifications of them. These are people who believe in core leftist dogma such as gender is a continuum or the patriarchy is real and needs to be torn down or capitalism is the core of evil etc. but don't ever think about or extend these ideas beyond the surface level that they seem to feel right at. They are taught these ideas in university or find them on the internet and are drawn into the narrative because at an emotional level, they feel right.  These people have filtered into society as a result of these ideas being prolific in education for 40+ years and now they are represented everywhere in the culture. Mainly in education (not just academia but primary school on) and in government. Our current government has embraced the equity of outcome agenda wholeheartedly and has implemented social programs in an attempt to change society towards their ideological view of what is right.  For example, in local schools here, children are taught about gender continuum and racism and inclusivity at a very young age where they should be being taught simply to share and not bully. A 7 year old child does not need to concern them self with white guilt and the patriarchy.   Our government has passed compelled speech laws and for a while our federal agencies were not allowed to address someone as sir or ma'am or Mr. or Ms. on the telephone. They were not even allowed to say parent, father or mother.   I assume from your second post that we likely disagree on many issues including affirmative action but I hope we can agree that all of this virtue signalling and indoctrination does not actually examine an issue, it's causes and present a solution. It's nothing more than the proliferation of an ideological viewpoint and goes counter to the concept of a free country. In my opinion it is also counter to actually solving an issue if there is one and a huge waste of resources.   If you want to drive a social agenda then let's talk about improving healthcare, improving education k-12 and access to post secondary, affordable housing, reducing poverty, teacher shortages, labour shortages due to housing or 100 other real issues that need to be dealt with.

jml79 So the problem with what you're saying is that you can be against certain PC policies such as not using Mr. or Ms. or being against affirmative action or whatever, without instilling the perception of a dangerous overarching ideology that connects all of these things.   From my experience that just leads people blindly being against any kind of change to the status quo that progressives or liberals might support. When you start connecting dots that don't really constitute any consistent ideology this can lead to further and further right wing reactionary thinking.   If not referring to Mother and Father or calling people Ms. or Mr. is the result of postmodernist-influenced thinking, how far does that extend? What do these issues have to do with affirmative action, exactly? Is calling black people "African-American" postmodern PC thinking, or just a shift in cultural norms of politeness? What about referring to a trans woman as a woman, even though she was born a man? Is this a result of postmodernist thinking?   You could potentially convince yourself that one is, or that they all are the result of "postmodernism" or "intersectionality" or "marxism" or any other right wing boogeyman. But you need to think really hard about why you're connecting all these things and why they deserve a certain label. And you need to think about how far this ideology could logically take you into reactionary politics.   This is probably the best I can do at explaining why many people have serious problems with what Peterson is doing. Sorry.

Anton Just because other people are talking without nuance doesn't mean that it's okay to do the same. Especially when you are influencing as many people as Peterson is.  The general message Peterson presents in the area of gender disparities, as he did in this Q&A, is that they are caused by inherent difference. He doesn't really give any credence to the potentiality of hangover effects from patriarchy and other systemic issues.  This is why he always brings up that Swedish(?) study which apparently shows that gender differences become more pronounced as the playing field is leveled in societies. I'd like to take the time someday to read that study because my instinct tells me he is misrepresenting its findings.   My guess is that while this is true in some areas (males dominate engineering more, females dominate nursing, etc.), the general trend is that most fields (i.e., law, accounting, sociology, physics, finance, marketing, entrepreneurship, etc. etc.) show much less gender disparities as society become less patriarchal and women are encouraged to pursue education. He didn't really represent this side of the argument and nobody pushed back against him on this.  Again, I haven't read the study so I don't really know but practical experience would suggest he is somewhat misrepresenting what the data show and the goal of many diversity/inclusion programs. For instance, my own field of law has gone from practically no women 50 years ago to being roughly 50/50 male and female today.

Troy Barnes| Okay. Here's my best attempt to condense it: Q: Where is the source of meaning, if not God? A:  He answers the question first by noting that humans cannot create value by themselves. There needs to be something else. And that else is Freud's idea: that most of who we are, and what we do, is something that we have no control of. Jordan then predicates that these forces are the source of meaning, particularly in his first out of three answers: 1) Placement. According to him, we have these intrinsic forces -- motivations, maturation, etc. -- that becomes arranged into a heirarchy of being, and that heirarchy manifests itself into the community. Now, meaning arises from the arrangement of those intrinsic values, as well as from the community itself, or where a person is located on that heirarchy and where it should place the self. I think it's the idea that everything has its place in the world and that where everything else is, is predicated on its placementwithin the world. And that could be the source of meaning. 2) Contemplation. When an enlightening idea hits you, you get statled. Then you try to figure out what to make of it. Hence, meaning is constructed upon it. 3) Balance. One foot in the dark; one foot within light. The continous search for the unknown whlist keeping within the realm of what you do know procreates meaning.

He really is a simplistic "thinker" who spends a long time making points that could be expressed with brevity.  To take one of his simple notions: the idea of asserting the primacy of the individual and individual responsibility is all well and good, but dangerously naive. We are thrown into a world we did not make, we are judged based on our bodies, our accents, our friends (and our family's friends), where we were educated and so on.  In the face of these layers of social embeddedness, the individual often doesn't stand much of a chance.  This is at the core of Peterson's naivety.  The more interesting question is how to negotiate through a value-laden world that may or may not exist in your favour.  For this, we need the very tools that Peterson eschews - the tools of intersectionality and respect for difference - if we are to challenge calcified hierarchies.

NabsterHax Looking at everything through "individualism" just isn't that useful as people are constantly judged and have negative or positive impacts in life based on their identity. Really this just comes down to whether you perceive society as still having identity-based oppression that is worth fighting against.   For instance, if a small town in Oklahoma with a considerable Muslim population decided to institute a ban on hijabs, I doubt Peterson would have any problem with a group of Muslims banding together to fight against this. But wouldn't this be "identity politics"?  Part of people's problem with Peterson is that his railing against "collectivism" in the West seems to presuppose there is no longer any problems with identity-based oppression and therefore "identity politics" are not only unnecessary but dangerously divisive. Many, many people disagree with this assessment.

"For instance, if a small town in Oklahoma with a considerable Muslim population decided to institute a ban on hijabs, I doubt Peterson would have any problem with a group of Muslims banding together to fight against this. I'm a conditional and pragmatic tribalist, which is compatible with the idea of a sovereign individual. I'd prefer individualism, but it only really works if that's the framework that everyone acts out. But if some individuals decide to gang up and form a tribe and use that to their advantage at the expense of the rest, the individualists, what other choice do they have but to go tribal themselves? A tribe is more politically powerful than a bunch of uncoordinated individualists. There's a parallell to war here. War is terrible and mostly to be avoided, but if one side decides to go to war against you, what else can you do but to pick up a gun and go fighting? You either fight or surrender and let the victor do as they please with you. It takes two to cooperate, but only one to start a war â€” or to force the rest to go tribal. I do believe a society that's largely individualist is possible, but it requires reasonably closed borders. You can be individualist within a tribe, as it were, if the position of that tribe is secure and not under threat. But put a bunch a different tribes with different interests together in the same country and full on tribalism is unavoidable.

Regarding Baduki's comment: He's being serious. He's at odds with how to use the language--he prefers a pragmatic use of language and a consequence of that is that it's difficult to define some actions like 'believing.' It's clear that he doesn't know how to define the act optimally--there is a view of 'acting as if' and defining your words accordingly and a view of claiming a belief because of empirical evidence or statistical priority--both of which are too undefined to address with a position. If you disbelieve-there is also a question on what basis you do so--if you look at the recurrence of the archetypal God-then you are inclined to be partial to the existence of God literally-and are accepting a symbolic or archetypal existence of God by definition. If you use a statistical standard-you are more inclined to this position, not by much-but the partiality can't be quantified. If you use a scientific standard-you simply rule out the literal existence of God as something unfalsifiable-this is what most people do but there is also a sponsored ideology behind it-which makes it harder to be partial and it's not obvious that it is the default preference-if anything it appears not to be-but that is accounted for by a Darwinian propensity (ie-that there is a potential for a preferred mistake in terms of propensity to live--he also addresses this point frequently-referencing "Darwinian Truth' from Nietzche) rather than a philosophical foundation. I don't think Peterson is being disingenuous-he's being obsessive compulsive-and he would demand that level of specificity in most of his responses regardless of the subject of the question. The truth is-that it is a hard question to answer with an exact statement. In fact it is impossible to make an exact statement regardless in spoken or written language. If you did it would look like this: This (Used(having(possessing..)..)..)..  . This is defining each word of a statement. Because of this-you rely on pattern recognition and implication to learn to communicate some things are harder to prioritize for communication--The short answer is: he believes that you should act as if God exists and you should not include language that is superfluous-in this case: using words that contradict how you ought to act. So as a minimum-you should say you believe in God if you act as if you do-but it is made as an exception because it is virtually certain to produce a miscommunication. He also isn't a literal athiest-he seems to be a literal agnostic but I'm not sure.

Amy VanHym not quite but it's a similar idea, my understanding is that Occam's razor is more about the number of assumptions you've made rather than the detail of the theory but I might be wrong

Occam's Razor is "don't multiply entities unnecessarily." It means don't assume additional things not necessary for a complete explanation. When he's talking about high- vs. low-resolution, he means use the least amount of detail necessary in order to model something so that it remains as simple and accessible as possible.   It's not really the same thing. Occam's razor isn't suggesting you approximate by committing things that are actually there. It's just telling you not to make things up without a reason.

Martin W, in reading the CBA document, it seems their statement contradicts the quick stance on restricted speech.  "Hate speech legislation is not aimed at discouraging repugnant or offensive  ideas. It does not, for example, prohibit expression which debates the merits of reducing the rights of vulnerable groups in society. It only restricts the use of expression exposing them to hatred as a part of that debate. It does not target the ideas, but their mode of expression in public and the effect that this mode of expression may have." Arguably, misgendering a person, and if a professor were to do this frequently for weeks and months, would not be a debate of merit on all of this, but could be argued as an act of hatred toward that individual.  It continues, "The amendment to the CHRA will not compel the speech of private citizens.  ... In federally regulated workplaces, services, accommodation, and other areas covered by the CHRA, it will constrain unwanted, persistent behaviour (physical or verbal) that offends or humiliates individuals on the basis of their gender identity or expression. "  They are saying it doesn't do it for all private citizens, but in the case of a professor at a public university,  then if the persistent use of the incorrect gender expression which that person feels is offensive or humiliating, then this bill is seemingly restricting that speech.

Well I think he makes a lot of good points in this particular video, and I couldn't point to anything that I disagree with here. But the first thing that comes to mind that I do disagree with him in about in general is some of his views on religion, which is not something he talks about in this video. I hope this isn't too long winded, but sometimes reasoned discussions have to be long winded, as I said. Also note that I'm a computer programmer, not an expert on religion, but here's what I think.  He has said on a few occasions that true atheists cannot have morality, and if someone believes in morality and claims to be an atheist then they are not really an atheist. Now I've seen all of his lectures on the psychological significance of the Biblical stories, which covers Genesis in great detail, and even though I am an atheist, I think that the way he covered that material was logical and coherent and I think he sends a good message about why we should study these old religious stories, even if they are myths. So I do think he has a lot of good points to make about religion as well. However I disagree that morality requires belief in God, and that atheists who are moral are not real atheists.  I think the issue is the definition of God. "Theist" means someone who believes in God, but what does "God" mean? It's easy to say that someone doesn't believe in God if they don't believe in the same version of God that you do, and it looks to me like that's what Jordan does when he says that atheists who are moral are not really atheists. I might not be doing his argument justice, but I think his argument is that God represents the highest possible good, and morality is aiming at the highest possible good, and there's an objective truth about what actually constitutes "good." And if there's some objective truth underlying that, and it is independent of whether humans exists or not, then that's no different from the concept of "God" because God is objective and universal and independent of humanity's existence, the same as this abstract idea of objective morality and "good." So, since atheists believe in objective good or morality, they're not really atheists.  But most people don't mean that when they say "God." They just mean a deity, which is an all powerful, all knowing, conscious being who created the universe and the Earth and humans. When people say they believe in God they mean they literally believe that there is a unique being who consciously created everything. And I think that that description of God is not the same as Jordan's description of God. The deity description is about something concrete and that actually exists in the physical world, whereas Jordan's description is about something metaphysical, and that's not the same thing. For example, I believe in morality, but I do not believe in a literal deity.  Basically it boils down to a difference in terminology, in my opinion, and I think he fails to make the distinction between the two concepts because his opinion is that they're the same thing. There are probably a couple other things I disagree with him about too but this youtube comment is too long already.

There's already a field called literature that does what Jordan does with his "Maps of meaning" except they do it with any and every book. There's nothing special about the bible and its stories. We can get more meaning from comic books than the bible.  Is what is moral, what god says is moral? or is it moral irregardless of what god says?  If it is the former, then you are arguing for moral relativism. If it is the latter, then we can cut out the middle man and discern morality ourselves.  This was a kiddie interview at best. Hardly any real questions of substance that probed or challenged his beliefs.  Let's not forget about him lying about C-16.

Life is fundamentally suffering, because we're all doomed to die.  Everyone we know and love will die, and all of our struggles to live in the world will end, apparently meaninglessly.  We are adapted to feel fear and pain to drive us to stave off the inevitable end.  Since every day, we're another day closer to death, trying not to think about it, we suffer.   According to Peterson's research, most mythological stories were created to be a record of parables and lessons to help humans live with and navigate this fact.  He's not just throwing out mystical mumbo-jumbo; read maps of meaning--he goes into great detail deconstructing myths to show how they mostly are a response to people dealing with, and making the best out of the fact that we're all individually doomed to die. He demeans post modernists because they argue that they don't believe in any ideologies, then they irrationally promote Marxist ideologies, which makes them a bunch of hypocrites.  They were all french marxists in the 1950s whose cherished utopian beliefs were threatened after Stalin died (and his genocide was publicly admitted by the Soviets).  They say "nothing is real" to tear down other ideologies, but turn a blind eye to their own Marxism.  They simply re-skin the discredited marxist idea that everything is a oppressor vs oppressed power struggle between economic classes, to "everything is a power struggle between the races, or the genders, or sexual preferences".  Since nobody wants to be called racist or sexist, if anybody tries to point out the Postmodernists' hypocrisy, they can form their disciples into a bullying mob to name-call and shame critics into silence.  They are using social justice to push a pathological ideology.

Alister Sutherland I've actually been thinking quite a bit about why Peterson is so resonant. I think it's actually fairly simple and that most left wing critiques are spot on.   I think for more apolitical centrist types, he functions to preserve the status quo when people are increasingly concerned about disturbing noises coming from the  left (Concepts like "white privilege" "toxic masculinity" "institutional racism" "antifa" etc.) and right wing (Alt Right, Trump, Incels, MGTOW, Fascists, Populists, PEGIDA, UKIP,  EDL, etc.).  These people perceive him as a preserving a reasonable center/moderate position who preaches self-improvement over engagement in politics. He also champions easily supported and banal concepts like "free speech" and not judging people by their identity, but by their character.  To the right, I think conservatives/right wingers like him for a variety of reasons. One of the main reasons is that he is helping form what they perceive as a coherent ideological description and refutation of progressivism.   The left has had the biggest burst of innovation and a rapid adoption of new language and rhetoric probably since the 60s. Peterson positions himself as an "antidote" to this and equips primarily young conservatives with a means of understanding the root of progressive ideology and allows them to make sense of all these new ideas (again, "white privilege," "intersectionality" "systemic racism", etc.) and where they come from.   Unfortunately, mixed up in the answer he provides to conservatives is an old far right idea of "Cultural Marxism" which Peterson has repackaged as "Postmodern Neomarxism."  So, looking at this, you can see why Peterson is almost universally maligned by leftists and progressives and why they see him as such a threat.
